PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-THIRD PARLIAMENT
Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate passed on 16 December 1983, the Senate met on Tuesday, 28 February 1984, at 3 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Hon. Mick Young was appointed Special Minister of State and Leader of the House on 21 January 1984. The Hon. Kim Beazley remains Minister for Aviation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR FRANCIS PATRICK McMANUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 28 December 1983 of former Senator Francis Patrick McManus. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 28 December 1983, of Francis Patrick McManus, CMG, Senator for the State of Victoria from 1956 to 1962 and from 1965 to 1974 and former Leader and Deputy Leader of the Australian Democratic Labor Party, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Former Senator McManus died on 28 December 1983 when most honourable senators were on holiday or enjoying the break from this chamber. His death was perhaps less noticed than it might have been because it occurred on that date. He was a founding member of the Democratic Labor Party and he represented my State, Victoria, as a senator from 1956 to 1962 and from 1965 to 1974. I had personally a little to do with Senator McManus in 1955 before he became Democratic Labor Party senator for Victoria, but after that time I had no personal knowledge or experience of him except of his public record as a senator and as a person who was outspoken about the things in which he believed. He was, of course, a parliamentary leader in the Senate for a brief time between October 1973 and April 1974, and prior to that he was Deputy Leader of the Democratic Labor Party .

During his term of office in the Senate he served on a number of committees, I believe with distinction. As a result of that period of dedicated public service he was made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George in December 1979. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with the Government in expressing compassion and condolences to those members of his family who survive him after a prominent public career.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in support of this motion of condolence on the death of Francis Patrick McManus. It says something for the rate of change in Australian politics that the great majority of honourable senators here today did not serve with former Senator McManus, who left here as recently as 1974. Those of us who did not serve with him and who therefore did not know him personally all know something of his role in Australian politics over the period from 1955 in particular through to 1974 when he left the Senate. He was involved in matters of great principle and of deep division within the Australian political system, but I have never heard it suggested that he was other than a man of very great principle or that the arguments in which he became so strongly engaged were not arguments, for him, of very deep principle. I understand that he was educated at his local Christian Brothers College and that he later won a scholarship to Newman College at Melbourne University. Whatever view one took about the particular issues in which he was engaged, I believe that the men who educated him at those institutions would have regarded him as having followed through the principles that they delivered to him during his education.

SPEECH.PARA: I, on behalf of the Opposition, join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in expressing the sympathy of the Senate to his family, his associates and his friends. He was held in very great respect throughout the political spectrum. In a sense, I suppose that the more recent political events in Victoria are a reminder of some of the more permanent aspects of politics about which he was concerned. In any event, the Opposition joins very sincerely in this motion of condolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this motion of condolence towards the memory of the late Frank McManus and send sympathy to his family, not just on my behalf but on behalf of my Party. I knew Frank McManus very well. I attended his funeral, where I was greeted by a great number of people who stated that they were surprised to see me there because my attitudes towards the philosophies of the Party which he led with distinction were well known. I should have thought that it would be very difficult to find a party with a political persuasion so different to that of mine as was that of the Australian Democratic Labor Party. Notwithstanding that, my respect and admiration for Frank McManus the man transcended my feelings about the philosophy to which he chose to belong. He was a man of extraordinarily high principle, of total integrity, and a man of great compassion.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember with some affection some of the long philosophical discussions that he and I used to have when I and a fellow called Billy Snedden, and others, were callow back benchers in the Liberal Party. We used to go to the Yass railway station on Thursday nights in the winter and catch the train from Yass to Melbourne to save any delay at a fog-bound Canberra airport on Friday mornings. Frank McManus always accompanied us. Quite often the train was late, and on those wintery mornings, well into one o'clock or two o'clock in the morning, we used to have lengthy philosophical discussions, and we used to play ricky-ticky, with pound notes, as I remember, and we had general conversations about various issues.

If honourable senators had been at the funeral service at St Patrick's Cathedral, they would have been as impressed as I was, and as everyone who attended it was, not only with the number of people present-the enormous cathedral was packed to overflowing-but also with the genuine beliefs and feelings of sympathy and admiration for the man on the part of those present. It was a living tribute to a person who had made his contribution and passed on. I take this opportunity of putting on record my personal tribute to a good man.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in offering my personal sympathy and the sympathy of my Party, the National Party of Australia, to the family and friends of the late Senator McManus. I had the pleasant experience of serving in this chamber in the latter years of the late Senator McManus's period here, when he was Deputy Leader and then Leader of the Australian Democratic Labor Party. I remember him as a tall, distinguished and, above all things, scholarly member of this chamber. I suppose that if anything marked him more than any other single thing it was the measure of his dedication and sincerity. I am sure that wherever he moved he would have left that impression at least among those people with whom he spoke, both friends and foes. There was never any doubt that the late Senator McManus was sincere and dedicated in all of the things that he did. I again express my and my Party's sympathy to those he leaves behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with all other senators in paying tribute to the late Frank McManus and conveying to his widow, his two sons and his two daughters our warm sympathy. At the same time I record my own view-I am sure it is the view of many-that Frank McManus was a great Australian, a very distinguished person and a man of very singular qualities. I came to know him, as did Senator Chipp and others, in the time that I served here. I came to respect him as a man of high intellect, great integrity and massive courage.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever were the rights and wrongs of the 1950s there is no doubt at all that Frank McManus believed that what he did was right. He did it with courage and at great sacrifice to himself and to his family. He carried those principles with great honesty and integrity wherever he went and in whatever he said. He was a man of great humanity and great affection for others. Indeed, I quite willingly say that I had not only an admiration but also an affection for the man quite beyond the ordinary politics of this chamber. Because he stood up for his principles and was willing to run up his flag for what he believed in against his own self interests, he paid the price. Although I was not able to go to his funeral-I would have liked to do so-I am delighted that there should have been such a wide Australian acknowledgment of the man at the point of his death. Therefore, I am very happy to place his qualities on record. I think we are all the better, whatever our political views may be, from having walked with him and shared the dialogue of life with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frank McManus was born in North Melbourne in 1905. He was educated by the Christian Brothers and won a scholarship to Newman College at the University of Melbourne. He held an honours degree in English and Latin Literature and a Diploma of Education. He spent 19 years in high school teaching. He joined the Australian Labor Party in 1925 at the Flemington Branch. He was elected to the Victorian Executive of the Labor Party in 1947 and between 1949 and 1955 he was Assistant Secretary to the Victorian Branch of the ALP. In 1955 he was elected, with George Cole from Tasmania, to the Senate as ALP (Anti- Communist) Democratic Labor Party Senator. His term took effect from 1956. He was unsuccessful in the elections in 1961. From 1962 to 1964 he was Federal Organising Secretary to the DLP. In 1964 he was re-elected to the Senate. He was re-elected again in 1970 and in 1973 took over from Senator Gair as Federal Parliamentary Leader of the DLP. In 1974 he was defeated at the double dissolution.

SPEECH.PARA: In his retirement he wrote a book The Tumult and the Shouting. Frank McManus was married. He and his wife, Clare, had two sons and two daughters-Mary, Brendan, Paul and Noreen. One different feature of Frank was that he was No. 1 patron of the North Melbourne Football Club. He died on 28 December 1983 at the age of 78. His funeral was held on Tuesday, 3 January 1984. Unfortunately, I was not able to attend that funeral because at the same time the funeral of another great Australian citizen, John Traill, Q.C. who was a close friend of mine was being held in Sydney. Bishop Perkins was the principal concelebrant. There were four other bishops, 45 priests and over 1,000 people at St Patrick's Cathedral, Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well over 1,000.

—There were well over 1,000 people at that funeral. I did not know Frank McManus well. I got to know him in the 1950s. From memory I did not have the opportunity of renewing that acquaintance after the 1950s. As all honourable senators know, he stood a tall man and used to walk and speak with his hands behind his back, somewhat like a school teacher-reminiscent, of course , of the 19 years he spent as a high school teacher. He was an avid reader, mainly of history and biographies, and was a good customer to the Parliamentary Library. He had an aversion to travelling by plane and, as Senator Chipp has reminded us, he used to travel by car to Yass to meet the train going to Melbourne. He was a very strong family man and regretted the time that the Parliament kept him away from his family, particularly whilst his children were growing up. His wife Clare was very devoted.

SPEECH.PARA: Frank McManus had a great affection for Ireland. His father was born in County Roscommon. He was good friends with a number of journalists, including from the Press Gallery the late Kevin Power, Ian Fitchett, Alan Reid and the late Richard Hughes-the China watcher. He had some very close friends amongst the Chinese community in Melbourne. Perhaps his major interest during his parliamentary career was foreign affairs. He served on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

He had a dry sense of humour and a well-developed sense of the ridiculous. He often told jokes against himself. For example, in his book The Tumult and the Shouting he recalled his introduction to politics in the schoolyard in 1916 when the conscription debate was raging. He said:

I was accosted in the schoolyard at St Mary's by five or six boys and asked 'Are you for conscription?' I did not know what conscription was and said so. An answer was insisted on, so I guessed; I said 'Yes', and was promptly flattened.

Subsequently, largely because of the conscription debate, he joined the then Australian Labor Party. Senator McManus was always grateful for the assistance he received from the many thousands of ordinary men and women-support which enabled him to receive a very high 19.7 per cent of the vote in the 1970 Senate election. In the foreword to his book he paid tribute to those men and women who had fought over the years to save the Labor Party and the unions from communist domination. He said in that foreword:

They were branded as scabs and rats, as fascists and traitors; they were widely and ignorantly regarded as a Catholic mafia, seeking to take over Labor and the unions. They deserve no less than that the truth be told; therefore I have written this book.

As with many other books, The Tumult and the Shouting will probably be read and understood only now that the author has died. I take this opportunity of joining with other honourable senators in placing on record my support for the condolence motion and my sympathy for Senator McManus's family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR L. G. WALLIS

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 10 January 1984 of Mr Laurie Wallis, former member of the House of Representatives for the electorate of Grey, South Australia, from 1969 to 1980.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, on behalf of Government senators, I want to say a word about Laurie Wallis who died on 10 January 1984 aged 62 years. Mr Wallis was the honourable member for Grey in South Australia from 1969 to 1980. During his period of service in this Parliament he belonged to and served on many committees. All those things are a matter of record in the Parliamentary Handbook and I do not want to go into them .

SPEECH.PARA: On my own behalf and, I believe, on behalf of my colleagues, I want to say that Laurie Wallis will be very well remembered by us all, firstly as a man of great integrity and a very honest man. Secondly, he was a man with a great deal of common sense. I think Laurie Wallis was one of the best barometers in this place if one wanted to find out what sensible people were thinking in the sometimes frenetic atmosphere which arises here. Thirdly, he was a very diligent and hard working member for his electorate. It was an enormous electorate and he knew it very well. He worked very hard for the people of Grey in the time he was in this Parliament and in difficult times. Because of that, he remained the honourable member for Grey. On behalf of the Government I place on record those things about Laurie Wallis and express our sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the remarks which have been made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Mr Wallis was a member who was known to many of us-I suppose to all of us. I support the comments about him which were made by the Leader of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I served with him on one of the joint committees on which he served in the Parliament, namely, the Joint Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights in the Northern Territory. That exercise was one of many exercises in which one gets a great deal of non-partisan consideration of difficult and complex issues. It was the one opportunity I had to work with him directly. On that occasion he showed the sorts of qualities to which Senator Button has referred. I do not wish to say a great deal because I know that Senator Jessop has a wish to speak about this matter, but I extend the sympathy of the Opposition to Mr Wallis's family for the loss of a very fine man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Button has already pointed out, Laurie Wallis was the honourable member for Grey, which was indeed an enormous electorate covering more or less half of South Australia-the west coast and the upper northern regions of that area centred around what is known as the Iron Triangle, Whyalla, Port Pirie and Port Augusta.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of considerable regret to me that most honourable senators do not get the opportunity to know members of the House of Representatives very well. This is of course particularly true when they are not members of one's own political party. So my knowledge of Laurie Wallis is pretty much hearsay. Nevertheless, I think that no one will disagree with me when I say that he was well known and well liked in his electorate both as a man and as a member of parliament. He was widely respected as a person who cared for and worked hard for his electorate and for the people who lived in it. It was not an easy electorate to work for covering, as it did, such a large rural area plus a very large industrialised area, both of which suffered intensely from unemployment and the problems that go with it. I and my Party therefore join in the previous expressions of sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to join in the condolences for Mr Laurie Wallis. Mr Wallis worked very hard for the electorate of Grey. Laurie Wallis would meet with people of any political persuasion. He worked just as hard for members of the Country Party or the Liberal Party as he did for Aboriginals or members of the Australian Labor Party. It did not make any difference whether a person was wealthy or poor or what position he held, Laurie Wallis worked very hard. I believe he gained the respect of people in the electorate of Grey. It is a great loss because he worked so hard. I know that Laurie Wallis used to burn out a car every twelve months because of the distances that he had to travel in the huge electorate of Grey in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Laurie Wallis retired only a couple of years before he died. Before he entered Parliament he was a boilermaker. I believe that, like so many boilermakers, he had to work with asbestos. I still believe that that was the cause of Laurie Wallis's early death. It is a great shame that Laurie Wallis could not have gained some enjoyment from his retirement. His family saw very little of him. Any member who works in a huge electorate such as Grey must sacrifice some pleasant things, such as family life. My sympathy goes to his family, because, for the ten years he was a member, they saw very little of him. It is a great loss. As I said, it is unfortunate that he could not have had more time to enjoy his retirement. On behalf of all South Australian senators, I extend condolences to his wife and family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with this motion of condolence. As honourable senators know, following the redistribution in 1969 after which, unhappily, I lost 7,000 or 8,000 rural votes, Laurie Wallis was successful in taking from me the seat of Grey. It was a large area which covered nearly 90 per cent of the area of South Australia. I knew Laurie before he went into Parliament. He was a patient of mine and I regarded him always as a friend. I did not always agree with his political views, but he was a quiet man who quietly went about the task of serving his large electorate. As Senator Elstob has said, irrespective of people's political views, he did his very best to serve them. I would like to pay that tribute to him. I was able to attend his funeral and paid my personal respects to his widow. I would like to place on record my feelings of a man whom I regarded as a friend and who served his people well. I pass on my condolences to his wife and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with this motion of condolence for two reasons. Firstly, Laurie Wallis was a good friend of anyone with whom he came into contact. He was a man of the people. Secondly, he represented the electorate of Grey which includes the town of Quorn where I was born and the area in which I worked for some time. I did not actually work in Quorn, but certainly in the northern area. It has always been recognised far and wide in Australia that the northern people are the salt of the earth. Laurie Wallis was a typical northerner. He dedicated himself to his job and I know from first hand knowledge from relations in the area that, as has been said by Senator Elstob, he did his job without fear or favour. I join with other senators in supporting this condolence motion and expressing sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask your indulgence and the indulgence of the Senate to raise a point of order concerning the condolence motions. In the white copy, the draft program, which was circulated in this place earlier this morning to party leaders there were to be condolence motions regarding the late Senator McManus, the late Mr Laurie Wallis and the late Mr Andropov. However, on the Notice Paper the last name does not appear. When inquiring into this omission I was told that certain people who prepare the Notice Paper considered that in view of the remarks that I made the last time a condolence motion was raised in regard to a Russian leader, Mr Brezhnev, it might be more desirable to leave Mr Andropov's name off and avoid that sort of situation. In the event, had a condolence motion to the late Soviet leader been on the Notice Paper, I would have used similar expressions of concern and put on the record some of the crimes against humanity for which he was responsible.

INTERJECT.PARA: That is not the point I am raising today. I am asking you, Mr President, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) or somebody else to refer this matter to the Senate Standing Orders Committee. The point I am making is that it is undesirable for a certain group in this place, whoever they might be-Whips, officials or party leaders-to say who shall or shall not be listed if they are a head of state who has died. Are we reaching a situation where a certain group here will determine that only 'the good guys' are listed for condolences? If so, who will determine the criteria? It is a matter of some concern. I have a personal view that it is time we stopped this nonsense of putting the names of any heads of state on the Notice Paper. I believe it is reaching a serious situation if we are going to discriminate between one head of state and another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. It is not a matter for the Chair. It is a matter of programming arrangements on the part of the Government. I suggest that if the honourable senator wishes to pursue the matter he should direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate at Question Time . So far as the honourable senator's suggestion about the Senate Standing Orders Committee is concerned, I will see that the matter raised by him is taken up by the Committee when it meets.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: Protest to the proposed change to the Oath of Allegiance in which recognition of God and the Queen would be deleted.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should- Request that the Oath of Allegiance remain unchanged.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows: that Australia is basically a Christian nation, as shown by figures from the last census. That the Queen of Australia is recognised as head of Australia's Parliamentary System. That no mandate has been sought from, or given by the Australian people to alter our Oath of Allegiance, the proposal to amend the Citizenship Act not being publicised prior to the last Federal election. That removal of reference to God and the Queen is the first small, though significant step towards Republicanism.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Government does not remove references to God and the Queen from our Oath of Allegiance and that it be allowed to remain unchanged.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHANEY; COLLARD; DURACK; GUILFOYLE; SCOTT; TEAGUE; WITHERS
PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that General Revenue Grants to Local Government under Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83, the inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent, the increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent, increased demands are being made on Local Government Authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g., Community Employment Program, the Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 46 citizens), Collard (from 25 citizens), Durack (from 11 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 22 citizens), Scott (from 39 citizens), Teague (from 15 citizens) and Withers (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools, through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 36 citizens), Ryan (from 762 citizens) and Zakharov ( from 40 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Scott (from 75 citizens) and Sibraa (from 57 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post-School Education Sector
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the post-school education sector has been neglected in recent years.
Therefore we call on members of the Senate to endorse:
(1) Increases in TEAS to at least the level of the poverty line. All people should be guaranteed a living wage.
(2) Increased funding for campus based childcare.
(3) The abolition of the overseas student visa charge which is grossly discriminatory.
(4) Increased funding for student housing.
(5) Increased funding for libraries to ensure facilities are adequate.
(6) The establishment or supplementation of campus based student loan funds which are interest and free short-term.
(7) Increasing the level and number of postgraduate awards.
(8) Extending services to part-time, mature age and external students to open access to education.
(9) Increasing student representation at all levels.
(10) Innovation in curriculum to ensure curriculum is relevant and critical.
(11) Increasing education funding to improve existing facilities.
(12) Funding quality student health services which help contribute to the successful completion of courses.
(13) Expanding enrolments to open access to education.
(14) Compensating institutions for the costs of amalgamation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The Senate will support the above claims.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 19 citizens) and Jones (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Scott (from 19 citizens), Sibraa (from 65 citizens), Walsh (from 63 citizens) and Zakharov (from 87 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc., for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
Domestic consumers dependent on L.P. gas are currently disadvantaged by the current pricing system of L.P. gas which imposes exorbitantly high energy bills.
Country consumers have a choice of using a mixture of expensive L.P. gas and electricity, or switching to all-electric homes and paying higher tariffs.
In addition they miss out on the concession on winter gas bills announced by the State Government because the pricing of L.P. gas is a Commonwealth, not a State matter.
Your humble petitioners therefore pray that: The pricing of L.P. gas undergo a thorough public review to determine a pricing structure which does not disadvantage domestic consumers of L.P. gas.
That this review be determined by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with the Victorian Government and domestic consumers and community groups.
That domestic consumers of L.P. gas receive any concessions available to the users of reticulated gas.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, recently discovered 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, equal in importance to those in the Vesere Valley in France, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. The constitutional basis for protecting historical and environmental assets remains weak.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the duty and a right superior to State and local governments to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore, those things we hold in trust for the future.
Being relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance.
To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, to manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and in any other matter which might be seen to be in the same spirit.
In particular to prevent beach mining, preserve the Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and consider its extension into the Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Friendly Societies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned, being Electors in the State of New South Wales, respectfully submit that the Government review its intention to tax Friendly Societies after so many years of service to the community at large.
And in faith your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Young unemployed people continue to suffer discrimination through insufficient income.

We therefore humbly request that the Commonwealth of Australia: Make available unemployment benefits to all young people who have left school. And that the unemployment benefits for those between the ages of sixteen and eighteen be raised to the level of the adult benefit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: 'Countrywide Calling' Telephone System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government of Australia is discriminating against Australians living in remote areas through the introduction by Telecom of the 'Countrywide Calling' telephone system;
2. That people adversely affected by the new telephone charging system should not be further disadvantaged by having to bear these additional charges; and
3. Calls on the Government to allow those disadvantaged by the new arrangement to retain their local call status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Student Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty-five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:

1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students. The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.

2. Decrease access to education for country students. Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even further disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to ensure:
(1) That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
(2) That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closures of colleges in Victoria.
(3) That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

(4) That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e., accommodation appropriate for students with dependant children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserve
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia are concerned at the termination of the tax exemption on Defence Force Reserve pay. We are convinced that unequal relativities in pay will occur and the Reserve Force will lose a large number of dedicated trained servicemen and women which will make it impossible for the Reserve to meet its commitments to the defence of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will act to form a Senate Select Committee to inquire into and report on the effect of the removal of the tax exemption prior to the implementation of Government policy.

PETITION.TITLE: Manual Assistance Centre, Parkes
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposal of Telecom Australia to close the Manual Assistance Centre at Parkes will severely disadvantage the Parkes community by:
1. The loss of current employment and future employment opportunities and consequent loss of income to the district
2. The loss of a local 24 hour emergency service
3. The loss of local knowledge of telephonists being available to telephone users when traffic is routed to an exchange anywhere in the State
4. The loss of a local and personalised service provided especially to elderly and handicapped people.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable Senate will call on the Government to halt the closure pending a full and open inquiry into the needs and desires of affected subscribers and the full economic and social effects of the closure on this district, rural telephone subscribers and Telecom Australia employees.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Investigation of Foreign Affairs Officers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. A petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we believe that there should be a thorough investigation by a parliamentary committee into all allegations of corruption and improper conduct by Foreign Affairs officers, whether made in the Parliament or otherwise.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Don Witheford
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. A petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we believe that all charges against Mr Don Witheford of the Department of Foreign Affairs should be dropped and that he should be immediately reinstated to his former position.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF NUCLEAR MATERIALS) BILL 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the exportation of nuclear materials, and for purposes connected therewith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 so as to give further protection to consumers in respect of defective motor vehicles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: — I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate deplores moves by the Queensland Government to encourage and facilitate sand mining on Moreton Island and urges that the Federal Government immediately declares the entire area of Moreton Island a national park.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate congratulates Queensland's banana growers, particularly those newcomers to the industry in North Queensland, who, for the first time, have produced more bananas than their counterparts across the border in New South Wales and are setting new records each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is there, or is there not, to be an assets test?
—Yes, I expect so.

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for Health receive a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Andrew Peacock, as I did, requesting his assistance in fighting creeping socialism, especially in Medicare ? Did his letter ask first for a donation to the Liberal Party of Australia and, secondly, for him to fill in a brief questionnaire on which future Liberal Party policy about health insurance would be based? Does the Minister agree with one of Mr Peacock's assertions that he will not tolerate free public hospital beds, regardless of patients' means, or does he agree that this betrays Mr Peacock's failure to understand the Medicare levy, which is based on patients' ability to pay, that is, according to means? Finally, does the Minister agree that Mr Peacock should check his medical mailing list?

—Yes, like Senator Crowley, I did receive a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, asking me, amongst other things, whether I would donate at least $25 to assist the Liberal Party in its fight against the Labor Party, and assuring me that he would continue his fight against what he called the nationalisation of the health industry in this country. Incorporated in the letter, I think Senator Crowley will agree with me, are the most puerile yes/no questions I have ever seen in my life. I think the first question was, 'Are you opposed to Medicare? Yes/No'-one was to be crossed out. Others were 'Are you opposed to nationalised medicine? Yes/No', 'Do you like the Liberal Party? Yes/ No', et cetera. At the bottom of the letter were two lines. The first line read: 'Will you send a donation of $25 to the Liberal Party?' The second line read: ' Will you send a donation . . . to the Liberal Party to enable Andrew Peacock personally to lead the fight against' what he called, as Senator Crowley said, ' creeping socialism?' Certainly the letter sent to me and the letter sent to Senator Crowley indicate that the Liberal Party has some problems with its mailing list.
—Answer the question. Did you send him any money?

—I will come to that. The Liberal Party really has problems with its mailing list. As my colleague Mr Young has pointed out, some people may send some money, but under the new legislation some may not be so keen to do so because they may have to disclose the amount of money they have sent.
—That sort of statement inspired many doctors.
—I hear Senator Walters, the greatest representative of the medical profession in this place, known amongst her own colleagues as 'creamy', because she is rich and thick.
—Order! The honourable senator should withdraw that remark.
—I am sorry; I did not call her that, Mr President.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.

—Yes, I withdraw that. If Senator Walters wants to come into this chamber and represent the privileged in the community, she can. But I am in the extraordinary situation of having received that letter from Mr Peacock. I say to Senator Chipp and Senator Crowley that no, I did not send him any money. I am not likely to. I suspect that neither are the majority of the doctors in this country.

—My question follows that asked by Senator Crowley, which related to the courtesy my Leader displayed in sending a letter to Senator Grimes. I ask the Minister for Social Security: Did his Leader have the courtesy to send him a letter, or perhaps to use the telephone, to contact him about the change in the assets test before he announced it to the waiting Australian public at the Press Club last week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a surprising question! I spoke to the Prime Minister about this matter on the day he came back from China. I also spoke to him about this matter on Monday last week, I believe. The reason that this matter came up, of course, was that the Government was in the position-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-The by-election.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the by-election was before that. Honourable senators should get their facts right. Last November the Government was informed-through the Press, of course-by the Leader of the National Party that the Opposition was not going to oppose this legislation, that it might defer it until February. We were informed also that the Australian Democrats would agree to a deferral of the legislation but would not oppose it. In recent weeks, of course, Senator Messner , who I notice changes his appearance with his views, announced that the Liberal Party would again defer the legislation. Senator Chipp and the Democrats also decided that they would defer the legislation. So, of course, the Government had to make moves to take that situation into account. It was for that reason that we decided at the Cabinet meeting in Hobart that we would discuss this matter. It was for that reason that Mr Hawke announced on Wednesday what the Government was going to discuss on Thursday.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: 1986 CENSUS: QUESTIONS ON INCOME AND WEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the finding some years ago of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, appointed by the McMahon Government, that 'the effective discussion of taxation policy in this country is hampered at every turn by the lack of reliable data about the distribution of income and wealth'. In view of the Committee's conclusion that an inquiry into these matters would be valuable, is it now proposed that the 1986 census include questions on incomes and private wealth ownership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the 1986 census forms, if printed in accordance with current recommendations, will include a question on income, as the previous census and, I think, at least one census previous to that did. The current recommendation does not include the asking of a question on wealth or total assets, nor does it re- commend that the sources of income be disclosed, other than payments from government. A question relating to the sources of income might give some indication of wealth holdings, but it would be an imperfect measure of wealth, a fact which I am sure Senator Maguire would appreciate. Nevertheless, if he wishes me to, I am quite willing to ask the Treasurer whether he will consider including in the question on income the various sources from which that income is derived.

ANSWER.PARA: I also understand, in a more general sense relevant to the question that Senator Maguire asked, that the Prime Minister's office has recently spoken to Professor Karmel. While I am not aware of the details, tentative discussions were held as to the most expeditious way in which wealth holdings and variation of wealth holdings may be accurately determined. As Senator Maguire's question suggests, it is very important for any government which is seriously interested in equitable social policies that reliable information on wealth holdings be available.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ILLEGAL RECEIPT OF SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Can the Government estimate the number of people who are illegally and improperly receiving unemployment benefit, pensions and sickness and other benefits? Does the estimated loss of revenue due to this illegal activity exceed several hundred million dollars per year? What argument can the Government advance against the proposition that receipt of any benefit from the Government should be gained only after producing an identity card showing the name, address, photograph, registered number and signature of the bearer? Even though there may be some valid concerns as to civil liberties, is such a card not a logical extension of the Medicare card and may not the savings to taxpayers warrant it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has asked a question which concerns many people in the community. The exact amount of money which it can be estimated people are receiving improperly-that is, illegally and otherwise-from the Department of Social Security is very difficult to assess. It certainly is not, I believe, many hundreds of millions of dollars, but I will see whether we have the latest figure available.
—Did you say it is not?

—Well, not hundreds of millions, as Senator Chipp said. The matter of identity cards comes up quite frequently and creates much debate in this country. The first thing to point out is that to produce an identity card which is beyond falsification or corruption is not easy and is a considerable administrative problem. The fact that there is a name, a number and a signature on it does not mean that people cannot get round the system. For instance, in the United States of America, everyone from the President to the latest new-born babe has a social security number. However, at the same time, one of the big and continuing controversies in the United States is the amount of alleged fraud on the social security system.

ANSWER.PARA: We also have a political problem, to which Senator Chipp referred. For instance , at various times Mr Anthony, the former Leader of the National Party, has said that everyone should have an identity card or social security card of that type before he or she receives benefits. Yet at the same time people such as Mr Fraser, the former Prime Minister and Leader of the Liberal Party, have said that the introduction of such a card, even just for the health insurance system, was akin to nazi Germany in 1939. I know that it depends a little on what stage of the political cycle people are talking about, but there is always the complaint that the introduction of such a card or such compulsory identification is an offence against civil liberties. I do not necessarily agree with that.

However, I point out that it is administratively very difficult and very costly to produce cards which cover the whole population and which would not be able to be subject to deception in the way that Senator Chipp is concerned about. The Department of Social Security and, I understand, other departments are continually looking at this matter, but until now we have no proposals to introduce such a system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The banks can do it; why can't the Government?

—There is a great difference between the Medicare card, banks' arrangements and the taxation system. Everyone who pays taxes has a number. We have a political problem in that, every time this matter is raised in this place , I can guarantee that there will be a whole lot of people on the Opposition benches who will say that it is akin to something in nazi Germany, and that there will be some people on our side of the Parliament who will be worried about the civil liberties aspects of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Medicare system, as honourable senators will know, some people have managed, through various means, to get more than one card. This is a simplistic method which is attractive to many people but; when one comes to the nitty gritty of just how to go about it, one finds that it is a difficult administrative problem. In the United States of America and in such countries in which a similar system exists, it does not eliminate social security fraud in the way in which Senator Chipp would believe that it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen media reports over recent weeks of allegations of corruption and security breaches made by a former Foreign Affairs officer, Mrs Van Dartel? Will the Minister support a parliamentary investigation into these allegations? Will he also investigate allegations by several officers that the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Peter Henderson, used the diplomatic bag for the illegal transportation of a valuable set of jewellery from Sri Lanka, along with expensive perfume and other items for personal use? Will Mr Henderson be suspended from duty whilst these investigations are conducted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of Press reports, as I am, of allegations made by Mrs Van Dartel about misuse of diplomatic bags and loss of classified documents. Mrs Van Dartel was an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs until 1980, when ill health led to her being retired from the Public Service on invalidity grounds. In the absence of specific details, the Department of Foreign Affairs, I am told, has been unable to substantiate Mrs Van Dartel's claims. However, they have been brought to the attention of the police.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of diplomatic bags, I assure honourable senators that Australian diplomatic bags arriving in the Department of Foreign Affairs from Australian missions overseas have no immunity and are regularly and thoroughly inspected by Customs officers. Items deemed to be other than official are subject to the normal range of Customs duties and quarantine regulations. Other than those responses, I am afraid that I am unable to assist Senator Primmer further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Attorney-General. I refer him to questions that I asked him on 30 November and 8 December last year concerning the need for an investigation into possible breaches of Federal law involved in allegations published in the National Times. In view of the undertakings given on both of those occasions, why did it take the Attorney and the Special Minister of State more than two months to initiate any proper inquiry into these allegations of corruption involving a Sydney solicitor, a senior judge and several crime figures? Now that the Government has, belatedly, appointed a Special Prosecutor and a Joint Police Task Force to inquire into some aspects of the questions raised initially in the National Times, when does the Attorney- General expect to be in a position to report to the Senate on the substance of those allegations?
—In about 46 minutes time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns a case where a person who has defaulted on his maintenance payments over several years is now receiving unemployment benefit and is having his accrued maintenance debt paid off in the form of child allowance payments. Will the Minister explain why the defaulting payer is not liable to repay the Department? Does the Minister agree that this system is actually rewarding long term maintenance dodgers?

—I am not sure that I have the exact gist of Senator Elstob's question. It seems to me that he is suggesting that someone who has defaulted on his maintenance payments is paying the money back in the form of child allowance or family allowance payments.
—Exactly.

—I assume-I am thinking aloud-that in those circumstances the person receiving the unemployment benefit and the family allowance, or the allowance for children, had custody of the children and was paying his separated spouse back out of those children's allowances. I cannot imagine any way in which the Department of Social Security could force someone in those circumstances to use those allowances in any particular way. However, if Senator Elstob gives me the details of the case I will be perfectly happy to take that matter up with the Department to see just what is happening and whether this is an abuse of the system. I would not like, any more than anybody else, to see the social security system abused in the way that Senator Elstob seems to think it is being abused.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I will phrase the question politely. I refer to the Prime Minister's speech to the National Press Club last week in which he admitted that his Government had made a mistake regarding the assets test. He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It has become clear that there is continuing and justifiable uncertainty about whether the Government has yet found the best way to implement legislation on an assets test in a fair and equitable way.

Given this justifiable uncertainty about the fairness and equity of the assets tests legislation, will the Minister explain why he wanted to push the legislation through the Parliament last year before its full implications could be thought through-action which would have imposed a defective and punitive assets test on the aged people of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters referred to a statement by the Prime Minister last week about justifiable concern by various pensioners in the community about the assets test. I agree with that statement. Some pensioners were concerned, and justifiably so. They were justifiably concerned because--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is a complete misrepresentation of what Senator Walters asked. The words were:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . continuing and justifiable uncertainty about whether the Government has yet found the best way to implement legislation . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.
—Thank you, Mr President. The Leader of the Opposition is very stroppy early in the session.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—If I can answer the question in my way, as Senator Chaney used to do in the same circumstances I will be grateful. The concern is, of course, justifiable in the light of what the Government did. I will go through it very carefully. We announced last August that we would introduce an assets test, giving a general outline. We said we would not introduce the legislation until November, to give people a chance to look at it and to allow me and others to have discussions with various organisations about the test. Come November, the Opposition announced that that was not enough and that it would defer the legislation. So we introduced the legislation into the House of Representatives and said we would reintroduce it at the start of this session after we had had further consultations, especially in the light of the fact that after the legislation was introduced and passed in February there would be another period of nine months or so until November in which people could further look at it and further talk about what they thought might be anomalies. The Opposition, of course, announced that that was not enough and that it would defer the legislation again. That became an intolerable situation.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem was that although the assets test would affect only a small percentage of pensioners and although up to 85 per cent would not be affected at all we had the situation-it is an understandable situation in our political system-in which people, including members of the Opposition, were saying to pensioners that they would all be affected, their house would be affected, et cetera. What we did not have at any stage was a suggestion from the Opposition on just what it would do. We know that it was opposed to the lump sum taxation on superannuation. We know that it was opposed to the introduction of the attentuated means test for those over 70. We know that it was opposed to the assets test. But it has had no positive proposals. The only positive proposal was that of Senator Macklin. He wants a national superannuation scheme of the Hancock type which would involve a 5 per cent levy on people's taxable income. That would be an interesting debate in this country.

We were in a situation where there was uncertainty. That uncertainty was justified in view of the propaganda that had been put around. We thought that the best thing to do was to establish a panel of people. I believe that when that panel of people is announced even the Opposition will accept it as being expert, dispassionate, able to look at the situation and able to take evidence from all those in the community who have a view, including members of the Opposition such as Senator Messner, Mr Peacock and even Senator Walters, if she can get it down on paper. They can come along and say, as they have always said: 'We believe in a needs-based pension system and a needs-based social security system. This is how we would do it. We would not do it in the way in which the Government was going to do it with its assets test. We will do it this way'. It will be a very interesting day--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are quite willing to talk about what you are saying before the election.

—It will be an interesting day when the Opposition in this place actually comes forward with some positive views on what it would do. I hear Senator Messner talking. Senator Messner is an honourable senator. We are all honourable senators-the Standing Orders say so. Therefore, the dreadful rumour going round this Parliament and the Press Gallery in this place that when he was Minister for Veterans' Affairs he actually advocated the introduction of an assets test cannot, of course, be true. We know that could not be true because Senator Messner is an honourable man. But once this review panel is in place Senator Messner will be able actually to go to it and say: 'This is what I believe in'. Then we can have a debate about what people believe in. Senator Walters believes that people should be able to have as much as they like and get as much as they like from the Government in those circumstances. I believe we have given everybody in the community the opportunity to express their views clearly to a dispassionate, non-political panel. It will be an interesting day when they all do.
—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not refer at all to the Prime Minister's admission of the Government making a mistake. Will he refer to that part of my question?

—Certainly. I remember very well what the Prime Minister said. He referred to the fact that we introduced the assets test in the way in which we did and that we encouraged a prolonged debate. As a result some people were quite justifiably disturbed. I have said that several times. Senator Walters was not disturbed. Therefore, we have taken the action that we have. I put it to honourable senators opposite that that is very different from a former Minister for Social Security in this place getting up and standing very near to where I am standing and saying: 'We will probably limit people to having $3,000 in cheque accounts. We will probably introduce some legislation which will restrict the amount people can have in those accounts'. I well remember Senator Giles and I month after month asking: 'What will you do?' Eventually, after about 12 months, the former Minister for Social Security said that it was too hard. We are not saying that. We are giving members of the Opposition a chance to get up and say what they think. I hope that they do.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen the Insurance Commissioner's annual report for 1982-83? Is it the case that the Commissioner's report tells us that for 1982-83 the general insurance industry as a whole failed to record a profit and that it continues to amass large underwriting deficits in the compulsory compensation classes of business? Does this mean we can expect another bout of hefty premium increases to shore up this ailing industry? Is this one of the concerns that lies behind the Government's commitment to co-operate with the States in establishing a national compensation scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the annual report of the Insurance Commissioner for 1982-83. Like other honourable senators, I would be concerned at a deterioration in the performance of the general insurance industry in this area. Private insurers have in fact accumulated nearly $1,100m in underwriting losses in the past three years and almost half of this loss occurred in 1982-83. Much of the loss has resulted from the compulsory compensation classes of business.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree that we can expect another round of workers compensation and, in fact, compulsory third party premium increases as a result. As Senator Cook says, we have all heard this before. This is the same tired story we have grown used to over the years. It is of great concern because the premium increases which will result-as they have resulted in the past-will be at the expense of a further tightening of the labour market because workers compensation costs are a major indirect cost of labour. In fact, after taxation they are the major cost of this type to various employers. This results in higher inflation because at least some part of workers compensation costs are passed on in higher prices and compulsory third party premiums are included in the consumer price index basket of goods which are calculated every three months. There is also obviously some loss of business profitability and competitiveness.

This situation is all the more lamentable when one recognises that, after excluding the State government insurance offices, about two-thirds of workers compensation and all compulsory third party business is now operated for the benefit of little more than a handful of insurance companies-of the order of 10 companies at the last count. The only solution to this would seem to be a co- operative effort from both the States and the Commonwealth Government to establish a more rational compensation system. The very serious alternative to this may in fact be a collapsing around our ears with an increasingly severe restraint on economic activity, which I do not think anyone wants.

I believe, as Senator Cook obviously believes, that we have to look forward to a rational, sensible, sure and economical system of compensation in this country through a national compensation scheme, whether it is done through the Federal Government or with the co-operative effort of the State and Federal governments. I hope that day will come but, like other honourable senators, I hoped that day would come back in 1974 when I was in this place and the idea was first introduced. It seems as though it is a long time coming.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's National Press Club speech last week in which he said that after conversations with 'some senior Ministers that I have had time to consult' he had decided that the whole question of asset testing had to be looked at again by Cabinet at its Hobart meeting last week. Given that Senator Grimes is fourth in the Ministry ranking and he was not informed of the Prime Minister's decision to back down, can the Minister inform the Senate whether he or Mr Bowen were consulted on this matter?

—I cannot inform the Senate in relation to Mr Bowen. I suggest that Senator Bjelke-Petersen pursue that matter with Mr Bowen in the House of Representatives through one of her National Party colleagues. I was not consulted about the details of the announcement that was made at the Press Club on Wednesday last week.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: REFERRALS TO SPECIALISTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' affairs to the recent cries of poverty from medical specialists, and ask: Can he advise the Senate of the extent to which private specialists have benefited financially from referrals by his Department? Is it a fact that expenditure on private specialists in the current financial year is far outstripping expenditure in the previous financial year? Is it also the case that certain specialists who are leading the campaign against Medicare and the Government's other health care initiatives are amongst the principal beneficiaries of referrals by his Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus referred to the obvious controversy which exists as a result of the passage of the Medicare legislation by the House of Representatives and the Senate and the resultant exaggerated statements that have been made by some groups of specialists and some sections of the Australian Medical Association in respect of the expenditure containment proposals which the Government insists will be followed in the wake of the Medicare legislation. Naturally, of course, the Department of Health, which is the Department most affected by the proposals and my Department, in which there is about one-third or one-quarter of such expenditure in this area, have looked at the costs involved in specialist treatment. Expenditure by the Department of Veterans' Affairs on private specialists in 1982-83 was $32.2m.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note that in the first seven months of this financial year expenditure has been $22.1m. If those figures are maintained they will result in an increase in expenditure of 18 per cent during a period in which everybody in Australia is being requested to exercise some measure of economic restraint. Of course, employees generally, in accordance with the prices and incomes accord, have followed that request fairly strictly. However, there are sections of the Australian community which are not prepared to put into effect the assurances that they gave at the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983. For example, in my Department in New South Wales expenditure for the first seven months of the financial year has been $11.4m, which represents a projected increase of 14 per cent over 1982-83.
