Included in the list are eight or nine specialists' firms and individual doctors who have benefited annually by amounts in excess of $100,000. In particular, in the area of pathology, six centres in New South Wales have benefited to the tune of between $110,000 and $554,000. As regards the centre which has received payments from my Department of $554,000, this represents five or six times the salary of the Australian Prime Minister. When that figure is multiplied three or four times to take into account the amount which is paid by the Department of Health, one can estimate the desire of the Government to have some containment in the area of payments to specialists in Australia.

Of course, I find it ironic that prominent amongst the list of specialists are several doctors who are leading scurrilous campaigns against Medicare which are not only based on deceit and misinformation but also creating a great deal of confusion in the Australian community. This Government is determined to ventilate publicly those doctors who are making considerable incomes out of specialist attention in our repatriation general hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Attorney- General confirm that the Prime Minister has been unsuccessful in his request to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to amend the new Northern Territory Criminal Code where that Code offends against the notions of criminal justice and particularly where it disadvantages Aboriginal people? If this is the case, will the Attorney inform the Senate whether the Government has decided to advise the Governor-General to disallow or amend this legislation which is so contrary to the principles of justice and personal liberty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that a number of aspects of the Northern Territory Criminal Code continue to give rise to considerable concern not only among lawyers but also among all those in this country with a keen interest in civil liberties, particularly the application of the criminal justice system to minority groups such as Aboriginals. Four particular matters in the present code appear to the Government to be quite unconscionable by reference to Australia's international obligations in particular under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It is also unconscionable by reference to the traditional standards of the Anglo-Saxon tradition of criminal jurisprudence which we have inherited.

ANSWER.PARA: Those matters relate to issues concerning the mental element in offences in which drunkenness is involved, fines for persons who are in fact not convicted of any offence, the provisions relating to proscribed organisations, in particular the absence of any provision for judicial review in relation to such organisations, and the complete abolition without qualification of unsworn statements from the dock.

These matters have now been the subject of a further letter from the Prime Minister to the Northern Territory Chief Minister. I am not sure whether it is accurate to say the Prime Minister has been rebuffed once again because I think the letter has been sent only in the last 24 hours or so. In that letter a further course of action is foreshadowed. I believe it would be premature to say anything more about that course of action and indeed the details of the latest plea that has been made to the Northern Territory by the Commonwealth Government . I simply say that the Commonwealth Government remains hopeful, although not tremendously optimistic, that reason and common sense will still prevail without the necessity for more severe measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Veterans' Affairs receive a considerable number of complaints from veterans and their representatives regarding delays in the repatriation determining system? Can the Minister advise the Senate how many repatriation claims are outstanding at present? Does the Minister regard this situation as satisfactory? If not, what steps is he taking to overcome the problems that currently exist in the repatriation determining system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably one of the areas that both my predecessor, Senator Messner, and I would accept as occasioning a great deal of complaint is that concerning the delays in the repatriation determining system. Clearly it is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs when people who served their country in time of war make application for a pension and have to go through the processes of the system that start at one tier and finish up four tiers later, with a lot of tears in between, by the way. That process takes from an average of 268 days to reach the Repatriation Board, to 784 days to reach the final Repatriation Review Tribunal. Of course, that is very unsatisfactory. At the end of January, for example, 17,000 entitlement claims were waiting to go before the repatriation boards. Another 8,800 pending claims were for an increase in the disability pension. Naturally, of course, those claims have been occasioned by the health of the applicants. Consequently any delay lessens their standard of living. Something like 3,700 entitlement claims were awaiting the Repatriation Commission; 4,500 were before the Repatriation Review Tribunal, as well as 2,700 assessment claims also before the Tribunal. The Government and I regard this backlog as completely unsatisfactory because it often denies benefits to people in their declining years.

ANSWER.PARA: I advise Senator Colston and the Senate generally that I will be taking to Cabinet within the next few weeks proposals designed to remedy the problems in the determining system which have led to the accumulation of this backlog. I am sure that this legislation will receive the assent of all members of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the 1,400 staff that have been employed and trained in order that they might administer the proposed assets test on pensioners. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the duties that these officers are currently undertaking now that the intended legislation is being reviewed? What has been the cost to the taxpayer of employing these officers, training them and paying them to fulfil a duty that does not exist? In retrospect, does the Minister still stand by his defence of the employment of these people last year before the assets test legislation had been decided upon by the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is normal practice in the Public Service in this country- it has been for many years through all sorts of governments-to prepare for the introduction of legislation which it is announced will be introduced in the Budget in this way. The introduction of an assets test has a long lead time. We have always said that. From the sorts of comments which were made by the Opposition last year I think it was reasonably expected that the legislation would pass in February or March this year. The people who have been employed have been largely in training for the implementation of the assets test. They have been employed training themselves or training others on the preparation for the introduction of the test which at the moment is deferred.

ANSWER.PARA: I am the first to admit that 1,400 people is a lot of people, but I think Senator Hill should remember that the normal turnover of staff in the Department of Social Security is some 300 a month; so it does not take long, if one stops recruitment, to run down that number of people. Also there are many other activities which can be performed in my Department from now on. In the past few years pension reviews, for instance, have been intermittent in some cases. There is a need for more extensive training. In the last five years training was cut down considerably in the Department and this has affected its efficiency. At the moment officers from my Department, the Public Service Board and the Department of Finance are discussing independently and with each other the reallocation of such staff within the Department and if necessary outside the Department. I will get to Senator Hill as soon as possible the exact figures on what it has cost until now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that almost all diagnostic specialists in Queensland public hospitals have been employed by the State Government for more than 20 years under contracts almost identical to those proposed for the public health hospitals in other States by the present Federal Minister for Health? Is it not also a fact that, because this system has been proven to work well in Queensland hospitals for more than two decades, it is unlikely that any active support will be forthcoming from doctors in that State for the inexcusable strike now being threatened for Thursday by the mercenary minority of doctors in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I agree with the gist of Senator Jones's question, but I think it is worthwhile pointing out that he is not quite accurate. In fact the contracts under which the doctors he referred to in Queensland hospitals work are much harsher, and certainly much more restrictive, than the contracts proposed by the present Federal Minister for Health under section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. The Commonwealth Government's initial proposals were that salaried specialists would be able to earn an additional 25 per cent above a senior specialist's salary from private work in a public hospital. That is, they can earn another $12,500 a year on top of the $50,000 a year which is the average per annum salary of senior specialists in hospitals. Visiting specialists and radiologists in hospitals would have been able to earn $62,500 a year without any restrictions. They could then leave 25 per cent of their earnings-between $62,000 and $87,500-in a trust fund and 40 per cent of their earnings above $87,500 in a hospital fund.

ANSWER.PARA: Queensland salaried specialists have no private practice rights at all and have not had them for two decades. Queensland hospital specialists would be very attracted to the sorts of contracts that Dr Blewett and the Federal Government are offering under section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. In these circumstances Queensland private practitioners must be very different from their avaricious friends in New South Wales in particular who are indulging in the obscene activity of going on strike when they have an income of more than $90, 000 plus whatever they can earn from private practice. Senator MacGibbon, I notice, has not been going in to bat over the last 20 years for the apparently poverty stricken state of diagnostic specialists in Queensland hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government scheme gives less to all medical practitioners in Queensland than is paid in other States.

—The Queensland practice has been in place for 20 years. Queensland specialists have been getting less than specialists in other States for 20 years. They have been on much harsher contracts than the contracts suggested by Dr Blewett. Queensland specialists would love to be under the same contracts as those suggested by Dr Blewett. But the Government, and Dr Blewett in particular, has not demanded the imposition of conditions on those even higher earning diagnostic specialists. We have offered to defer the income restraints. Many people would not consider that they were much of a restraint. We have offered to defer these restraints until the whole issue has been examined-particularly the matter of private practice in public hospitals-by a joint Government and Australian Medical Association committee under Professor Pennington, who is the Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Melbourne.

ANSWER.PARA: Other more contentious issues, such as the matter of appeals, rights and the preparation of a national list of facility charges for the use of public hospital services and other equipment, have also been referred to the inquiry. This Government's only requirement for doctors who have been trained at public expense and who practise in public hospitals using facilities which are paid for by the taxpayer is that they stick to the schedule fee. That is the only restraint that is on them at the moment. These are the people who are, in fact, going on strike. The schedule fee is drawn up by a committee which is agreed to by the national body, the Australian Medical Association.

I repeat: It is an absolute obscenity that these medical practitioners should be going on strike in this way when they work in taxpayer-funded facilities and when they have been trained with the taxpayers' money. It is an absolute obscenity that they should go on strike because the Federal Government says: ' Charge what is a fair thing'. These same people-I am quick to point out that I believe that the majority of doctors in the community do not approve of these doctors going on strike-would be the first to complain about unionists in another area who earn much less going on strike.

In fact, as one of my colleagues has said, they make Norm Gallagher look socially responsible. I put it to honourable senators that what Dr Blewett and the Federal Government are doing is, in fact, being perfectly reasonable with these people. The fact that Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Austin in the Queensland Government have come out in support of surgeons in New South Wales who are going to indulge in a strike of this type when, for the two decades that they have been in Government, Queensland's own doctors have been working under much harsher and stricter contracts which imposed much greater restraints on diagnostic specialists in Queensland hospitals is the absolute epitome of hypocrisy.

This Government will not back down under these circumstances. We will not back down under political or economic blackmail such as this. We believe that those who use publicly funded facilities and who are trained with taxpayers' money have some sort of social responsibility in this country. If they will not demonstrate that social responsibility, we will have to impose such a responsibility on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also ask the Minister for Social Security some questions about the Prime Minister's announcement last week that an independent panel would be established to review the assets test legislation. I refer in particular to the Minister's announcement earlier today that the panel will be able to take evidence. I ask the Minister: Can he indicate to the Senate on what date that panel will be constituted and what will be the extent and nature of its powers? Finally, will the Minister also give the Senate and the people of Australia some assurance that the members of the panel will include people directly representative of those people who are to be affected by this test, in other words, the pensioner community?

—I am happy to answer that question. The panel is in the process of being constituted now. I cannot give Senator Lewis the exact date when we will make an official announcement, but it will be within days rather than weeks . Secondly, I can assure Senator Lewis that members of that panel will be representatives of the constituent groups affected by the assets test and others . Thirdly, as to the nature and extent of the inquiry, the panel will be asked to look at the proposed assets test and the legislation.
—Powers?

—The panel's functions will be to advise the Government on what it considers are the efficiency, effectiveness and nature of the assets test and on any anomalies it may see. We will certainly let Senator Lewis know the terms of reference of the panel. I am not sure what Senator Lewis means by powers. Does he mean whether it can subpoena or gaol people?
—You said that it could take evidence. What do you mean by that?

—The panel will not consider just the legislation in isolation. Organisations, groups and individuals in the community will be able to give their views to the panel. We will inform the honourable senator as soon as possible as to the exact details and the mechanics of how that will work.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the reported claims by a serviceman that he was denied treatment for a badly lacerated hand until he produced his Medicare card with its number? Can the Minister say whether this is probably another case of bloody-minded officiousness on the part of the doctor concerned and assure all holders of Medicare cards, even Defence personnel, that such standover tactics will not be tolerated?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators-That is the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately for members of the Opposition, that is not the system. We went through this in many ways.
—They made a mistake again.

—As a senator and a citizen-and a doctor, I might add, Senator Walters-I would be appalled at any member of the medical profession who refused to treat anyone in this community if that person did not have a Medicare card, if that person did not have a dollar in his or her pocket or for any such reason . The Medicare card does not entitle any doctor to refuse to give treatment to anyone. In fact, it is a means of simplifying a patient's capacity to claim on his or her medical bill. Any doctors who refuse to treat a patient in this country who does not have a Medicare card or, as I have known happen in the past , who refuse to treat in an emergency situation a patient who is not insured, do not deserve to be members of the medical profession in this or any other country . In fact one wonders whether they should be part of the human race.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that Medicare officers, on payment of the 85 per cent of the fee, are retaining the receipted account from medical practitioners? Is he aware that the excuse given by Medicare officials is that this is the only way in which they can establish proof of the claim? Is he aware that Medicare officers are claiming that they have storage facilities for every receipt issued in Australia for years? Finally, is he aware of the variance with commercial practice that this action is causing, because legally that receipted account is the property of the patient and not of the Government?

—I am not aware of the exact details of the claims that Senator MacGibbon has made. I understand that the account given by the doctor is needed by Medicare as proof that the account has been rendered and paid. I do not know the exact details of the problems raised by Senator MacGibbon. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health and seek an early answer.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to the acute shortage of places in the tertiary education sector? How does this measure up with the Government's stated intention of increasing participation in post-school education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government and I are very concerned about reports appearing in newspapers daily and coming to us from vice-chancellors and other responsible bodies about the explosion of demand for higher education places. It is something that we anticipated and indeed took steps to cope with in our first Budget by making an extra $10m available for an extra 3,000 tertiary places. Those extra 3,000 tertiary places have been taken up according to our guidelines of providing increased possibilities for tertiary study in areas which had previously been disadvantaged. But quite clearly the legacy of the Fraser Government is still with us and is the main cause of this unhappy situation. During the seven years of the Fraser Administration recurrent and capital funding for the higher education sector was systematically cut back to a stage where there is virtually no infrastructure to deal with this excessive demand.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say a couple of things about the increased demand for higher education places. The Government welcomes and I welcome the renewed confidence that young people are displaying in undertaking further education. It has been very much part of our Government's strategy to try to restore the confidence of young people in gaining further education and training, because we are very well aware that young people who leave secondary education without an adequate level of skills and training and who do not undertake some form of further education and training will simply not be able to compete in the improved economy which we are now seeing with the kinds of jobs that are becoming available. We also have a concern on equity grounds. It seems to us to be quite inequitable that some young people who may finish their education in a government school, or even a non-government school, at the age of 15 and 16 are getting a much smaller slice of the education cake than those who complete their secondary education and then undertake higher education. Indeed, as my colleague Senator Grimes pointed out earlier in Question Time today, the highest paid people in our community, namely doctors, have available to them a very expensive publicly-provided education at universities. So there is the question of equity in our wishing to encourage young people to pursue their education, as well as the obvious fact, very well established now, that more than four years of secondary education is necessary and desirable if young people are to pursue satisfactory post-school education and work.

We are very encouraged and heartened to see that young people are now seeking places in higher education. However, the fact is that young people are seeking many more places and are qualified by their tertiary entrance scores for many more places than are available. This is not a situation, given that it resulted from seven years of neglect by the previous Fraser Administration, that we have been able to reverse in one Budget. We took some steps. We increased recurrent and capital funding for technical and further education. As a result, many more places in TAFE are available, although again not enough to meet the demand. In higher education, as I said, we have created an extra 3,000 places, particularly in areas which have been disadvantaged, but clearly that is not enough to meet the demand.

However, as a result of the urgent situation that has been created by the increased demand for places, the Cabinet considered at its meeting yesterday what steps we can take in the short term. We wanted to take steps which would not interfere with the proper process of the report and advice from the Tertiary Education Commission which I expect at the end of next month. We have decided to accelerate the approval of the forward commitment of capital funds for those three projects to which the Tertiary Education Commission, in two published reports now, has given the highest priority. They are the Kingswood campus of the Nepean College of Advanced Education, which will have a total cost over 1985 -86 of $5.3m; the Latrobe University library project, which is a $6.3m project; and the Coburg campus of the Phillip Institute of Technology, which is a $25m project. The agreement here will not involve any new expenditure for 1984, but those funds have now been guaranteed, so-

TALK.START.PARA: —Phoney-no extra places.

—The effect of announcing this now means that the tenders will be able to be let and the new places, which will be about 1,500, as I recall, will be available one academic year earlier as a result of building approvals starting this year rather than next year.
—Phoney.

—Senator Baume interjects: 'No extra places'. Quite clearly, the backlog in capital which the Government has inherited cannot be overcome in the first year. We acknowledge that. But by permitting the forward commitment of these three major projects, we will be putting those institutions at least on notice that they will have increased physical facilities for the 1986 year instead of the 1987 year. That means that their efforts to take in a higher number of students this year-each of those three institutions has increased its numbers this year-will be encouraged because they know that any interim arrangements they make by way of accommodation will be overcome one academic year earlier. Of course, we wish to do a great deal more in both capital and recurrent assistance to higher education, but further decisions will have to await my receiving advice from the Tertiary Education Commission and the issuing by me on behalf of the Government of the funding guidelines for the next triennium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The purpose of this statement is to report to Parliament on the issues arising out of, and the action that has been taken, concerning the material known as the Age tapes.

SPEECH.PARA: Receipt of Tapes
Early in the evening of 1 February-following an appointment arranged half an hour earlier-and then on 2 February 1984, representatives of the Age newspaper furnished to me the following material:
(a) four tapes containing what appeared to be 11 recorded telephone conversations between a Sydney solicitor and a number of other persons;
(b) 524 pages of documents, divided into six bundles, purporting to be the summaries and direct transcripts of approximately 3,000 telephone conversations between a large number of persons.

In providing the material the representatives of the Age stated to me that the material had been given to the Age by Mr Bob Bottom, who in turn was believed to have received it from some source within the New South Wales Police Force, although no detailed information or proof was offered as to the source. I drew it to the attention of the Age representatives, who appeared to be unaware of the point, that to the extent that the material was authentic and had been gathered otherwise than under Australian Federal Police warrant, it appeared that massive breaches of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, or its legislative predecessor, had been committed.
Action Taken

On 2 February 1984 I discussed the matter with the Special Minister of State, the Hon. M. J. Young, and set in train the arrangements carried into effect the following day, 3 February. On 3 February I wrote to the Special Minister of State, requesting him to arrange for a police investigation of the material, and on the same day I caused the material to be handed over to a senior officer of the Australian Federal Police. Later that day the Special Minister of State wrote to me confirming that he had asked the AFP to investigate the material with a view to determining whether federal offences had been committed.

There was never at any time any basis whatever for the reported suggestions by Senators Chipp and Durack that the Federal Police investigation of the Age tapes and transcripts given to me that week would be confined to the circumstances in which they were made, and not extend to their content. I made this clear in a statement issued on 4 February, when I said that the Australian Federal Police had been asked, through the Special Minister of State, to investigate fully and report upon all aspects of the matter, including the possible commission of any Federal offences revealed by the content of the tapes and transcripts.

A preliminary report from the Commissioner of Police was received by the Special Minister of State, and through him by me, on the morning of Monday 13 February, and was immediately considered. The report stated that the material disclosed the probability of an unauthorised, and accordingly illegal, interception of telephone calls in New South Wales. It also identified in general terms a number of matters requiring further examination and investigation; asked for assistance from the Attorney-General's Department in assessing the material; and identified a series of procedural options for carrying the investigation forward: The favoured one, so far as possible Federal offences were concerned, being investigation under a Commonwealth special prosecutor.

It was decided, as a possible prelude to the Special Prosecutor option being pursued, that the Director of Public Prosecutions-designate and current President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Ian Temby, QC, should be briefed to advise on what offences against Federal law, if any, appeared to be disclosed or suggested by the material, and what further inquiries should be made. Mr Temby was to be asked to advise on as a matter of urgency, and to give priority attention to, the position of the judge allegedly involved in the taped conversations. The Acting Crown Solicitor flew to Perth that afternoon to brief Mr Temby, and Mr Temby prepared his opinion over the course of the next two days , assisted by consultations both with the Acting Crown Solicitor and the senior AFP officer who had been in charge of the initial police investigation.

Mr Temby's opinion became available to me in vocadex form in the afternoon of 15 February. It confirmed that breaches of the Commonwealth Telecommunications ( Interception) Act 1979 and its predecessor, the Telephonic Communications ( Interception) Act 1960, were likely to have occurred, and that there were other matters that might require further investigation. I table Mr Temby's opinion, complete except for the deletion of names, other identifying characteristics and certain information supplied to him in confidence by the AFP.

The substance of Mr Temby's opinion, and the preceding police report, was summarised in the joint statement issued by the Special Minister of State and me on 17 February. Following the receipt of Mr Temby's opinion, and consultations with the New South Wales Government and Police Force, the Government made a number of decisions about the proper further course of the inquiry, and these were also announced in the joint statement of 17 February:
a special prosecutor would be appointed to supervise further investigations in relation to the tapes and transcripts handed by the Age newspaper to me on 1 and 2 February 1984;
the role of the special prosecutor would be independent of the Government;

he would supervise a joint investigating team, consisting of selected police officers from the Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales Police Force , and would be charged with bringing prosecutions for any breaches of Federal law discovered as a result of investigations into, or in relation to, the contents of those materials;
questions concerning State law that may arise from the materials would be a matter for the law enforcement authorities of the State of New South Wales.

The statement of 17 February also announced that Mr Temby would be recommended for appointment as Special Prosecutor. The appointment was made by the Governor- General on 21 February. Mr Temby's terms of reference have been specified by me for the purposes of paragraph 6 (1) (a) of the Special Prosecutors Act 1982 as follows:

(a) activities illegal under Commonwealth or Territory law in relation to the interception of alleged telephone communications which are referred to in the materials, including cassette tapes, delivered by representatives of the Age newspaper to the Attorney-General on 1 and 2 February 1984; and
(b) any other activities illegal under Commonwealth or Territory law established as a result of investigations into, or in relation to, the contents of those materials.

Although the most obvious grounds for investigation by the Special Prosecutor clearly concern the circumstances of the interceptions, there are several other possible offences under Commonwealth law that may have been committed and which will require further investigation-although in some instances, as is made clear in Mr Temby's opinion, the raw material on which such investigations could proceed is extremely limited and tenuous. These matters are:
possible offences arising out of an immigration racket-which has already been the subject of investigation and successful prosecution-involving a former Commonwealth public servant and AFP officers;
possible improper release of information by AFP officers;
possible currency regulation charges in relation to a money courier;
possible tax evasion; and
possible fixing of a case in the Australian Capital Territory

I should make it clear that in addition to being examined by Special Prosecutor Temby's team, some of the material has also been forwarded to Special Prosecutor Redlich, and to Royal Commissioner Mr Justice Stewart, as it is possibly relevant to matters on which each are working or have worked.

It should perhaps be stated, because it has been questioned in some quarters, that the reason that Mr Temby was asked to accept the role of Special Prosecutor in this matter was simply that he was the Director of Public Prosecutions- designate, scheduled to take up that office on 5 March. When he formally becomes DPP, he will continue to act as a Special Prosecutor in this matter, but the two roles will for practical purposes become assimilated. This is consistent with the policy in this respect which underlay the creation of the office of DPP and which was explained to Parliament at the time of enactment of the enabling legislation: Namely, eventually to absorb the work of the existing Special Prosecutors-Messrs Redlich and Gyles, QC-under the DPP umbrella, and not to appoint any new Special Prosecutor other than in the most exceptional circumstances.

On Saturday 18 February I indicated orally to the Solicitor-General that I would be referring certain questions of law to him to ascertain whether his views confirmed the view of the law expressed by Mr Temby in relation to the meaning of 'misbehaviour' in section 72 of the Constitution. This was followed up by a written reference on Monday 20 February. I will refer to and table the Solicitor-General's opinion later in this statement.

A question has arisen as to the action taken by the Government in relation to the article 'Big Shots Bugged', published by the National Times in its issue of 25 November-1 December 1983, which was clearly based on similar, perhaps identical, material to that in the possession of the Age. This article was the subject of questions to me by Senator Archer on 30 November 1983 and 8 December 1983 and, of course, today. On 30 November he asked whether I would assure the Senate that the allegations contained in that article would be fully investigated to determine whether there had been any breaches of Commonwealth law, and that appropriate action would be taken. In my reply, I said that I had been advised by the Special Minister of State that the AFP were investigating to see whether the material in the National Times could possibly have come from information supplied by them and that I was awaiting further information. On 8 December Senator Archer asked a follow-up question, repeating his request for assurances, and I told the Senate that I had not received any further information to that point from the Special Minister of State.

I understand that the investigation by the AFP had not been completed before 3 February, and is now encompassed in the larger investigation arising out of the material given to me by the Age. One of the difficulties involved in this area is that the National Times, unlike the Age, is not prepared to reveal to the proper authorities the material which it has in its possession. It has been widely reported, not least in the National Times itself on 17 February, that the New South Wales Police Commissioner, Mr Abbott, requested the National Times to provide him with its material, only to be refused on the ground that, as the document purported to be a police document, it should already be in his possession. I requested the National Times on 21 February, to provide me with material in its possession relevant to the inquiry being conducted by the Special Prosecutor. To date, I have had no reply.

This description of the action taken since 1 February should demonstrate to any observer that the Government's actions since the receipt of the materials have been both prompt and proper in every respect. I have dealt so far with the particular procedural steps taken by the Government in this matter and the reasons for acting as we did when we did. It remains now to address a number of particular issues which arise from the publication of the Age articles, and I do so under the following headings: First, authenticity and evidentiary status of the material; secondly, references to a judge and the question of 'misbehaviour' ; and, thirdly, privacy, illegality and responsible journalism.
Authenticity and Evidentiary Status

I cannot emphasise too strongly the dubious status of the material in question. The tapes and transcripts given to me are clearly not originals. The locations of the original tapes and transcripts are not known to the Government. Who took the copies from which the Age copies were derived is unknown to us. The material is therefore completely anonymous and completely unauthen- ticated.

This is not some technical point designed to divert attention from issues of substance, as some media comments have perhaps suggested. We simply have no means, and are unlikely in the future to have any means, of being sure that we have a full, untampered with, reliable account of the conversations that appear to have been intercepted. It is not even a matter of being able to check the content of the Age-supplied transcripts against that of the Age-supplied tapes, since the two categories of material are mutually exclusive: None of the material on the tapes is in the transcripts, and none of the material in the transcripts can be checked against anything on the tapes. There is no basis at all for assuming the authenticity, in whole or part, of the purely written material and there are a number of problems confronting any acceptance of the tapes at their face value.
The Tapes

As to the tapes, there is a very real question as to whether they have been tampered with. The New South Wales Solicitor-General's opinion confirms an impression to be gained by what I will call a layperson's hearing of the tapes. She said
In some conversations there are changes in speech patterns and/or speed which are to the untrained ear suggestive of 'editing'.
She went on:

Without full technical assessment it is not possible to exclude the possibility of 'editing' and/or 'patching' of conversations. I have requested the Commissioner of Police, who now has possession of the documents and tapes provided to the Attorney to undertake a full technical assessment of the tapes. This may be a lengthy process and, in any event, may not be reliable because the tapes are, as I have already stated, clearly not the original intercept recordings.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have established beyond any doubt that they are not original intercept recordings?

—We were told by the Age that they were copies of material supplied to the Age, quite apart from whether the material in the Age's possession is itself original or copies of other material. Certainly, it seems to have been a multigeneration process, with the copies in our possession being down the line. As part of the Commonwealth investigation of the whole material, our copies of all the tapes have been given to a leading expert in the field, and we are awaiting his assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Documents

The so-called transcripts in most instances are not in fact transcripts in the sense of being verbatim reports of everything alleged to have been said. The documents made available to me consisted of 6 bundles:

The first bundle, of 64 pages, apparently corresponding with the bundle identified by New South Wales Solicitor-General, Ms Mary Gaudron, QC, as 'B-1', purports to contain summaries or records of conversations over a telephone in March 1976. The party whose telephone was apparently intercepted, was identified in the documents as 'Target' or 'T'. The subject matter of the conversations is very wide, but is substantially concerned with horse races and SP betting.

The second bundle, of 106 pages, apparently corresponding with Gaudron bundle ' A-4', purports to contain summaries or records of conversations over a telephone in March and April 1979. The telephone intercepted appears to be that of a Sydney solicitor. Included amongst these conversations are a number of conversations between the solicitor and a judge.

The third bundle, of 146 pages, apparently corresponding with Gaudron bundle 'B -2', purports to contain summaries or records of conversations over a telephone in the period June-July-August 1979. The summaries and extracts appear to relate to 35 tapes of conversations in that period. The telephone intercepted was substantially used by one 'D' although a number of other persons seem to have used the telephone in that period. Again the subject matter of the conversations is very wide. Apart from personal matters, horse racing and SP betting appear to be the major subjects of the conversations.

The fourth bundle, of 97 pages, apparently corresponding with Gaudron bundle 'A -3', purports to contain summaries or records of conversations over a telephone during February 1980. The telephone appears to be that of the same Sydney solicitor. Again the subject matter of the conversations is very wide. Again the material includes much of conversation between the solicitor and the judge.

The fifth bundle, of 67 pages, apparently corresponding to Gaudron bundle 'B-3' , labelled 'Trimbole Tapes', purports to contain summaries or records of conversations over a telephone over a period March-May 1981. The telephone appears to be that of a person described as 'Bob' although a number of other persons apparently used the telephone. Again the conversations cover a wide variety of subject matter but racing and SP betting figure prominently.

The sixth bundle, of 44 pages, apparently corresponding to Gaudron bundle 'A-2' , consists of two documents. The first document is a three-page report which is undated and contains no reference to an author. The document refers to a number of prominent persons and makes very serious allegations against those persons. The second document is described as a summary of information supplied by an informant in relation to the solicitor and is in the form of summaries of telephone conversations over the period February to May 1980. The two documents are related in that the allegations made in the first document appear to be based on the summaries in the second document.

Both Mr Temby, QC, and the Solicitor-General for New South Wales, who appears to have examined essentially the same material as Mr Temby, state that there is no authentication of either the tapes or the documentary material. In terms of the law of evidence this means that the material is worthless. Of course, even if it were to be established that the tapes and transcripts were authentic in every respect, that there had been no editing of or tampering with the tapes, and that the transcripts and summaries were exact and faithful reports of what was said, it does not follow for a moment that what was said by any individual in any particular conversation was true. Quite apart from the danger of ironic, joking or careless statements being taken at their literal face value, it is not at all uncommon for people, especially when they believe they are talking privately and not in any way for the record, to brag, exaggerate, fantasise or tell straight-out untruths.
References to a Judge and the Question of 'Misbehaviour'

Any allegations involving a member of the Federal judiciary are matters of serious concern. Any government must treat such allegations as very serious matters. The Fraser Government claimed to do so when I raised serious questions of bias in relation to the then Chief Justice of the High Court in 1980 not in any casual or partial way, as here, but in a fully documented speech in the Senate occupying some 28 pages of Hansard (Senate, Hansard, 29 April 1980, pp. 1897-1925).

In the 1980 case, the Prime Minister said that the serious matter raised-a conflict of interest arising out of family shareholding, and one which was squarely and directly related to the conduct of his judicial office-was a question which was wholly one for the individual judge to decide (House of Representatives, Hansard, 29 April 1980, p. 2348). In the present case, as I have indicated, the Government referred the relevant material for examination and report to the Federal Police and then to Mr Temby. The substance of both reports was summarised by the Special Minister of State and me in our joint statement of 17 February as follows:

Both the report and opinion concluded . . . that in relation to the alleged involvement of a Judge in telephone conversations with a solicitor, the material -if authentic-could not support any conclusion that the Judge had been guilty of criminal misconduct.

Nor, in the opinion of Mr Temby, could the content of the material-if authentic -support in any way a conclusion that there had been 'misbehaviour' within the meaning of section 72 of the Australian Constitution.

Both the police report and Mr Temby's opinion make it clear that there is no basis upon which any further police or Special Prosecutor investigation of the alleged behaviour of the Judge, as revealed by the tapes and transcripts, could be justified.

One might hope that that is where the matter will be allowed to rest-in the interests not only of the judge concerned, who has already had to endure a disgraceful campaign of gossip and innuendo, but also of the whole institution of the judiciary. In fairness to the judge concerned, however, I made arrangements to interview him on the afternoon of 15 February, in order to put the material in question to him and get, should he be minded to make it, some indication of his response. The fact that such an interview took place was mentioned by me in my Press conference on 17 February. Since the timing of that interview appears to have itself attracted some questioning, I should make it clear that it was governed by two considerations: First, the desire to give to the judge the earliest possible opportunity to make his own response to the allegations concerning him; but secondly, not to do so until I was satisfied- following the reports from the AFP and Mr Temby-that to put the relevant material to him would not in any way prejudice further police investigations.

Both at the interview on 15 February, and at a subsequent brief interview on 24 February, I was accompanied by the Permanent Head of my Department, Mr Pat Brazil. On both occasions His Honour strongly questioned the authenticity of the material and referred in terms of the strongest conviction to the outrage done to his and to his family's privacy, and to his objection to the principle of guilt by association being applied to him. In respect of specific matters raised by the published material, he either specifically denied the factual accuracy of the allegations concerning him, or gave explanations which put those allegations in a rather different context than that evident at first sight.

For present purposes it is unnecessary to give more detail than that, and I do not propose to do so. When material of contested authenticity is obtained in circumstances which, at the best, are manifestly illegal and gross invasions of privacy, the onus of explanation should not have to lie upon the target of the attack. To argue otherwise is to place all public figures who may be similarly attacked-and the institutions of which they may be part-in an invidious position . For obvious reasons, nowhere is this more clearly the case than in relation to members of the judiciary.
The Question of 'Misbehaviour'

The Government has given careful consideration to whether there is anything in the Age material which-assuming for present purposes its authenticity-might properly be claimed to amount to or point to misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. That section provides that a Federal judge shall not be removed, except by the Governor-General in Council, on an address from both Houses praying for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. I am satisfied, and the Government is satisfied, that there is no basis at all on which any substantive motion based on misbehaviour could or should be moved.

The Government initially referred for advice the question of misbehaviour to the Director of Public Prosecutions-designate, with the request that he consider this, as a possibly separate issue, at the same time as he was considering whether any criminal offences were involved. That part of Mr Temby's opinion which deal with the meaning of misbehaviour in section 72 of the Constitution and which sets forth the conclusion he reached states:

There is nothing in the material I have seen, assuming its authenticity, which would prove or in any way support the conclusion that [the Judge] has been guilty of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution . At least ordinarily such misbehaviour must be in a matter pertaining to the office held although conviction for an infamous offence which renders the person concerned unfit to exercise the office is apparently sufficient. Quick and Garran, 'The Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth' p. 731; Halsbury 'The Laws of England', 4th ed., Vol. 8, 680; The Earl of Shrewsbury's case, 9 Co. Rep. 41''.

Quick and Garran, the most contemporaneous and authoritative commentary on the Constitution, quotes on the meaning of misbehaviour in section 72 the following passage in Todd, Parliamentary Government in England, second edition, page 857:

Misbehaviour includes, firstly, the improper exercise of judicial functions; secondly, wilful neglect of duty, or non-attendance; and thirdly, a conviction for any infamous offence, by which, although it be not connected with the duties of his office, the offender is rendered unfit to exercise any office or public franchise.

The opinion I have now received from the Solicitor-General, and which I now table, has substantially confirmed the test that Mr Temby applied. The Solicitor -General points out that the requirement under the Constitution is not conviction in a court of law but proof to the Parliament. It is important to note what he goes on to say:

Inasmuch as Parliament considers the matter, the question is whether there is proved offence against the general law 'of such a nature as to warrant the conclusion that the incumbent is unfit to exercise the office'. Parliament is not at large to define proved misbehaviour by reference to its own standards or views of suitability for office or moral or social character or conduct. The Parliamentary inquiry is whether commission of an offence of the requisite quality and seriousness is proved. Parliament would act beyond power if it sought to apply wider definition or criteria for misbehaviour than the recognised meaning of misbehaviour not pertaining to office.
The Solicitor-General goes on to answer the specific question of law I put to him as follows:
Misbehaviour is limited in meaning in section 72 of the Constitution to matters pertaining to-
(1) judicial office, including non-attendance, neglect of or refusal to perform duties; and
(2) the commission of an offence against the general law of such a quality as to indicate that the incumbent is unfit to exercise the office.

Misbehaviour is defined as breach of condition to hold office during good behaviour. It is not limited to conviction in a court of law. A matter pertaining to office or a breach of the general law of the requisite seriousness in a matter not pertaining to office may be found by proof, in appropriate manner, to the Parliament in proceedings where the offender has been given proper notice and opportunity to defend himself.

My understanding throughout of what Mr Temby considered to be the test was that it was substantially the same as that which has now been identified by the Solicitor-General. It is clear from the relevant paragraph that I quoted above from Mr Temby's opinion that he did consider whether the material, assuming its authenticity, in any way supported a conclusion that a serious criminal offence had been committed. His conclusion, to which I have just referred, was that there was no material that in any way supported that conclusion. Mr Temby, both by reason of his extensive criminal law experience and by virtue of his office of Director of Public Prosecutions-designate was clearly the most appropriate expert adviser on these criminal and evidentary matters.

I would only add that the issue of the meaning of misbehaviour within the terms of section 72 of the Constitution, and the question of the naming of the judge, raises in my view a quite fundamental constitutional issue relating to the separation of powers. This matter is referred to in the Solicitor-General's examination of the legislative history of section 72. Section 72 deals with the sensitive interface of the separation of powers between the legislature and the judiciary. In this regard, the Constitution was clearly established on the premise of separation of power between these two institutions. Because of the sensitivity of this separation-

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be 'judiciary', not 'Executive'?

—I have corrected the text. It should be 'judiciary'. I thought that the honourable senator would be acute enough to pick me up on that. I might also add that it involves the question of the relationship between the Executive and the judiciary as well which matter, no doubt, we may find ourselves debating. Because of the sensitivity of this separation, it is acutely important that all honourable senators and members be restrained in dealing with matters of alleged misbehaviour of judges.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticism of members of the judiciary by the legislature is a very sensitive matter, and certainly should not be based on the very unsatisfactory material which is available here. Any action asserting misbehaviour which were to be based merely on party political or other special interests would be quite indefensible in principle, and would degrade this Parliament and the Constitution.
Privacy, Illegality and Responsible Journalism

The most worrying aspect of this whole matter is, I believe, the massive illegality and invasion of privacy which appears to have been involved; and, associated with that, the profound indifference, even cynicism, with which that illegality and privacy invasion has been greeted by some members of the media and Opposition spokesmen.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, by section 7, makes it an offence to intercept a communication passing over a telecommunications system unless authorised by Commonwealth laws. Before that Act came into operation on 1 June 1980, the only relevant legislation was the Telephonic Communications ( Interception) Act 1960, under which there was no legislative authority for any telephone interceptions by anyone-other than the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation on national security grounds. If the material is accurate and authentic-that of course very much remains to be established-then it is clear that very large scale unauthorised interception of private telephone calls has taken place, contrary either to that Act or the previous law.

Section 7 of the 1979 Act also makes it an offence to divulge or to communicate to another person, or make use of or record, any information obtained by intercepting a communication passing over a telecommunications system or obtained by virtue of a warrant. This offence is not confirmed to the divulging of information obtained pursuant to law, but applies to the divulging of all information obtained by intercepting a communication passing over a telecommunications system. Accordingly if the material is in fact information obtained by an intercept, then the divulging of that material by any person to another person would constitute an offence. As the Solicitor-General for New South Wales points out in her advice, the effect of this provision may be even to make it an offence for her to divulge information contained in the material to other people.

It is this Government's view that the investigation of the circumstances in which this material originated should be pursued with the greatest vigour. It is also the Government's view that if, in the course of those investigations, other illegalities are established the law will take its course in relation to those illegalities. I make it clear however that the first concern of the Government in this regard is to investigate what is, or what appears to be, a massive invasion of the privacy of the citizens of this country.

It is important to appreciate just what is involved in invasions of privacy of the kind that appear to have occurred in this case. Confidentiality of personal communications appears to have been breached on a massive scale. The tapes, transcripts and summaries given to me by the Age on their face record approximately 3,000 separate conversations, involving dozens of different people .

Unless the law comes down very hard on unauthorised eavesdropping-and also limits very dramatically, as the present law does, the circumstances in which authorised eavesdropping may take place-no one in this country, and certainly no one in any position of public responsibility, can ever feel safe again in having a private telephone conversation. No one will ever be able to blow off steam with loved ones or trusted intimates; no one will be able to gossip, or brag, or exaggerate, or fib in the way that every one of us has done from time to time in circumstances which we would be appalled to ever find made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes in the Senate too.
—Don't tell me that you brag.

—Let anyone who is without sin cast the first stone. A great deal of reference has been made to organised crime in relation to the present tapes and transcripts. Many of the matters that might appear to lend themselves to this description have already been the subject of extensive police investigation and action; anything else that needs to be investigated will be investigated by either the Special Prosecutor's Joint Investigation Team or the New South Wales State authorities. What needs to be appreciated is that if there is any new kind of organised crime revealed by this material, and constituted by its proliferation, it is an organised crime against privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Those that have orchestrated this proliferation of smear and innuendo bear a very heavy responsibility. A situation has been created in which any persons whose identity can be associated with a reference on these tapes or transcripts immediately will be assumed to be involved somehow in organised crime or official corruption. They will bear an impossible burden of proving their innocence. They will be convicted in the public arena by the unacceptable process of guilt by association.

It is to be hoped that those in this and other parliaments around the nation who might be minded to contribute further to the process of identification, sheltering as they can under the cover of absolute privilege, and knowing that they will never have to defend or establish their position in a court of law, will think long and hard before they do so.

The investigation of the matters that need to be investigated is proceeding competently, honestly and quickly, at the Commonwealth level under completely independent supervision. There is nothing to be gained, and a great deal to be lost, by further smearing individuals who have already suffered a good deal of humiliation and hurt in the way this affair has developed so far.
Responsible Journalism

I think it needs to be said, finally, that the role of the Age newspaper in this whole affair has not been a very proud one, particularly for a paper so prone to suggest its moral and intellectual leadership of the profession of journalism in this country, and which is certainly believed by many to occupy that role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ban it.

—I appreciate that is the solution that springs readily to the lips of Senator Lajovic, but it is not one shared by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. About the only respect in which the paper has behaved completely commendably has been in giving the material in its possession to me so as to enable proper investigation to be carried out-more than can be said for the National Times, which still remains apparently quite unwilling to co-operate .

SPEECH.PARA: But this gesture was somewhat counter-balanced by the Age having its story already set up for front page treatment the following day at the very time the material was being handed over. Had the paper been genuinely more concerned to root out possible crime and corruption than to increase its circulation, it would have given the material to the Government well before it ever went to press-perhaps, if it felt that there was any danger the Government would be disposed to ignore it, also overtly making the material available to a responsible Opposition politician-if one can be found-at the same time.

It is acknowledged that this would hardly be a normal course for a newspaper to follow-papers are, after all, in the business of selling news, not crime fighting-but this was hardly a normal situation. The material was, if it was at all authentic, obtained in manifestly illegal circumstances; it manifestly involved outrageous invasions of privacy in so far as individuals were-or were ever likely to be-identified; and it involved putting at serious risk the credibility and status of, and public regard for, the whole institution of the judiciary.

These considerations should at least have led the paper to wrestle with its collective conscience before publishing, and to actively explore alternative courses of action. There is no evidence that it did so. The editorial columns show no particular signs of agonising over the principles involved-whether the end did indeed justify the means and indeed showed little sign of anything but cynical indifference to the values and principles I have just mentioned.

Worse even than that was the way the story was handled. The first article in the series, on 2 February, occupied most of the front page under the banner heading 'Secret Tapes of Judge'. Less than a third of the way into the story, very prominently located at the top of the second column, appeared a series of paragraphs relating to sexual matters, in particular the following:
'In other conversations the Judge talked of his drunkenness and sexual achievements.
'A transcript reveals that the solicitor asked: 'Did you have a good time?'. The Judge replied, 'if you can call getting tired and drunk and f...... everything a good time, yeah . . .'.

We now know, of course, that the transcript revealed nothing of the kind. There are no conversations in which the judge talked of his drunkenness or sexual achievements. The quotation in question is clearly attributed in the transcript not to the judge but to the solicitor. The mistake was not a peripheral or minor one. It involved one of the central premises of the whole article-that the integrity and fitness for office of the judge was in question-and the potential damage done to the target and his family was incalculable. But the acknowledgement of error, when it was eventually forced out of the Age two weeks later, was less than handsome. It did not appear on page 1, and it certainly did not appear under that stark and familiar heading 'We Were Wrong'. It appeared right at the bottom of page 3, in a single column, under the somewhat less than self-lacerating heading 'Wran points out error in police tape article'.

The editor was concerned to insist at the time-as no doubt will others-that the sexual issue was in any event a marginal one. Objectively, he may well have been right. But if that were so, why give that part of the story so much initial prominence? Of course the answer is clear, and it does not-again-do the paper much credit. One does not have to know much about human nature-and newspapers that survive know a lot about human nature-to know that this was the aspect of the story that was likely to command the keenest and most fascinated attention. One did not have to have one's ear very closely to the ground to know that this was the aspect of the story that was attracting the most gossip and speculation in the bars, cars and living rooms of the nation. And one does not have to have much imagination to appreciate that this was the aspect of the story which was likely to cause the most embarrassment and humiliation to the man in question in his personal and family relationships.

The Age newspaper has now called for a Royal Commission, and no doubt others will be minded to do likewise. But there is simply no evident necessity for any step of this kind now to be taken. The Government has acted quickly, responsibly and responsively. It has put in train a full, independently supervised investigation of the circumstances in which this material was obtained and the Federal offences its contents might reveal. That investigation will be conducted competently and with vigour. As I said at the Australian National University conference last weekend:

'It is not necessary, and indeed it is quite destructive of some of the very values it is sought to preserve-including in particular public confidence in the executive, legislative and judicial institutions of government-for every piece of scuttlebutt or tale of scandal to result in a full-scale, full-length Royal Commission.

'The three most recent Commissions of Inquiry in New South Wales-the Street Royal Commission into the ABC allegations against Neville Wran, and the Cross Inquiries into the Sinclair and Bottom allegations-should have amply demonstrated by now that where there is smoke, there is not always fire.
'They should also have graphically demonstrated the kind of damage, humiliation and hurt that even the most ill-justified muck-raking can cause its victims.

'It is not good enough for a newspaper-whether its motives be high-minded, political, cynical, or just plain circulation-greedy-to publish salacious gossip about people in high places, to disregard the illegal or privacy-invading (or both) circumstances in which it was obtained, to deliberately generate an atmosphere of disquiet, and then to thunder about the necessity for a Royal Commission to allay the very fears which it alone has generated.'

The investigation of crime is not a matter for amateur sleuths operating in the public arena or public forums. The way in which this whole matter has been developed and manipulated has been against the public interest. It has outraged privacy and threatens basic human rights. If crime is to be detected, and offenders brought to justice, it will be done not by sensationalism of a salacious Press story or a muck-raking question, but by careful sifting and proper professional police investigation under independent supervision. That is the course which this Government has chosen to follow in this matter, and that is the course to which we intend to stay. I seek leave to incorporate the Temby opinion and the Solicitor-General's opinion in Hansard for convenient reference.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Opinion of Mr Ian Temby Q.C., 15 February 1984
(Edited only by the exclusion of names, identifying characteristics, and certain information supplied by the AFP)
OPINION

I am instructed that ''The Age'' newspaper in Melbourne recently furnished to the Attorney-General 524 pages of documents, which are or purport to be comments on and transcripts of intercepted telephone conversations, and some tapes of intercepted telephone conversations. Copies of each have been made available to me. I have been instructed by the Acting Crown Solicitor to advise with respect to them as a matter of some urgency. I have not personally checked the transcripts of the tapes for accuracy. For the purposes of this opinion I assume that they are accurate. I have advised that this should be checked. It should be stressed that little is known as to the provenance of the material made available to me, and that it appears to have been abstracted selectively: the documents are not continuous or complete.
Whether the documents or the tapes, or both, are genuine, in whole or in part, is not known to me or to those who instruct me.

It appears from the material I have seen that on a number of occasions [the Judge . . .] had telephone discussions with [the Solicitor]. A matter of particular concern is whether [the Judge] has, or may have on the basis of the material, committed any criminal offence. I am also asked to give consideration to whether the material, assuming it to be genuine, could warrant the conclusion that ''the ground of proved misbehaviour'' could be made out or supported as against [the Judge] pursuant to section 72 (ii) of the Constitution: in that event he could be removed from office by the Governor-General on an address from both Houses of Parliament. That is of course a matter upon which only the Parliament could decide, if it chose to embark upon the exercise. It is thought appropriate that I should also comment as to whether, on the same assumption, the conduct of [the Judge] appears to have been injudicious. According to the Macquarie Dictionary, ''judicious'' means ''(1) using or showing judgment as to action or practical expediency; discreet, prudent, or politic (2) having, exercising or showing good judgment; wise, sensible, or well-advised; a judicious selection'', and to act injudiciously is to act in a manner which does not display these characteristics.

I have been instructed to peruse the documents with care and advise as to any offences against Federal law which they disclose, or any further enquiries which should be made on the basis of them. In that context I should say that it is police officers who have particular skills in relation to detection and investigation of alleged criminal behaviour. Lawyers do not have that expertise. I will do my best to make such suggestions as may be useful.

The first general point to be made is that the material I have seen could not of itself warrant the laying of charges against anybody. Neither the tapes nor the documents are original, and it may be that they have been fabricated. The first step, if any aspect of the matter is to be taken further, is to establish their authenticity. That might be difficult. It is not likely that those who prepared the tapes or documents will co-operate in disclosing the role they played. And if the tapes are genuine there will be great difficulty in proving the identity of any speaker to the high criminal standard of proof, at least in the absence of an admission. Speaking generally, no person is obliged to give information to investigating police officers, particularly information which may be of an incriminating nature.

The second general point I make is that even if the material is authentic, and the identity of the speakers can be established, it does not follow that what has been said by any individual is true. It is not unusual for men to brag, to claim greater power than they have, even to tell simple untruths.

The material I have seen covers an extraordinarily wide ground. In the circumstances those who instruct me have agreed that one broad aspect should be put on one side. It appears that there may have been one or more conspiracies to [. . .] using illegal means to do so. A man named [. . .], a former employee of the Department of [. . .] features largely in the material. It appears that at some stage he was the subject of a departmental investigation. A charge was brought against [the Solicitor] in relation to [. . .] matters. He was convicted , and has appealed. In the circumstances it is thought best not to deal in this opinion with any aspect of these matters, including [the Former Employee's] involvement.
There are various references in the material to [the Judge]. I deal with each of them which may be of any significance.

In a summary of a conversation between [the Solicitor] and a man named [. . .] it appears that one or other mentioned that 'a girl has to be arranged for [the Judge]'. Assuming that this was in fact said, it cannot be concluded that it was seriously meant: the comment could have been jocular. If it was seriously meant, it does not follow that anything of the sort was done on that or any other occasion. And if it was, it could not support a conclusion of criminal conduct on the part of any person. The matter does not warrant further investigation. Indeed how the matter could be further investigated I do not know: no details are available as to time or place. All of this can be said with equal force in relation to a statement in what appears to be a general commentary on the tapes, namely that [the Solicitor] organised girls for [the Judge] when time permits.

The transcript of one of the taped telephone conversations between [the Judge] and [the Solicitor] refers to [. . .] and [. . .]. Presumably those referred to were [. . .] and [. . .], who acted for [. . .], the complainant against [. . .] . Assuming the tape to be genuine, it contains nothing which is of a surprising nature. One cannot expect the defendant in criminal proceedings to be consistently charitable towards the complainant and those perceived to be associated with him. Some would think to be inappropriate certain of the language used by [the Judge] and the matters casually adverted to by him, given the high office that he holds. However, assuming the tape to be genuine, it is of a private telephone conversation which according to law should have remained private.

On a couple of occasions [the Judge] intimated to [the Solicitor] that he should, or perhaps they should, be careful as to what they said over the telephone. This is equivocal. It could not support the conclusion that [the Judge] had been guilty of criminal or other misconduct.

In March 1979 [the Judge] and [the Solicitor] had a conversation in which the former told the latter [. . .] is . . . appointing [a Public Servant] as Deputy Chairman of an unidentified body. The latter expressed himself to be pleased. There was talk about the tenure of the appointment. It appears that [the Judge] may have taken some steps to secure the appointment. That would be clear beyond argument if he is the unidentified male in another telephone conversation with [ the Solicitor] who was asked to ring [. . .] 'for that [Public Servant]', and agreed to do so. And in another telephone conversation between [the Solicitor] and an unidentified male person, the former said that when he barked the appointee as Deputy Chairman of the [. . .] would jump. In that telephone conversation [the Solicitor] was advising the person he called of the appointment of 'that big [Public Servant]' to the position in question. It seems unlikely that the other party to that conversation was [the Judge].

I am instructed that a New South Wales Government Directory published in 1982 shows that a [the Publish Servant] was then Deputy Chairman of the [. . .] of that State. If it be the case that [the Judge] used influence or persuasion, direct or indirect, to have him appointed to that position, then that carries no consequence so far as criminal conduct is concerned. There is nothing unusual about people in high places suggesting or urging that given individuals should be appointed to particular Government positions. It would of course be a matter of great concern if that was done in order to secure some favour, or for any sort of consideration. One can imagine circumstances in which the taking of steps to secure such an appointment would be by reason of accompanying circumstances be criminal in nature. There is nothing in the material I have seen to suggest any such accompanying circumstances. I cannot think that any further investigation of the matter is likely to be at all fruitful.

In the transcript of one of the tapes of a conversation between [the Solicitor] and a man named [. . .] who I understand to be a lawyer, the former asked whether the latter was ''sweet with any of the Judges in Canberra'' to which he received a coy reply. [The Solicitor] said that a horse trainer friend of his had a son who had bashed some fellow and it was desired to save him from the can . He then suggested that money might be put forward to that end. The matter was not taken further. A credulous cynic might conclude from this that an attempt was to be made to bribe a Judge of the ACT Supreme Court. I do not think the matter can be taken further as against any party. If the tape is genuine it would not warrant the laying of any charge against either [the Solicitor] or [. . .]. And police officers can hardly be asked to go through the embarrassing ordeal of approaching all of the Judges who sit in the ACT Supreme Court and asking each if he has taken or been offered any bribes lately. As I have been dealing with [the Judge] it should be said that he of course sits on [. . .] which does not deal with cases of [. . .]. This conversation clearly has nothing to do with him.

There is nothing in the material I have seen, assuming its authenticity, which would prove or in any way support the conclusion that [the Judge] has been guilty of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution . At least ordinarily such misbehaviour must be in a matter pertaining to the office held although conviction for an infamous offence which renders the person concerned unfit to exercise the office is apparently sufficient. Quick & Garran, ''The Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth'', 731; Halsbury, '' The Laws of England'', 4th Ed., Vol. 8, 680; The Earl of Shrewbury's case, 9 Co. Rep. 42.

Has [the Judge] acted injudiciously? On the material I have seen his conduct cannot be so categorised, unless it be established that he well knew that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation. [Judges] occupy lofty and rather isolated positions, and it may be that [the Judge] did not know in any detail what [the Solicitor's] reputation was. Even if he did, there is room for debate as between persons of good sense and goodwill as to whether any people, including those who hold high office, should be traduced by reason of the reputation of their friends and acquaintances, in the absence of actual and established improper conduct on their part.

It places a Judge in an invidious position if he has frequent dealings with any person of poor reputation. Presumably [the Judge] now realises this and will act more carefully in the future than he has done in the past. If there is doubt in this regard, it may be that he should be approached and advised as to the desirability of not further nurturing the relationship he has with [the Solicitor] if it presently remains on foot.

Except in relation to the aspect to be dealt with in conclusion, I can find nothing in the material which provides any strong indication that any breach of Federal law has been committed by any person. Nor do I think there are any obvious lines of enquiry open to police officers. It is hard to see what course could be usefully followed by an officer who was required to conduct a supplementary investigation in relation to Federal offences.
