SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill is a further development of legislation which was designed to protect Australian trading interests from the extraterritorial application of foreign laws. In particular the problem has arisen from courts in the United States of America seeking in private lawsuits to apply US anti-trust laws to Australian corporations in relation to those companies' operations outside the United States. In 1982 an anti-trust co-operation agreement was signed between the Australian and the United States governments which provided for negotiations to take place at an intergovernmental level to solve conflicts arising from the extraterritorial application of United States laws. In general both parties have subsequently abided by the spirit and letter of the agreement and apparently the agreement is working quite well. However, it must be conceded, as I did when, as Attorney-General, I signed the agreement on behalf of the Australian Government, that it would not be fully effective as a shield against private anti-trust suits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill consolidates and extends existing Australian legislation to provide a comprehensive range of defences to enable the Government to protect Australian interests against extraterritorial enforcement of foreign laws. I do not propose to deal in detail with the Bill; suffice to say that incorporated in it are refined provisions of the existing Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act which was passed by this Parliament in 1976 and which, an order of the Attorney-General, prohibits the production of documents located in Australia and the giving of evidence in foreign proceedings in circumstances covered by the order of the Attorney-General where it is thought to be in the national interest or the interest of international comity, or where it would be in breach of international law for the foreign court to exercise a jurisdiction of an extraterritorial kind.

The Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979 is also incorporated in the Bill. It provides for the blocking in Australia of foreign judgments which are also prohibited, on order by the Attorney-General, in the circumstances that I have already mentioned in relation to the giving of evidence. These two Acts passed by this Parliament in those years were fairly major developments in providing a shield for Australian companies which were likely to be affected by proceedings of this kind. The first Act was introduced with some haste. I think it is desirable that it be looked at again. The provisions which have been included in this legislation have been updated and refined in that way. I think they are useful additions.

As I have said, this Bill purports to be a code in relation to the subject. It incorporates the restriction enforcement of judgments legislation. I think it should be said that, as a general rule, judgments of foreign courts are and should be enforceable in Australia. It is important for a nation such as Australia, in respect of our trading interests, comity of our laws with other countries, and our commercial operations, that we should give effect to and expect other countries with similar interests to give effect to the judgments of our courts. This legislation certainly qualifies that rule in regard to foreign anti-trust proceedings. I believe that is justified only because of the exceptional threat of those proceedings to Australian interests. It is important to emphasise that, by and large, this is an exception and ought to be an exception to that rule of comity.

A development of existing law contained in this Bill relates to the recovery back of moneys paid under a judgment, or that portion of a foreign judgment, which has been declared to be unenforceable in Australia under the provisions to which I have just referred. This is a rather unique provision which has developed from English legislation known as the Protection of Trading Interests Act. The United Kingdom Parliament passed this legislation several years ago as part of its defence mechanism to cope with the same problem that we face in Australia. Of course the problem is not one which is experienced only by Australia; it is a problem which greatly and gravely affects a number of our trading partners, particularly the United Kingdon, Canada and countries in western Europe, because American laws apply extraterritorially in those countries. It affects the trading interests of those countries in the same way as it may affect Australian interests. The United Kingdom took the further step of providing not only for the blocking of a judgment, that is, declaring unenforceable a judgment of a foreign court-as I have said this concerned principally courts in the United States of America-but also it made provision for a United Kingdom citizen who had such a judgment enforced against him in the United States or in some other country to recover back, against assets situated in the United Kingdom, that portion of the judgment which was declared unenforceable.

This was a development of the shield against the problem of the extraterritorial enforcement of United States laws, a problem at which we looked very closely when we were in government. In fact in 1981 I introduced a Bill to achieve the same purpose as this Bill. However, we were also concerned in government to enter into an agreement with the United States to ameliorate the problem as far as we were concerned. Other countries have since followed suit in trying to achieve such agreement with the United States. As I have said, that agreement was entered into at the end of June 1982. Having entered into that agreement we decided not to proceed with that Bill. Although I told the United States Attorney-General who signed the agreement on behalf of the United States that we would not proceed with that Bill, I made it clear that we would still keep it in place in case the agreement proved-these are the general terms and honourable senators should not hold me to the exact words-to be less effective or successful than we had hoped. Certainly there was never any suggestion that we would withdraw our existing blocking legislation. It was made clear that it may well be necessary, if circumstances occurred, for us to proceed and put in place this further part of the armoury, so to speak.

This Bill goes two steps further than that. It adopts another provision of the United Kingdom legislation which will enable the Attorney-General to make an order prohibiting the performance of an obligation in Australia which has been imposed by a foreign government under a foreign law relating to trade or commerce where the Attorney-General has specified that it is necessary to do so to protect the Australian national interest. It is a very broad power indeed. It is one which I think is somewhat questionable. Certainly it is a rather questionable power to be exercised by the Attorney-General. I would have thought it would be very much more a matter for a Minister concerned with trade rather than a Minister concerned with the enforcement of judgments. In the United Kingdom all these powers are exercised by the Secretary of State for trade and not by the Attorney-General.

However, the mischief which this provision was designed to correct in the United Kingdom, which may certainly apply in Australia, is due to the fact that there are a number of other foreign laws. Again, unfortunately, the main example we refer to is the United States example where orders are made under Acts which prohibit extraterritorially another country from taking certain actions which are seen to be or are contrary to the interests of the country making the order. This is a very gross violation of international comity. It is a very gross example of extraterritorial law and it has given nations in Western Europe very great problems. A classic example is orders which were made under the United States export administration Act in regard to companies in Western Europe which were providing work, materials and capital equipment for the building of the Siberian pipeline. That is the sort of example where these laws apply. Although Australia has not been affected directly by orders of that kind-an Australian company was indirectly affected by those orders-I suppose one must always concede that that is a possible problem.

Another clause in the Bill allows the Attorney-General to make orders based on national interest grounds which prohibit the enforcement of court orders and judgments which are not for money amounts in Australia. I think that is designed to deal with a situation which was of some concern a few years ago to us in this country when proceedings were brought in a United States court. These proceedings were designed to prevent American companies from entering into resource development agreements in Western Australia in the exploitation of some forest areas. That certainly was a different example of the extraterritorial problem. This particular clause would meet a judgment. In that case the proceedings were dismissed in the United States and no problem arose, but it certainly is another possible problem.

From what I have said, it is clear that this Bill implements and carries forward policies that were developed when the Opposition was in government. The object was to protect Australian interests against the successive jurisdiction claimed primarily by United States courts and possibly United States government agencies. They arise particularly under anti-trust laws. The private suits that are commonly brought under these laws enable treble damages to be given and could be ruinous of even large Australian companies. This is a problem which is not, by any means, confined to Australia, but is of considerable concern to many of our trading partners and Western allies.

Over the years we have developed very good relationships with other countries which are affected in this way. Certainly when I was in government I had many discussions-I think Australian foreign Ministers and other Ministers concerned in the trading areas also had discussions- with our counterparts in these countries with the object of putting up a united front of resistance to the extraterritorial application of these laws. Our legislation and this proposed legislation would be part of a wide spread defence mechanism which was pursued in various degrees of strength by these countries.

It was our policy, and it is the present Government's policy in carrying forward that policy, to encourage this multilateral response to the problem. At the same time we endeavoured to develop modifications of the United States policy in relation to Australia. Our particular self-interest dictated that we should endeavour to reach agreement with the United States to modify, as far as possible on a government-to-government level, the application of its laws. The United States Government cannot dictate what private litigants do in courts, but the United States Government has a very big enforcement arm of anti-trust laws in the Department of Justice. In this agreement we were primarily concerned to reach a means of consultation and negotiation on a government-to-government level in relation to possible enforcement by the Department of Justice.

However, another important aspect of the agreement was the obligation the United States Government undertook. If we were to persuade the United States Government that its law should not be enforced against Australian interests it would intervene in a private suit and put the argument to the court that the enforcement of that law, even in a private suit, would be contrary to comity and good relations between the two countries in the hope that the court might be moved to dismiss the suit. That would be a very valuable addition but of course the United States Government's views will not be binding on the court. That is the one major deficiency in the existing agreement.

I believe that there is justification for these further steps being taken. I reiterate the view we took in government. Having entered into this agreement we felt, with our existing blocking legislation and with the agreement, that we had a number of valuable tools at our disposal to cope with this threat and that it was not justifiable to proceed with these further defence mechanisms which are provided in the legislation. However, the present Government has taken a different view. It says that the United States Government will understand the need for this legislation in the manner in which it is being taken. I hope the present Government is right in that assumption. I hope that adequate discussions and explanations have taken place with the United States and that it will understand the need for this legislation. I am sure it will not accept the legislation with equanimity because such blocking legislation is very serious.

However, it is also very important that the countries of the Western world which are so affected by these laws should make their concerns not only known but also should make them effective. Effective defences should be raised against these economic effects which apply in the extraterritorial application the laws will have. I think this is the only way, in the long term apart from constant protests and constant complaints about these matters when they do arise, and they are certainly made and orchestrated pretty strongly. Another part of the defence is legislation of this kind. Similar legislation has been passed in the United Kingdom and other aspects of this blocking legislation has been passed in other countries. In the long run we hope that in these ways the American legislators or courts will be persuaded that they should not keep on foot laws of these kinds. I think that will take a long process of persuasion.

Although there are some indications that expert opinion in the United States appreciates these matters, nevertheless there is a very strong commitment in the United States, reflected in Congress, towards their anti-trust laws, not only the domestic application but also the foreign application. I believe it will be a long process. I believe it is important that we maintain a bipartisan approach to the problem in this country. I believe it is important for us to maintain the strong mutual relationships and defences that have been built up with countries such as the United Kingdom, Canada and others over recent years.

I know that this legislation will be welcomed, particularly in the United Kingdom because of the reciprocity that is available there under its legislation and will be available under this legislation, if it is passed by this Parliament . I believe that this legislation goes further, particularly in relation to the general orders that can be made prohibiting the performance of obligations under executive orders made by foreign governments and to some extent it may be premature to proceed with the recovery back aspects of the legislation. Although I have those reservations, I think that the more important aspect of this matter is to maintain the common front, both domestically and internationally, in relation to this problem and to maintain the pressure against extraterritorial application, particularly of the American anti-trust laws. By a process of that kind and of complaint-and, dare I say, even education by taking opportunities of various forums that arise in the United States-we may be able to put our point of view and will, in the long run, obtain a modification of these offensive extraterritorial laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Foreign Proceedings ( Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill 1983. I acknowledge the contribution by the shadow Attorney-General (Senator Durack) who indicated that the Opposition would, with some reluctance as to the timing of the legislation being introduced in this chamber, support it as part of the erection of a common front, the maintaining of the shield with various other trading partners of the United States, and also the maintaining of a common front domestically so that the United States Government may know that the Bill enjoys bipartisan support. Indeed, I think much of the rationale underlying the introduction of this legislation, which is reactive and which responds to a situation forced on us by the purported extraterritorial application of United States laws, is shared throughout this chamber and by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which brought down a report on the extraterritorial application of United States laws late last year. There is a question as to its timing, and I am sure that this will be the subject of contributions by other speakers this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has been reminded by Senator Durack that the legislation tries comprehensively to deal with a couple of situations which have arisen in recent times. The first instance arises when the United States, through one of its agencies or a private citizen within the United States, applies anti-trust legislation to the activities of non-nationals, even when that activity occurs in foreign states-in other words, outside the territorial jurisdiction of the United States-so long as there is some substantial impact on the United States economy. The United States courts take the view that they can subject that non- national to their jurisdiction if they can physically find that non-national either within the United States or elsewhere.

The most notorious example of this procedure has been thrust upon our attention over the last several years in relation to the Westinghouse case when, of course , that procedure was attempted. In relation to the activities of several Australian corporations it was alleged a cartel had been entered into in order to maintain and set an artificially high price for uranium with direct effect outside the United States, but with a claimed effect within the United States. Westinghouse entered the United States courts with a view to getting treble damages suits enforced against those Australian companies. In the end the four Australian defendant companies had to settle out of court at a cost of $11m. Of course, one of the techniques employed by those who manipulate the anti-trust laws within the United States is that they bring forward actions for treble damages, which are clearly so potentially ruinous to the defendants that they settle out of court, whatever the merits of the case, because the fact is that costs cannot be recovered even in a case in which the plaintiff's suit falls to the ground. Rather than face hundreds of thousands, even millions, of dollars in court costs, defendants prefer to settle out of court at an early stage. That is a fairly notorious example of which everyone is aware.

A more recent example was the purported extraterritorial application of presidential orders issued under the Export Administration Act of 1979 and its regulations. It will be recalled that under this process the legislation asserted jurisdiction over any foreign subsidiary or affiliate of a United States company abroad which was controlled by a company within the United States . The controlling interest could be as little as 10 per cent or 15 per cent of the shares in that particular company. Of course, over the last couple of years an attempt was made by the United States to achieve a foreign policy objective in relation to the Siberian pipeline to try to prevent its early construction. In that instance, whilst imposing certain sanctions against the Soviet Union, those regulations were invoked and orders were made to embargo the export or re- export of equipment containing United States manufactured components for use in the Soviet-European gas pipelines. This embargo included the export of equipment made outside the United States under United States licences or by overseas subsidiaries of United States companies. This action had a quite unexpected effect in Australia when Santos Ltd, which had contracted with Dresser France to obtain certain gas compressors, found that as the United States presidential ban prohibited United States companies from providing energy-related technology, goods or information to European companies, Dresser France could not fulfil that contract to Santos and Santos had to go elsewhere for the particular equipment to get the compressors it needed.

As Senator Durack said, these matters have the potential for quite ruinous treble damages judgments to be entered against Australian companies by the extraterritorial impact of United States anti-trust legislation, most usually in suits brought by private litigants who cannot be controlled by the United States Government, or by the more direct use of the presidential orders under the Export Administration Act regulations which are designed quite clearly and openly to further foreign policy concerns of the United States Government. In both instances very serious questions arise as to the need to preserve Australian sovereignty in its international relations. That applies not only to the more blatant instances but also, of course, to the Australian Government's policy of having orderly marketing schemes, particularly for the sale of our primary products overseas. In relation to these matters Australia must be in a position to protect itself, its citizens, its corporations and their employees, and its general sovereign policy, from the jurisdiction of United States courts. This legislation has been brought forward because of those concerns.

I had intended to outline the more salient points of that legislation. But I noticed that Senator Durack felt that the second reading speech sufficiently outlined those matters. Perhaps I could rest on the same approach. I did note with interest his comment that the Minister involved in the making of orders and the exercising of discretions under the equivalent United Kingdom legislation is in fact the Minister of State for Trade. Whilst it is true that we have followed the pattern set by Senator Durack's earlier legislation where the Attorney- General was vested with this power, I think it might bear some examination for the future to see whether the powers to make these various orders are most properly or conveniently vested in the Attorney-General.

The fact is that we have here an underlying jurisdictional threat to Australian sovereignty and to our various export and trading policies. Certainly there has been no significant change in the United States anti-trust laws. I believe that we are right to bring such legislation forward. I use a fairly neutral phrase there-'bring such legislation forward'-because, like Senator Durack and some members of the Opposition, I had misgivings about translating this Bill into law . The reason I entertained those misgivings as to the timing was that there has been some evidence of a changing pattern of judicial pronouncements within the United States. In fact, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence recognised this development of judicial doctrine within the U.S. It referred to a US Court of Appeals decision in the Timberlane Lumber Co. case and a US Court of Appeals decision for the Third Circuit in the Mannington Mills case-courts of some status in the hierarchy. In the Timberland case it was stated by the Court that it would take into account these matters:
(a) Does the alleged restraint effect, or was it intended to effect, the foreign commerce of the United States?
(b) Is the alleged restraint of such a type of magnitude so as to be cognisable as a violation of United States anti-trust laws?
And, most importantly for our purposes:
(c) As a matter of international comity and fairness, should the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the United States be asserted to cover it?

Honourable senators may well argue that it is not really for a judge or a court to make that sort of decision as to the bounds of international comity and fairness and the extent to which the jurisdiction of the court ought to be pushed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagine, Senator, you would be fairly conscious of what the extraterritoriality claim in relation to this sort of thing very nearly did to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation with the gas pipeline. So it does have its very great dangers.

—Yes. I take it that Senator Rae's intervening at this point to say that they are matters of such moment and such consequence that to vest decisions as to whether the matter should be pressed in a judge or a bench of non-elected judges has its dangers.
—It has its dangers unless there is very full evidence available as to what all those other consequences may be.

—That is right. It will be difficult to put those matters before a court. Indeed, however fully they are put before a court, the objection will remain that it is a non-elected bench and it ought not be making decisions of that character. Nevertheless, I mention that particular case and the Mannington Mills case which followed, which laid down some 10 criteria for the US courts to consider when the question of extraterritorial enforcement of one of its judgments arises. The sixth point was the 'Possible effect upon foreign relations if the court exercises jurisdiction and grants relief'. Those criteria have not yet found universal acceptance within the United States judicial system . Nevertheless, there was a movement there which gave rise to some thought that perhaps we ought to stand back and watch that and encourage its development over the next several years rather than come in with legislation at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second cause for not being so sure of the timing was that an agreement of a very single, special and extraordinary kind has been entered into between the Australian Government and the United States Government. I believe it is the envy of the other trading partners of the United States. Honourable senators will recall that, in brief, the agreement contains: A provision requiring the United States to give Australia prompt and detailed notification of any United States Department of Justice or Federal Trade Commission anti-trust investigation that might have implications for Australia's national interest; a provision providing an option for Australia to notify the United States of any Australian policy which might have implications for United States anti-trust laws; and a provision that, after such notification either party may seek consultations and that conflicts are to be resolved with due regard to each other's sovereignty and to considerations of comity.

Very clearly, in relation to matters which are instigated or initiated by United States Government agencies, there is good provision for consultation and modification of a stance that may have been taken up in the United States courts . But in relation to private action there is still a great difficulty. It is recognised in the agreement that the United States Government would intervene in private anti-trust actions to inform the court of the substance and outcome of consultations where the matter before the court includes activity which has been the subject of notification and consultation under the agreement. That is a mere intervening obligation cast upon the United States Government to come into a court where private litigants have instigated anti-trust actions and the court may or may not take into account the criteria I have outlined from the Timberlane and Mannington Mills cases. In any case, the weight to be given by the court to the various considerations of international comity is something that is quite unpredictable and still therefore leaves Australian corporations in the jeopardy that they may face a treble damages decision.

The view of the Joint Committee was, as I recall, that that agreement was a very significant step towards resolving an issue which had been a major irritant in relations between the two countries over a number of years. Nevertheless, the Committee concluded that, whilst this provided a good framework and certainly a token of good faith on both sides, there needed to be this further element of legislation brought forward. I believe that we are right to do so. It ought to be noted for the record that during discussions at the time of drawing up the Joint Committee report, which were always aimed at getting a consensus report, as I recall it, was put forward that the significance of the agreement could be acknowledged and we should have some sort of phrase in the report to the effect that the legislation be introduced and allowed to lay on the table without actually being processed through the Parliament but that, nevertheless, it would bring the legislation up out of the dungeons or the bowels of the department and lay it for public exposure and comment-that every official within the relevant United States agencies and the lawyers in the major United States corporations would know or suspect that such legislation was in preparation and it was a question of laying it out for public view and then bringing it into play if it were required. That compromise formula, as I recall it, was not accepted on the Committee. Therefore, the conclusion reached by the Committee was in the terms that 'The Committee recommends that the Attorney-General introduce legislation into the Parliament' to carry out that which it does carry out. In relation to that I am sufficiently persuaded by the argument of the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech, where he stated:

. . . it is better to introduce protective legislation now, during a period of improved relations, than to leave it until some crisis arrives, and so heighten what would be at that time a public perception of conflict between our two countries.

I think that argument has merit. I think the Senate is right to accede to it, as I believe the shadow Attorney-General has indicated will be done by the Opposition. The argument has sufficient force to persuade me to support the timing of the introduction and passage of this legislation. I support the Bill because of the need to overcome a potentially ruinous application of the United States courts' jurisdiction within Australia upon our corporations trading within Australia and overseas on the basis of policies which have been formulated by democratic processes under our government. As Senator Rae quite rightly pointed out, there are major foreign policy implications. I may have mentioned the Santos case before Senator Rae came into the chamber. The matter that the honourable senator alluded to had an unexpected impact in relation to gas pipelines in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —An extraordinary ramification, but a very real one.

—That is right. We need to have as many shields as possible-I adopt the language of Senator Durack-in our arsenal, if one can have defensive equipment in an arsenal, and for that reason I believe this legislation ought to be passed into law and should be supported by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill 1983. I very much regret that this legislation is before the Senate at this time. I remind the Senate that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), in his second reading speech, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Government's firm belief that jurisdictional conflicts between the laws and policies of sovereign governments should be resolved if at all possible by consultation and not by unilateral legal or executive action. But here jurisdictional conflict is attempted to be resolved by unilateral legislative action.
He also stated:
. . . the Government reaffirms Australia's commitment to the consultative approach of the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement between Australia and the United States.

This is not evidence of the consultative process in action. Rather this Bill is of a confrontationist nature. Furthermore, in current circumstances it is unnecessary confrontation. There is no evidence of current need and certainly no evidence has been given in the Minister's speech. To make matters worse, it is destructive of the consultative process. The consultative process, which went as far up as heads of state, was the path chosen by the previous Government to avoid the need for confrontationalist legislation such as this.

I remind the Senate that former Prime Minister Fraser and President Reagan met to discuss an alternative course and through them, and in due course their Attorneys-General, an agreement was reached. The action of the previous Government led to what is accepted as a unique agreement between Australia and the United States. It is a bilateral agreement which goes beyond that which had been previously negotiated between the United States and such countries as Canada and West Germany. I referred to the unique nature of the agreement in a speech I gave on this subject in the Senate on 2 December last year. It is based on the understanding and belief that the consultative process was the better way of resolving these difficulties, a better way than legislation which would only further inflame what has been at times a difficult trading relationship. Both parties-Australia and the United States-saw that as the better way to go. Clawback legislation, recovery-back legislation or what ever one calls it, is not helpful in industrial relations. The United States experience with the United Kingdom did not enhance the type of relationship we should all be seeking between friends and allies.

I remind the Senate of the language that was used in the report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the extraterritorial application of United States laws. It adopted language that was put to it that there was lengthy and acrimonious confrontation between the United States and the United Kingdom following the implementation of the United Kingdom law. The previous government was of a view that that was not the way to go if there was a better alternative. The United States also had learnt by its experience and had negotiated with Australia with what I think can be fairly described as a new attitude. Australia on its part made it clear that if the consultative agreement could be made to work it was preferable to legislation. It is clear-I think this is the critical point in this debate-that an understanding was reached that we would go further and legislate on recovery-back only if the agreement failed. Tonight we heard the former Attorney-General remind the Senate that the recovery -back legislation was before the Senate for a long period but it was not enacted because of the understanding that had been reached with the United States that it would be enacted only if bilateral agreement failed. I remind the Senate of Senator Durack's Press release of 29 June 1983 in which he stated:

On behalf of the then Australian Government I assured the United States Government that we would not proceed with any further blocking legislation unless the Agreement proved less successful than we hoped.

As I have said, there is no evidence that the agreement has failed. There is no evidence in the Minister's second reading speech that the agreement has failed. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, also stated:

When the Labor Government came into office in March this year, the general climate between Australia and the United States in relation to the extraterritorial enforcement of U.S. antitrust laws had improved significantly in no small measure due to the fact that both countries were trying to abide by the spirit and the letter of the Agreement.

The Australian Government is reneging on the deal that was made. It is putting at risk the good faith that has developed. It is waving the legislative big stick at the United States in a provocative way when it acknowledges that both parties were, I repeat, trying to abide by the spirit and letter of the agreement. It is acknowledging that it does not have faith in the consultative solution. Its potential destruction of the good faith that has been built up through that agreement is something that I very much regret. I am not saying that the Westinghouse case was not an unsatisfactory affair and I am not condoning the international grasp of United States anti-trust law which I think is, on occasions, contrary to international law and international comity. I am not critical of the enactment of, first, the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976 or, secondly, the Foreign Antitrust Judgments ( Restriction of Enforcement) Act of 1979 which, in the heat of the Westinghouse case, were necessary. It was a time of bad experiences and the Government had a responsibility to protect Australian interests. But the question that we then had to face was where should the Government go along the road of resolving these international trading difficulties. Should the Government introduce further legislation-I acknowledge, and I am sure the Attorney-General would acknowledge, that no legislation in this field can be totally protective- or should it seek a better alternative to develop machinery whereby these difficulties might be overcome by a consulative process in good faith? To its credit, the previous Government chose the latter path. The agreement reached, as I indicated, goes further than any previous agreement and is, I believe, to the great credit and achievement of Senator Durack. The scope and functions of that agreement are well set out in the explanatory memorandum. I say in passing that the explanatory memorandum is comprehensive, helpful and to be commended. I remind the Senate of paragraph 42 of that memorandum which states:

The Agreement does not attempt to provide a comprehensive panacea to cure all problems which might arise from the extraterritorial enforcement of antitrust laws. Rather, it is a framework for conflict resolution, in which two nations, respecting and understanding each other's differing positions on important issues have committed themselves to consultations and related conduct that will enable potential conflicts to be faced squarely at the earliest possible time, and to be resolved in a spirit of accommodation and compromise, according to the principles of comity and equality of sovereignty.
If one goes to the terms of the agreement itself-I just briefly touch upon the premise to the agreement-the language is of the same style:
The Government of Australia and the Government of the United States of America;

Recognising that conflicts have arisen between the interests reflected in the United States anti-trust laws and policies and those reflected in Australian laws and policies, and that such conflicts may arise in the future;
Recognising the need for such conflicts to be resolved with mutual respect for each other's sovereignty and with due regard for considerations of comity;
Considering that intergovernmental consultations may facilitate the resolution of such conflicts;
Desiring to establish an appropriate bilateral framework for conducting consultations; and
Considering that in, the absence of conflicts, co-operation between the Governments of Australia and the United States is desirable in the enforcement of anti-trust laws,
Have agreed as follows--

So continues the agreement that was reached. I think that one has only to consider those words to realise the moment of the agreement that was, in fact, reached. Also, if one looks at the words of the then United States Attorney- General, one sees further evidence of that good faith and the early development of what I think can be described as a new and commendable United States attitude in this field. I remind the Senate of his words at the time, which appear in the report I mentioned. The Attorney said:

While neither of our countries has sacrificed any part of its sovereignty or rights under international law by this agreement, we have agreed upon an excellent mechanism for channelling and containing potential differences. The United States will work diligently to ensure the usefulness of that mechanism to both nations.
I repeat:
The United States will work diligently to ensure the usefulness of that mechanism to both nations.

The Labor Government is putting all of this at risk by this Bill. Why? One can surmise only that a new Attorney-General hungry for legislative achievement, a Prime Minister perhaps too busy at sporting contests, a Caucus always gleefully ready to embrace any attempt to kick the Americans, fail to appreciate the consequences of their actions.

The Attorney-General said that he went to the United States and satisfied himself that America would not be too concerned by such legislation. I invite him to produce one statement from an American official that expressed that view. It is illogical in view of the existence of the agreement to which I have referred and the statements made by the then American Attorney-General which I have quoted. We then get the argument that now is the right time. The Attorney- General said:
. . . in the light of this much improved relationship between the two countries .
In other words, we can slap the American face now because we are getting on better. The Attorney-General in his second reading speech, said:
. . . it is better to introduce protective legislation now, during a period of improved relations, than to leave it until some crisis arrives--

What a disappointingly negative approach, an approach that dismisses the agreement and the good faith upon which it is based, that dismisses the consultative process. The Attorney-General, in his speech, places great emphasis on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Not surprisingly he fails to mention that a third of the members of that Committee, after taking into account those who were away, strongly dissented, believing that to legislate in these terms, whilst the agreement was being given an opportunity to work, was not in Australia's best interests.

I remind the Senate that apart from myself, members of the Committee included Mr Coleman who is, I think, highly regarded by all in the area of international affairs; Mr Shipton, the former Chairman of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of this Parliament; Mr Lusher, who was the Chairman of the Sub -Committee inquiring into the Pacific Basin which took upon itself this reference and who had to chair the first half of that Sub-Committee's reference before the last election; the Hon. Ray Groom, and you, Mr Acting Deputy President. These members were all of the view that to legislate at this time in these terms was unwise. I would have thought that to be fair, when the Attorney- General was laying great emphasis in his speech upon the decisions and recommendations of the Joint Committee, he would have made some reference to the fact that about a third of the members of that Committee held a totally different view.

I wish to look very briefly at the other of the Attorney-General's arguments. He says that one reason we should proceed in this way is that no significant change in United States domestic anti-trust laws is occurring; whereas I think anyone who has done work in this field would concede that Congress is particularly stubborn in this area and that his statement is technically correct . I draw the attention of those who are interested to chapter 6 of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which looks at all sorts of new pressures that are being brought to bear by the American Bar Association, by the Justice Department, by the State Department, by the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia and other American chambers of commerce throughout the region and to a number of supportive speeches that are starting to occur, in fact, within the Congress. There is evidence of a slowly changing-but changing- attitude. Whether that is to continue whilst governments such as ours unnecessarily decide to enact provocative legislation is questionable.

Secondly, the Attorney-General says that the agreement will not resolve problems of private treble damages. I say that whilst there is no absolute answer to that, article 6 of the agreement provides a process which allows the American Government to become involved and which requires consultation between governments and for the American Government to put the result of such consultations to the court. Under the Timberlane principle it is likely, I believe, to be taken into account. But the trouble is that we will never know whether the agreement would have satisfactorily worked because this Government has decided that there are better courses to take by provocative legislation.

Thirdly, the Attorney says that the agreement will not overcome trade problems that might arise incidentally after the use by the United States of its Export Administration Act to implement foreign policy decisions. That point has been mentioned by others tonight. Again, the way the Government proposes to act is not the way to resolve such difficulties. When one envisages particular examples it is difficult to see how it would work. I for one cannot see how it could have helped the Santos case, which I noticed was not mentioned by the Attorney- General in his speech. That is the case usually cited as the type of problem that could be overcome by such legislation. The fact is that we cannot effectively legislate out of these problems. Their solution depends upon good relations and good faith. It is a choice of the way in which to operate when in government-whether we are prepared to stand by foreign relations undertakings given by a previous government or whether we favour the consultative process over that of the implied threat. It is clear that the former Government preferred the consultative process and gave the opportunity for a new leadership between friends in what has been a difficult area. It is clear that this Government prefers the alternative of an implied threat. It talks about its comprehensive arsenal of defences, terms which might be used more appropriately in a policy on war or defence.

The present Opposition is still anxious to remain constructive and will not formally oppose the Bill. To divide would be to accentuate the differences, and that is still not seen by us as in Australia's best interest. This is not the way we would have gone had we remained in government. In summary, the decision the Government has made, I believe, reflects poorly upon Australia and its good foreign relations and has led to a situation which I regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Financial Review reported on 15 September 1978 the comments of Mr A. H. Page, then, I understand, a senior officer with the Department of National Resources. Amongst the comments he made was this sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: The philosophy underlying US anti-trust law is not necessarily in Australia's national interest in regard to export of our natural resources.

Nor apparently was it considered to be in the interests of certain other countries, as the Australian Trade Practices Reporter mentioned several years later in an article under the heading 'Enforcement Jurisdiction', which made the following comment:

. . . the encroachment of foreign anti-trust investigation and litigation abroad has recently led to positive action by way of blocking legislation enacted, inter alia, by Australia, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, Canada and The Netherlands . . . Governments have felt it necessary to secure their own sovereignty by legislating to protect their own citizens against investigations and orders sought to be enforced domestically by the US authorities where doubt exists as to the likelihood that the courts will prevent such investigations on the ground of their repugnancy to international law.

The blocking legislation enacted in Australia relates both to the investigatory stage and the enforcement of orders in foreign proceedings. Although it is not strictly relevant to the extra territorial operation of the Australian Act, it is convenient that it be dealt with here-
that is, in this article-
and maybe instructive from the point of view of comparison.
The two pieces of legislation were a direct result of proceedings seeking treble damages commenced by Westinghouse Electric Corporation against 29 United States and foreign uranium producers.

The Westinghouse case in 1977-79, if it served to do nothing else, served to highlight the fact that as yet Australia and other trading nations do not live in a world economic community. Certainly no one would argue that the removal of artificial trade barriers within a nation state such as Australia is essential if we are to achieve the benefits flowing from competition, such benefits including lower cost to the consumer and the efficient allocation of resources within the economy. Notwithstanding that fact, even in that context we in this country justify a degree of intervention to protect the weak. It is interesting to note though that as yet we in Australia have no legislation akin to the anti- trust laws in the United States which are designed to ensure that the strong do not misuse their position to force up market prices. That may at the moment be no real problem in Australia and indeed there may be no internal need for such legislation. However, it is quite another matter if such internal provisions are to be used to disadvantage individual companies trading in the world economy. In that context it is essentially the individual nation states rather than the individual companies which are trading partners, with varying degrees of strength. Individual companies are part of their respective economic fabrics and I believe nations have the right and the duty to protect those companies against attacks on their economic viability which in turn could well affect the national economy.

In 1977-78 Australia's export income from minerals was $4.7 billion, which represented something like 39 per cent of the total national export income that financial year. This was of no small value to Australia and the Australian Government encouraged it, as indeed it should. In the context of what, in view of recent developments, we laughingly call resource diplomacy, Australian companies sued by the Westinghouse Corporation did what Australian Government officials had been recommending that they do to avoid being played off against each other by international buyers; that is, they made price agreements in a market which had been severely destabilised by the release of in the vicinity of 50,000 tonnes of U308 from the United States uranium stockpile.

At this point, in view of the resource which was involved, I ought to make the point that the Australian Democrats view that the Australian companies were entitled to government intervention to protect them and to protect Australia's economic interests is not to be taken as any sort of approval of or support for the products they were trading in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, I am shattered!

—I thought that the honourable senator would be absolutely destroyed by that! I am totally and utterly surprised! However, I am sure the honourable senator will agree that we all share a belief in the principle of the matter; that is, that it was something of vital concern to Australia, the effect of which on the companies concerned and on the Australian economy could have been quite devastating. In the event, the punitive treble damages available under United States anti-trust legislation which I have already mentioned in the article from which I quoted at the beginning-I understand they were something like $7 billion-and which may well have been justified and justifiable in that context and in that country were sought against 29 uranium producers, including Conzinc Rio Tinto of Australia Ltd, Mary Kathleen Uranium Ltd, Pancontinental Mining Ltd and Queensland Mines Ltd. Ultimately, as I understand it, the judgment was entered after, and indeed despite, Australia's attempt to raise jurisdictional objections; and those objections, I also have been given to understand, were somewhat contemptuously dismissed.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence, in March 1979 the Australian Parliament enacted the Foreign Anti-Trust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act enabling enforcement of the judgment in proceedings in Australia to be prohibited by order of the Attorney-General. Orders were in fact made by the Attorney-General prohibiting the enforcement or recognition in whole or in part in Australia of the judgment entered in these proceedings. However, that 1979 Bill was limited in its application merely to anti-trust judgments. The 1981 'recovery back' Bill introduced by the previous government was not passed, as I understand from some comments made by Senator Durack earlier this evening, apparently in an effort to avoid straining the somewhat fragile agreement on anti-trust co-operation concluded with the United States in 1982. I am somewhat at a loss to understand why it is always Australia that has to tread fairly warily whenever these sorts of agreements look like being broken or strained to the limit. Certainly the United States of America did not worry too much about what damage it was likely to have on its relations with Australia when the United States undertook the proceedings which produced this brouhaha.

As Senator Durack also pointed out, that agreement provides avenues for consultation and negotiation but acknowledges that ultimately 'both countries can protect their national interests as they see fit'. Indeed, I believe that the 1979 decision by the Australian Attorney-General was made for the purpose of protecting our national interest in relation to the trading operations of trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth. The present Bill seeks to further this aim by extending protection against enforcement to other than anti-trust actions and to protect Australian citizens and companies from the extraterritorial enforcement of foreign laws.

I am not a lawyer. I cannot judge or enter into the fascinating arguments that have been thrown around the chamber tonight by the legal experts in this place. I can simply say that if in effect this Bill does do just that-as I have indicated it does, that is, if it offers protection to Australian citizens and companies from the extraterritorial enforcement of foreign laws, laws which may be well suited to the country in which they were formed but of no particular relevance to Australia, whose laws are established under totally different criteria-it will be supported by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much appreciate, on behalf of the Government, the support for the Bill that has been expressed around the chamber, particularly by Senator Durack, leading for the Opposition, who had a particular personal interest in this whole policy area, and for whom the signing of the agreement with the United States of America represented a very significant personal achievement and, indeed, a significant achievement for the then Australian Government. I can understand the reservations that have been expressed in various parts of the chamber by Senator Durack himself and, more particularly, by Senator Hill, because this is a very sensitive and difficult area. But I also appreciate the way in which honourable senators appear to have overcome those reservations and have seen the necessity for there to be strong and uncompromising bipartisan support for a measure of this kind if it is to successfully serve the very purpose for which it is, after all, being introduced , namely, to remind the United States, in particular, but also any other country that might be minded to engage in extraterritorial activity of a legislative kind, that their trading partners and the rest of the world will not simply look idly by while their interest, our interests, are threatened or potentially threatened by such activity.

SPEECH.PARA: The objective of this legislative enterprise, the putting in place of some potential sticks to match the carrot that is already there, at least in the anti -trust context with the bilateral agreement, has, I think, been sufficiently explained in the second reading speech not to require repetition from me now. As Senator Durack pointed out, what we are about will be very well understood in the United Kingdom, and certainly also by Canada and a number of European countries, which are only too well aware of the need to shore up legislative and associated defences against the potential application of United States law in these areas. What we are about is equally very well understood by the business community, which, particularly through the Business Council of Australia, which has been apparently the major spokesman on this issue, has made no bones at all about its support for this legislation.

The reservations that have been expressed range over a number of different matters. I shall not endeavour to cover them all, but I should address at least a couple of points made by Senator Hill, in particular, in reliance upon and in repetition of the reservations of the minority members of the Joint Parliamentary Committee that considered this matter in its very constructive and useful report. The first matter to which I refer in this respect is the suggestion that the Australian Government may in some way be acting improperly in proceeding with this legislation in the light of the signing of the anti- trust co-operation agreement. But that sort of criticism fails, I think, significantly to acknowledge that, apart even from the continued concern with private triple damages actions, which concern was expressed by the then Attorney -General in an address on the signing of the agreement, the whole of the negotiations for that agreement took place against a background of the introduction and presence on the Notice Paper at the time of the recovery back legislation and of a series of public statements by the then Attorney-General that those provisions in the 1981 Bill were being further considered and refined and that there may well indeed be supplementary provisions to accompany them, and, indeed, against a background, further, of an understanding by the United States-the subject of oral discussions rather than anything that was particularly documented-that the conclusion of the Agreement did not necessarily preclude further Australian legislation.

I think that one can go so far as to say, fairly robustly, that at all times, as I understand it, during the negotiation of the agreement it was comtemplated that at least recovery back legislation of the kind proposed in that June 1981 legislation would be introduced. Indeed, the final form of that legislation was settled after the bilateral agreement had been negotiated in the middle of June 1982. The giving away, as it were, of the legislation seems to have come about at the euphoria of the signing, and the dissentients, in their report, are really just in error in point of fact, as I am advised, in assuming, as they do at page 68 of the report, the contrary.

So much for the past. What of the present and the likely response of the United States Government to the passage by the Australian Parliament of this legislation? Are we really generating, as Senator Hill would almost have us believe in one particular flight of rhetorical fancy, a warlike response and provoking accordingly a likely warlike reaction on the part of our friends across the Pacific? To make any such claim is, I think, completely to fail to appreciate the tenor of the further discussions that have taken place with the United States in the context of the development of these legislative proposals. As I made clear in the second reading speech, I engaged in extensive discussions on this matter in the United States, in the course of a fairly eventful trip in the middle of last year, during which, among other things, my house burnt down. The United States Government understood, I believe, the need for Australia, from Australia's point of view, to have protective legislation. I shall not seek to saddle it with the second leg of the famous double and say that it not only understood but also accepted the need for Australia to have protective legislation of its own, but it did, nonetheless, appreciate that Australia saw its interests as demanding an additional legislative series of protections of the kind that had become quite familiar with the United States' other trading partners, not least, of course, the United Kingdom, with its protection of trading interests legislation.

United States officials were provided at an early date with copies of the Bill and other relevant documents and were invited to discuss the matter with Australian officials if they thought it necessary. I am able to report that, to date, apart from an informal inquiry on a technical aspect of the Bill and what I might describe as a couple of wry remarks to me from United States diplomats at odd times in the last six months on the Canberra cocktail circuit, there has simply been no official or unofficial reaction from the United States. One could hardly pretend that the United States would be ecstatic to see any country moving to join the list of those putting in place protective legislation of this kind; but nor does it, I assure the Parliament, regard the exercise as being a provocative one or one that is beyond the ken in terms of the continuing relations of otherwise friendly trading partners.

The final group of points that need quickly to be made relates to the terms of the 1982 agreement and to whether that is sufficient for us to roll along with in the foreseeable future without the necessity for legislation of this kind. This matter has been sufficiently addressed in the second reading speech, but I think it needs to be reiterated, first, that the 1982 agreement is not in any way an all-purpose one; after all, it deals only with the anti-trust area and certainly has nothing to say about the application in Australia of the Export Administration Act, about which Australian business is justifiably very concerned. Equally, the 1982 agreement certainly does not cover the field very effectively or completely so far as private suits are concerned. The consultative procedures are not very powerful weapons in this area and there is always the prospect of the rogue elephant, a treble damages private suit, appearing in the anti-trust area to really make a mess of rational trading relations.

The balance of the interests approach in the two court cases-Timberlane Lumber Co. and Mannington Mills-useful as that may be, has not been unequivocally adopted by Unites States courts and we simply cannot assume, in any event, that that will always produce the kind of result that is appropriate from the point of view of domestic Australian industry and national protection. Essentially, United States interests are not uniform. Certainly they are not identical to our interests and neither consultation nor the application of judicious judicial balance will necessarily produce acceptable results. The legislation is not in a form which involves a plunging into confrontation on the first occasion on which a potential conflict arises. It enables all sorts of discretions to be exercised by the Government, by the appropriate Minister, as situations develop.

The final point I make relates to who the appropriate Minister should be. This matter was raised by Senator Durack when he asked: 'Why does not the Minister for Trade administer this legislation as is the case in the United Kingdom?'. I simply say that the Minister for Trade and Industry in the United Kingdom has traditionally dealt not only with this area but, indeed, with the whole area of what in Australia might be regarded as the business law part of the Attorney- General's portfolio, including company law, such British-type restrictive practices legislation as there is, securities control and matters of that kind.

Traditionally in Australia the Attorney-General, when there has not been a Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, has had the ministerial responsibility for these matters. So far as the extraterritorial operation of anti-trust legislation is concerned, the Attorney-General has certainly had the carriage and co-ordination of matters in this area. I make no imperial bid for the retention of any jurisdiction in this respect, I have quite enough on my plate in this as, indeed, in a number of other areas. I simply make the point that it is as it is because that is the way it has been. That is not to say that it will not be that way in future. I make the point that the making of any order in this area will be a matter for the whole Government taking into account trade policy considerations as well as local or peculiarly technical legal ones. I will certainly have very close regard to the views of all relevant Ministers before making any order in this area. Once again, I thank all honourable senators, particularly Senator Durack who, I repeat, has played a major personal role in this area over the years. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Domican: Marrickville Council-Darwin Airport-Northern Territory Criminal Code

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to answer allegations made against me in the New South Wales Parliament by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, Mrs Rosemary Foot, on Thursday, 23 February. The substance of the allegations were that a man named Tom Domican had been employed by a property developer, Mr Warren Anderson, to work as an Australian Labor Party operative in the inner city and to do my bidding; further, that Mr Anderson had paid Domican $20,000 a year for two years to do so; and, further, that in return for these favours granted to me Mr Anderson was to receive preferential treatment from ALP-dominated councils in his development and rezoning applications. The councils mentioned specifically were Marrickville, Ashfield, Fairfield, Waverley, Liverpool and Campbelltown. A development at Woonoona in the Wollongong Council area was also referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: To try to answer all of the allegations against me will take some time. Nevertheless, first and foremost, all of the allegations are based on the unsubstantiated work of Mr Domican. I wish to inform the Senate of some of the activities of Mr Domican, why he has pursued a vendetta against me for the past 18 months, why I believe that vendetta will continue and why I believe it will have no effect. If one looks at the activities of Domican over a long period in the Marrickville area in the inner city of Sydney one sees a pattern-a history of threats, intimidation and violence waged against many ordinary citizens of Marrickville but, most particularly, many Party members and aldermen. All of those involved had at times suffered the overwhelming sheer physical presence of Domican. Anyone who saw Nationwide last night knows he is no man to be trifled with when it comes to matters physical. He professes to be an expert in the martial arts.

We saw an unsavoury period in Marrickville, particularly in 1982. Finally in October of that year an assault on Alderman Ken Brennan took place after a council meeting. It was witnessed by Alderman Margaret Newman. That matter received wide publicity. Indeed, it received coverage in the newspapers and in the New South Wales Parliament. I spoke at the time to Alderman Brennan and to Alderman Newman. Alderman Brennan had been terrorised by Domican for some time. He did not wish to pursue the matter with the police because he feared reprisals . Accordingly, I spoke to Domican and asked him not to attend any future council meetings. He agreed to my request, while denying that the assault had taken place and stating that Mr Brennan had simply fallen down and put on an act. Alderman Margaret Newman told me the real facts of the matter. It did involve a serious and brutal assault by Domican.

After that incident no further violence was reported for some time, but in December 1982 Domican broke his undertaking to me and attended another council meeting. At that meeting a confrontation developed between Domican, the Mayor, Alderman Harrison, and Alderman Margaret Newman. The next morning, one could believe by divine intervention-I do not-a masked intruder entered Alderman Margaret Newman's home and bashed her. She received treatment in hospital from a doctor. Photographs of her bruised and bloodied face appeared in practically all the Sydney newspapers at the time.
