Very shortly after that bashing I had a meeting with Alderman Newman, her husband, Alderman Barry Jones, and a number of other aldermen from the Council. All of them complained of a pattern of threats, intimidation and violence which had increased in the previous six to 12 months. I suggested to them that, if I were an alderman on Marrickville Council, if I were suffering from these threats , this intimidation and actual physical violence, I would resign from the Council and I would ask the Government to sack the Council and appoint an administrator.

After discussing the matter with them for some hours the aldermen present at the meeting agreed to do so. Furthermore, they agreed to talk to other aldermen to see whether they could persuade any of them to go along with them. In the end seven aldermen resigned from the Marrickville Council because of the threats and the violence of Domican. These seven aldermen represented all shades of opinion within the Party. Not all of them were friends of mine. But they were all united on one point: They could not take any more. On that point we were all united.

Where were the investigative reporters of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Nationwide program during the last few days? They found time to make a folk hero of Domican. While listening to his plea that he had never threatened anyone where were they? Why were they not knocking on Margaret Newman 's door, Ken Brennan's door, Grahame Watson's door, or on the door of any other alderman who had been the subject of actual physical threats and violence by Domican in that period? Did they ask Lin Gordon, the Minister whom the aldermen went to see when they resigned, why he had taken the action to sack the Council? I suspect not unless that was edited out of the program.

I would like to read just a few clippings from the Press at the time which I think show that the opinions I am expressing here tonight are not my own but were widely shared by everybody at the time, including the Fairfax media and, in particular, the Sydney Morning Herald. The first article from which I will quote is from the Sun-Herald of 19 December 1982. In an article that was headed 'The Bashing that brought down a council', Margaret Newman was quoted as saying to Joe Payne who wrote the article:
'I was threatened before, but nothing ever happened . . .
Now I'm so scared I won't stay alone in the house-and the windows and doors stay locked.
I would like to think nothing more is going to happen, but I don't know.'

In the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 December 1982 Lin Gordon, to whom neither the Sydney Morning Herald nor the Nationwide reporters chose to talk, after having talked to all the aldermen involved said:
'No one would give evidence. People were frightened.
'There is obviously an explosive situation and I've got to defuse it. The situation is one of great concern.'

He said that the aldermen had shown great courage to resign and it was a credit to them. To quote Mike Stekettee who has been for some years now the number one political writer in the New South Wales Parliament for the Sydney Morning Herald :

. . . there are very clear links, acknowledged by the Right and the Left of the Labor Party, between the firebombing of Alderman Graham Watson's car, the bashing of Alderman Ken Brennan and Margaret Newman and of Peter Baldwin, MP, and each of these persons' activities, particularly in opposition to a small and notorious clique in Marrickville, to make it clear that the violence is motivated by politics and power in the Labor Party and the council.

The opinions that I am expressing are not simply mine. They were the opinions expressed by all and sundry at the time. What makes the argument so preposterous -that is, the argument that Domican was working for me-is the fact that most of these seven aldermen, those who were exposed to the threats, the violence and the intimidation, were my friends. Indeed, some of them were my close friends. I have known Alderman Margaret Newman's husband, Barry Jones, for some 15 years and I regard him as a close friend. These attacks against my friends went on and on. They also went on against my enemies. In fact if I could be criticised for anything that I have done in the Marrickville area at that time it would be for not having removed Domican and his element much earlier.

After the bashing of Margaret Newman, I decided, as the responsible officer of the Party, that we had to draw a line. The Labor Party could not handle those sorts of disputes. I could not find any reference in the Labor Party rule book as to how one handles someone who goes around bashing one's colleagues, especially when those bashings occur in one-off situations, when they are very difficult to prove and, more particularly, even where they are witnessed, when no one is prepared to give evidence because of the reprisals they fear will take place later. Ever since that time I have lived with all sorts of allegations emanating from Domican. However, I have to say that, if asked to do it all again , I would. The decision that was made at the time to talk to those aldermen and discuss with them the possibility of resigning, to see them resign and then to see the Council sacked was correct. At least it can be said that, in the 18 months that have ensued, there have been no further acts of violence perpetrated against those aldermen or against any member of the Party in the area at all.

Furthermore, it should be noted that before the last election Domican proclaimed loud and long in Marrickville that Leo McLeay, the Federal member for Grayndler, against whom he also has a fair sized vendetta, would not be allowed to take his place in Parliament as the honourable member for Grayndler and I would never be allowed to sit as a senator. He was wrong on both occasions. He will be wrong in anything else that he tries to talk Rosemary Foot into saying. Furthermore, what really annoys me about this matter is that this man, by his own actions, has shown that he has no credibility whatsoever. This aspect of the allegations that he was working for me in any capacity whatsoever is nothing more than a sick joke emanating from a very sick man.

After the attack on Ken Brennan, when Domican had given me an undertaking that he would no longer attend Marrickville Council meetings, he told me that he wished to stand for Labor pre-selection for Marrickville Council-something which he had tried to do before in 1980 when I and others had simply told him that he had to withdraw his nomination because we would not proceed with it. He told me he wished to nominate again for the 1983 election. I told him then, as my fellow officers at the time can bear out, that not only would he not be an alderman on Marrickville Council by winning a pre-selection from the Labor Party but also I would not support, on the administrative committee, his ever receiving endorsement to stand as a Labor alderman. It is natural in Labor Party circles to work at maximising one's support by encouraging people to join party branches . Domican was engaged in that activity. He was doing so of his own volition to support his own nomination and to support the nomination of the Mayor, his other friends and colleagues.

Let me turn now to the actual allegation about his employment with Mr Anderson. I say at the outset that it was well known in Marrickville at the time-it could hardly be denied by even Domican himself-that Domican was the close confidante, the shadow if one likes, the constant companion and many said the minder, of the Mayor, Alderman Harrison. I want to make it clear that I bear no malice towards Alderman Harrison. He has been a part of Domican's campaign from time to time-a campaign that has been to the Corporate Affairs Commission, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and to newspapers such as the National Times, although it would not print the allegations without them being substantiated by an independent representative or person. Naturally enough, no such person could be found. But I bear Harrison no malice. He has simply been dominated and used by Domican.

Back in 1981 Alderman Harrison had several discussions with Warren Anderson. As a result of those discussions Mr Anderson employed Mr Domican to act as a security guard for his properties in Marrickville. He was employed for one year and not for two years as was previously stated. Given that the value of Mr Anderson's properties in Marrickville at the time was some $16m the fact that he would employ someone to protect them from vandals and squatters-there was quite a deal of publicity about that at the time-should come as no surprise to anyone. Furthermore, the caretaker of the Alice Street, Newtown, site had been bashed over the head with a piece of 4 x 2 and seemed to have lost all of his enthusiasm for the job. I cannot state that I witnessed Domican during his employment over that time. All I can say is that Mr Anderson informs me that he had no further trouble with vandals or squatters.

To go further into these allegations that he was some kind of emissary for me and that he was working for me, it must be remembered that Domican was a hated man in Marrickville. Association with him rubbed off on all those who dared to be a part of it. What is more, when Alderman Harrison, the person to whom I have referred, nominated for pre-selection for the State seat of Marrickville in comparatively recent times he received fewer than 30 votes out of some 250 votes , which would suggest that any claim of support by Domican or any claim that he ensured that thousands of people joined the Party in the area are false and can pretty easily be seen to be so.

The fact that Rosemary Foot would use Domican as the sole source of her allegations fascinates me. From time to time I have remembered John Dowd. Honourable senators will remember that he is a former Leader of the Liberal Party of New South Wales. These people are hard to remember as they come and go like the seasons of the year. In the New South Wales Parliament on 14 October 1982 when referring to Domican, Mr Dowd said:

No inquiry has yet been established to look into the latest bashing episode involving Alderman Brennan, who was assaulted by Mr Tom Domican, a fine member of the Labor Party, in the presence of Alderman Newman. A complaint was made to the police, and Alderman Brennan was given time to think about it. Of course, when one has someone of the calibre of Tom Domican in a council, . . . one must be wary about the evidence one proposes to give. Obviously intimidation occurred and Alderman Brennan found that it was in his own interests to withdraw the complaint.

That Rosemary Foot could go on with Domican's allegations in the light of that is surprising and disappointing. More importantly, I think it shows just what has happened to the allegations business in the New South Wales Parliament where anything goes and any allegation is capable of getting a run, irrespective of how creditable it might be.

I anxiously await the publication of the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. I will respond to no more of Domican's personal attacks on me at any time until that report has been released. I suggest that all members of parliament, indeed all honourable senators who sit opposite in this Parliament and members of the Opposition in the New South Wales Parliament, would do well to wait for the release of the report before they engage in giving Domican any more of the publicity that he so craves and loves or the credibility that he could never have.

On that score I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald. When one looks at the Herald's front page on Friday, 24 February, it would seem that Domican was being glorified. If honourable senators read this paragraph that I am now about to read in conjunction with what had been said in other Herald articles, which I read a little earlier, they will see that at least in 1982 the Sydney Morning Herald had no doubt whatsoever as to who were the villains in the Marrickville piece. They regarded Domican, and said so directly, as the cause of the problem. In an editorial on 13 December 1982, the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Labor's problems at Marrickville will not be resolved simply by the dismissal of the council or a few aldermen. The Labor Party must take action to rid itself of elements that dominate the Labor machine in that area.

We took that action. We rid ourselves of the elements in the area. For our pains it would now seem that the victims are being made to look like the villians. Anyone who goes through the evidence of 1982 can come to only one conclusion; that is, while the decision to rid ourselves of thugs and hoodlums may have come too late, it did come. The two programs on Nationwide on the subject leave me almost speechless. I will read to honourable senators what Richard Carleton failed to read out on a program on the ABC last Friday night, 24 February.

If one looks at the further aspect of Rosemary Foot's allegations, that is, that Warren Anderson was promised favours by me and was to receive preferential treatment, with the exception of once making an appointment for him to see Alderman Harrison-I might say, in Mr Anderson's defence, that that is my recollection; he does not think that I did that, but at the back of my mind I recall that I did ring Harrison for him once to make an appointment-I have never spoken to an alderman, councillor, council or shire employee about any one of Warren Anderson's 23 developments that he has so far been involved with in New South Wales. I invite members of the Press and members of the Opposition to try to find somebody.

Let us look at Rosemary Foot's allegations about Labor dominated councils giving Warren Anderson preference. Let us go through the list of his developments in New South Wales, because it makes fascinating reading. First off , out of 23 developments he has undertaken only six involved rezonings. I will get to those rezonings in a moment. The other developments include: One at Campbelltown, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Forster, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Castlehill, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Armidale, a non- Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Hornsby, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Liverpool, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; at Katoomba, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned; and at Wagga, a non-Labor council, where he bought land already zoned. The Labor council areas include: Randwick, where he bought land already zoned; two developments at Blacktown, at Kings Langley and Plumpton , where he bought land already zoned; at Fairfield where he bought land already zoned; and at Marrickville, where he bought land already zoned. In three other councils where Labor had 50 per cent of the aldermen but did have the Mayors, so presumably they had a casting vote, he had two developments in the Sutherland Shire, at Engadine and Sylvania, where he bought land already zoned; one at Bondi Junction in the Waverley Council area, where he bought land already zoned; and one at Ashfield, where he bought land already zoned.

Let us look at the rezonings, the ones that people look at to see what might happen which could be wrong. There were six rezonings in all, five in non-Labor council areas and one only in a Labor council area. That rezoning has cost him the most money and threatens to cost him very much more. Let us look at those zonings. Firstly, there is one at Bowral, where most of the site was already zoned as commercial, but a part of it had to be rezoned. That part was owned by that well-known troublesome body of never-do-wells, the Salvation Army. The same happened in Goulburn, where part of the development was owned by another group of people that one has to look at closely, that is, the Uniting Church in Australia. In Woy Woy and Erina, two developments in the Gosford Council area, a non-Labor controlled council, the land purchased was already mooted to be in an exhibited plan to be rezoned, and indeed that is what happened. In Tamworth, where he bought a convent school from the Catholic Church, part of that site had to be rezoned as well. That left Woonona in the Wollongong Council area.

I think that something should be said about Woonona, perhaps not all of which may have been said by Neville Wran today and which may really nail forever any thought that Warren Anderson was given preferential treatment. Warren Anderson owned a zoned site at Bulli. He was asked by the council not to build there because it would tend to drag people away from the Woonona shopping centre. Instead the council asked him to develop something inside the shopping centre. Anderson agreed. As part of that deal he paid the council $1m to develop a soccer oval, plus $400,000 to relocate a council depot and purchase part of the site from the council as well. He followed the Department of Environment and Planning directives and he followed the council's directives. But the Land and Environment Court invalidated the zoning. After two years and several court appearances, Warren Anderson has still been unable to develop the site at Woonona or Marrickville and has briefed Queen's Counsel to look at the prospect of suing the Government for its failure to act and its failure to prevent a situation where he loses money-it could be up to $13m-simply because he followed the directives of the Department of Environment and Planning and the directives of the Wollongong Council.

If one looks at Marrickville, one sees yet another situation when Warren Anderson, far from being advantaged, has been grieviously mishandled by the Department of Environment and Planning. He had a site at St Peters-the old brick pits site-which had been already zoned. The Department of Environment and Planning wanted it for a bicentennial park, so it asked him not to build there. It asked him to move further up into the main shopping area of Newtown. He said: 'That is fair enough. I will hand over my contracts to buy the site at St Peters . I will go to Newtown'. So he spent $9m to buy a property in Alice Street, Newtown. However, the Council refused to agree to a rezoning, even though the Department of Environment and Planning would agree, and the dispute between the Department and the Council went on for some time.

In the meantime, in this same Government, I noticed that Eric Bedford was supposed to have been involved in the network of influence. He was the Minister for Planning and Environment at the time. The Minister and the Department approved the zoning of another site only a mile or so away at Marrickville, while leaving Anderson's site unzoned. So he had the worst of all worlds. He had to buy the second site to enable him to still have a chance of building a shopping centre in the area. For that site he had to pay the previous owners $ 500,000 for his trouble, plus the $7m for the land. He then had to sell off the Alice Street properties because they were not rezoned. That took over a year and he suffered a loss of more than $3m. Such are the activities of a man allegedly advantaged and given preferential and special treatment by the New South Wales Government. This man, Warren Anderson, has so far spent $500m in developments in New South Wales and employed 12,000 people in the process. State Government actions have cost him a fortune and placed very much more of his money at risk. Yet we still hear an allegation of preferential treatment.

Where would the Hermitage land rate, therefore, in this man's priorities? Whether the price was $145,000 or $600,000, it would rate nowhere to a man who was standing to lose as much money as he does because of State Government actions. In regard to the Hermitage land, honourable senators should remember that it cannot be valued as if it were the average block in a subdivision. It has no opportunity value. There is no access, not even for a four-wheel drive vehicle, let alone a family sedan. It is 66 metres long, 6 metres wide at one end and 3 metres wide at the other. It is not what one would call an average building block. At its widest it is 13 metres. I wonder why some of these facts are not stated.

For all of the muck raking that has gone on, Warren Anderson is talking about pulling out of New South Wales. Already, he told me that he has cancelled participation in $200m worth of further projects. A few of the places mentioned were Maitland, Wallsend, Wangi, North Sydney and an office block at the corner of King and George Streets. He intends only to complete those projects which are well down the line towards completion. It is a great tragedy that this should occur. It has been brought about by Rosemary Foot, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, being prepared to accept the totally unsubstantiated evidence of a man like Domican who has no credibility, and to slur Anderson, a man who has done so much good for New South Wales. He did not deserve to be repaid like that. He has been done a monstrous injustice. I hope, in light of all the evidence presented here tonight and in the New South Wales Parliament today, that Mrs Foot will show just one scintilla of decency and offer him the apology that he deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a very busy Question Time in the Senate today. I was one of the many honourable senators who was unable to ask questions. I take the opportunity now to read my question, which was to have been directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, representing the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley). My question would have referred the Minister to an article published in the Northern Territory News on 8 February 1984 which quoted a spokesperson for the Aviation Minister as saying that several hundred thousand dollars would be spent on the interim upgrading at Darwin Airport. I would have asked whether the report was correct and, if so, exactly how much would have been reallocated to the interim upgrading; what areas of the airport would be upgraded; what nature of work would be carried out; and finally, when would it be anticipated that the upgrading work would begin. I wish to ask that question because in an article in the Northern Territory News on 8 February 1984 Mr Beazley is reported to have said, in a statement in regard to the interim upgrading plan for Darwin Airport:

SPEECH.PARA: Several hundred thousand dollars interim upgrading will be undertaken at the Darwin Airport.
A spokesman for the Federal Aviation Minister, Mr Kim Beazley, said plans were under consideration but it was not yet known which areas would be worked on.

The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has looked at the proposal for a new international terminal building at Darwin at a cost of some $98m. We now await the recommendations of that Committee in its report to Parliament. But a very serious problem exists in Darwin. The fact is that if the international airport is to be constructed, it will not be completed before about five years. At the moment the facilities for processing overseas visitors is, without exaggeration, so appalling that I would say they are inferior to most Third World countries. Overseas visitors are severely jeopardised in Darwin and will continue to be so until the terminal is completed. Despite the efforts of Customs on the ground at Darwin to humanise the processing of inbound travellers , they are still herded through health and Customs checks under most deplorable conditions. In fact, the Customs area in which these people are herded measures only 16 metres square. Yet up to 200 men, women and children are held in that area for anything up to 45 minutes. This occurs in the early hours of the morning, at 2 o'clock or 3 o'clock in the morning. The building is not airconditioned. It is an old war-time hangar which was damaged during the war. Money has been spent on it occasionally to upgrade it to a minimal airport facility.

The travellers are held in this area for up to 45 minutes while their luggage is being unloaded from the aircraft and brought to an area next to the travellers' holding room. The roller doors are then lifted and there is bedlam as people fight their way to their luggage. In some cases it can take up to two hours before the traveller has been through Customs, collected his luggage and fought his way out to the fresh air. It is a most deplorable situation. The purpose of the question which I wanted to ask today was to highlight the situation and endeavour to have the Minister for Aviation proceed with the upgrading plan so that a minimum amount of money could be spent at least to bring the facilities at Darwin Airport to such a condition that people could pass through and be serviced in some reasonable manner until the new airport is constructed.

I turn briefly to another matter. Today I was very concerned to hear a question and answer in the Senate. The question came from Senator Macklin, of the Australian Democrats, and was addressed to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), regarding the Northern Territory Criminal Code. I believe that the situation is getting out of hand. I think a confrontation is developing when there should be no confrontation. I refer briefly to the situation which occurred last December. In answer to a question Senator Gareth Evans read out a letter on 19 November addressed to the Honourable Paul Everingham. The letter was from the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, who outlined the problems that the Federal Government foresaw in the Criminal Code. This letter was incorporated in Hansard.

On 15 December Mr Paul Everingham was at Parliament House and delivered to the Prime Minister a letter in very moderate language answering the criticisms, as the Prime Minister saw them, regarding the Northern Territory Criminal Code. In that letter Mr Everingham clearly indicated that the matter was open for further discussion. When I incorporated that letter in the Senate Hansard of 15 December I read the part which stated:
At the outset let me say that I hope my letter will not be the end to discussions between our Governments if you consider there are areas of concern.
At the end of the letter Mr Everingham stated:

As stated at the outset, I would not like this to be an end to our discussions on this matter if your concerns remain . . . In the meantime, a very careful watch will be kept and if anomalies are discovered proper use will be made of the executive discretion to remove any possibility of injustice arising from them.

Also at this time the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, indicated his disquiet regarding the matter. I asked questions of him in Question Time. I think it was just a little later at the end of Question Time that the Attorney- General said that he would make no more public comment on the matter as he would be receiving respresentations from a Mr Des Sturgess, a solicitor who was the architect of the Northern Territory Criminal Code. He had agreed that he would see Mr Sturgess to discuss overcoming the possible problems that Senator Gareth Evans saw. We have now reached a rather silly situation. Today in answer to a question Senator Evans said:

These matters have now been the subject of a further letter from the Prime Minister to the Northern Territory Chief Minister. I am not sure whether it is accurate to say the Prime Minister has been rebuffed once again because I think the letter has been sent only in the last 24 hours or so.

That is quite correct. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has waited more than 2 1/2 months now for some response from the Federal Government which has now been sent, probably today or yesterday, couched, I suggest, in terms, it would appear to bring about further confrontation. As I said before it is a most serious matter. Today I received a copy of a telex to the Prime Minister from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Paul Everingham. He said:
. . . Despite the fact that the code has now been operational since January 1 this year, and despite the fact that I have had not further response to my letter to you of December last.
That was when he was seeking some response from the Federal Government in an endeavour to have an exchange of views and to overcome the problem. Mr Everingham continued:

I myself, my Attorney-General, our law officers and Mr Sturgess can make ourselves available to meet you and your Attorney-General at any time of your convenience. I am most anxious to head off any confrontation in this matter and I don't believe anything can be gained by your acting precipitately. The Criminal Code has been passed into law by a democratically elected government after an exhaustive process of consultation. It was raised as an issue in the recent Northern Territory election by yourself and the Territory Opposition. The results speak for themselves.

I hope that before the Federal Government takes any action in Parliament the matter will be discussed government to government. I think it would be most unfortunate if we saw intervention by the Federal Government in the affairs of the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory has now been granted responsible self-government by enactment of the Federal Government. I suggest that even though the Federal Government has the ability to intervene in the affairs of the Northern Territory in the present circumstances it would be most improper. Once again I ask the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, before he flies off on another tangent, whether he would please receive representations from the Northern Territory Government and Mr Des Sturgess, the architect of this Criminal Code, so he can understand what the situation is all about. I suggest that there is good reason for the code. I recall of course that the crime rate in the Northern Territory for serious crime, whether it be rape, murder, bashings and so on, is 400 to 500 per cent higher than the national average. It was implied in the question asked today by Senator Macklin that this was a disadvantage to the Aboriginal people. Does he not realise that it is mainly the Aboriginal people who are the victims? Therefore, how can they be disadvantaged? This code will protect the Aboriginal people. There is far too much violence in the Northern Territory. As I said before it is the Aboriginal people themselves who are the victims. Murder and rape are increasing. I would expect this code to alleviate the situation. I say no more for the moment except that I believe the situation is now quite serious. There are increasing reports in the media as to the proposed action of the Federal Government. It has been said that Cabinet will discuss the matter next week. I hope that if the report is accurate Cabinet will take a reasoned, sensible attitude to the whole situation and at least accept the request by the Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, that he with his officers of law be received here in Canberra so the matter can be thrashed out properly. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the telex I referred to earlier .
Leave granted.

BCA AA36733
SENOPP AA62659
STBY BCAST 85356 CLG
FOR THE ATTENTION OF:
Senator Don Chipp
Senator Peter Durack
Senator Brian Harradine
Senator Bernie Kilgariff
Mr Andrew Peacock, M.P.

Set out below is telex sent to the Prime Minister a.m. today re. the Northern Territory Criminal Code for your information.
To: The Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, A.C., M.P., Prime Minister
From: The Hon. P. A. E. Everingham, M.L.A., Chief Minister of the Northern Territory
CC: Attorney-General Senator G. Evans
Dear Prime Minister,

I continue to hear media reports that your government in some way intends to interfere with the due administration of the Northern Territory Criminal Code. This is despite the fact that the code has now been operational since January 1 this year, and despite the fact that I have had no further response to my letter to you of December last.
It is difficult for me to conceive that you or your government would contemplate the grave breach of constitutional convention to which your interference with the Criminal Code would amount.
You of all people should be aware of the attitude of many Australians and of your Party to the last intervention by a Governor-General into matters politic and decreed by convention.

As I say the Criminal Code has now been in operation two months. This is far too soon to determine its effectiveness but obviously after twelve months or so of its operation the Northern Territory government is going to have to review whether it is operating fairly and effectively. This has always been our intention and has been stated in the past.

It is a matter of some regret to me that your Attorney-General, Senator Evans, did not himself take the opportunity of a briefing from Mr Des Sturgess, our principal adviser and draftsman of the code, but delegated one of his officers for this task. Even at this late stage I would still be happy to meet with Senator Evans and his officers to discuss any lingering concerns he may have. I do reiterate however the following points:
Unsworn statements by the accused from the dock have been abolished in Western Australia, and Queensland, New Zealand and many other British jurisdictions.
A sub committee of the Law Council of Australia has endorsed the terrorism provisions contained in the code.

Provisions relating to intoxication are designed to take account of the shortcomings in O'Connor's case, shortcomings foreseen by the High Court and for which the court suggested legislative amendment. Our law should be compared with that applicable in the code States of Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania .
I myself, my Attorney-General, our law officers and Mr Sturgess can make ourselves available to meet you and your Attorney-General at any time of your convenience.

I am most anxious to head off any confrontation in this matter and I don't believe anything can be gained by your acting precipitately. The Criminal Code has been passed into law by a democratically elected government after an exhaustive process of consultation. It was raised as an issue in the recent Northern Territory election by yourself and the Territory Opposition. The results speak for themselves.

As I indicated earlier, the Northern Territory will be reviewing the operations of the code after twelve months or earlier if it should prove necessary. We have not rejected or refused consultation in this matter. Indeed I am seeking discussions. I await what I hope will be a constructive response from you.
Your Sincerely,
Paul Everingham

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff raised on the adjournment tonight two matters of concern to him. The first matter relates to the proposed improvement to Darwin Airport. I will make sure my colleague the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) responds to that. Senator Kilgariff's then expressed his concern about the Federal Government's response to the proposed Northern Territory Criminal Code. I will make sure the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is made aware of those matters and responds to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Senator Kilgariff's remarks while I was sitting in my room. I am indebted to him for his contribution to the debate. I can assure him that the kinds of noises he is making have been present to my ears for the duration of this exercise. In particular, the propositions likely to be advanced by Mr Sturgess, as the primary architect of the legislation, have been the subject of very extensive discussions between Mr Sturgess and an officer of my Department who has made trips to the Northern Territory for the express purpose of satisfying himself and accordingly reporting to me that there is a real problem in this area. The Government believes there are real problems with this legislation, as I said at Question Time today. I regret that the initial response from Mr Everingham does not seem to be one that acknowledges their existence. Accordingly, it may be necessary for the Government now to consider moving to the next inevitable stage of this process. We will do so unhappily, but the attitude of the Northern Territory Government seems to leave us little choice.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much of the additional $21m allocated for children's services in the Budget will be expended on 'after school care centres'.
(2) What will be the extent of the Government's assistance in the provision of staff and equipment for these centres if funds are to be expended.
(3) Will funds become available this financial year; if so, what criteria will be used in determining which centres receive funding priority.
(4) Are the 'after school care centres' at Ryde Primary School and Eden Park Industrial Estate in Sydney being considered for funding in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No specific amount has been allocated to out of school hours care projects from the additional $21m allocated to the children's services program in the 1983-84 Budget.

(2) The policy and funding arrangements relating to the provision of outside school hours care services are currently being reviewed in consultation with community groups and service operators. Under the present arrangements, new services are provided with an equipment grant and recurrent assistance for approved staff salaries and associated costs according to a formula which takes account of numbers of children, and hours of operation. Usually an equipment grant of $500 is provided to a service on establishment but this may vary dependent on the size of the service.

As an interim measure I have recently approved a 15 per cent increase to all out of school hours care services. In addition I have approved 39 new services at the increased level of funding. Included in the new services approved are the Ryde Primary School and the Eden Park Industrial Estate in Sydney which have been approved for equipment grants and recurrent funding from 1 July 1983.

(3) Yes. Applications are ranked according to the distribution of other services, priorities of need, the type and quality of the service to be provided and the relative cost of the service in terms of the number of children who would benefit.
(4) See 2 above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government planning to set up an office of aged care.
(2) Are the State governments likely to set up similar offices; if so, what functions will these offices perform, and when will they be operational.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, no decision has yet been taken as to where the office will be located.
(2) The Government is aware of two proposals to set up similar offices.

The Premier of New South Wales advised the Prime Minister and myself on 23 September 1983 that his Government proposes to establish an office of aged services in New South Wales. The functions of this Office are listed as:
(a) To liaise with Government departments and authorities for the co-ordination of programmes affecting the ageing and to monitor the functioning of such programmes.
(b) To provide policy advice to the Government on matters affecting aged persons.
(c) To initiate or assist development of policy/programme to advance the quality of services provided for aged persons.
(d) To liaise with and provide support for community-based aged persons/service organisations.
(e) To provide a co-ordinated information service on aged related matters.
(f) To foster the appointment of aged persons to Government boards and commissions where their decisions affect aged persons.
(g) To co-operate with local government and Federal Government authorities on aged related issues.
(h) To co-ordinate government sponsored senior citizens' week and other programmes initiated by the Premier, for aged persons
There was no indication from the New South Wales Government when the office would be operational.
I understand that the South Australian Government also proposes to establish a commission of aged care.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the reason for disregarding disability pensions for the purpose of the income test for unemployment sickness benefit (see answer to Question No. 81 , Hansard, page 1278).
(2) Why does a similar situation not prevail for other social security pensions and benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Disability (war) pensions have not been taken into account as income for unemployment and sickness benefit purposes, other than where paid for the same disability as sickness benefit, since 1950. The reason for disregarding such pensions at that time seems to have been the strict income test then applicable which reduced unemployment and sickness benefit by the full amount of any income over $2 per week and thus, in effect, significantly negated the payment of this form of compensation.

(2) Disability pensions are not disregarded in the legislation for other social security pensions because of the more liberal income test applying. A married couple may have income of up to $50 per week before there is any reduction in pension. Moreover, there would be a very substantial additional cost if disability pensions were disregarded for all social security purposes and other areas of need are seen as having a higher welfare priority at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a study conducted by British doctors reported in the Lancet in April 1983 which concluded that a distance of 10,000 metres away from the hypocentre of an atomic explosion is not safe and that even minute doses of radiation can be harmful.

(2) Is the Minister also aware of determinations given by the Repatriation Board claiming that unless the applicant was within 0 to 10,000 metres from the hypocentre of an atomic explosion, then it would be difficult to relate such an incident to the applicant's present condition.
(3) Is the Minister also aware that the United States has sent doctors to Japan to study the effects of radiation and the clinical records of those who suffered in the two atomic explosions.
(4) Have Australian doctors been properly trained in the effects of radiation; if not, will the Government take similar action to that of the United States to ensure that the situation is rectified.
(5) When will the study into the present health of those ex-servicemen who were involved in the British nuclear tests conducted in Australia during the 1950's be completed and the results tabled.

(6) Will the Minister take steps to defer further assessment of nuclear veterans who have applied for repatriation benefits until the results of these studies are known and will he ensure that those who may have been wrongly assessed in the past are reassessed in the light of these results and fairly dealt with.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the Lancet article of 9 April 1983 did not refer to a distance of 10,000 metres away from the hypocentre. Nor did the article come to the conclusion canvassed.
(2) The author presented five possible explanations for the observed increase in reticulo-endothelial system neoplasms, either:
(a) far more men at risk than the number considered in the study;
(b) much higher radiation doses than has hitherto been supposed;
(c) much higher cancer risks from smaller doses of radiation than has hitherto been supposed;
(d) exposure of the men to other causes of reticulo-endothelial system neoplasms; or
(e) a combination of some or all of these factors.

2. I am not aware that repatriation boards determine claims on the basis of distance from the hypocentre of an atomic explosion. Distance is only one element among many which would delineate the radiation exposure and risk to a claimant.
3. Yes.

4. In undergraduate medical education all medical students receive some training in the use of radiation for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. Extended coverage of radiation is provided at postgraduate level for appropriate medical specialities. At both the undergraduate and postgraduate level the subject gives some coverage of the effect of ionising radiation on human beings; the Department of Health is not aware of the 'action . . . of the United States' referred to in the question.
5. The report of the study on the health of those Australian ex-servicemen who were involved in the British nuclear tests has been printed and was tabled on 15 December 1983.
6. See (5) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Film Australia been commissioned to 'produce a film for national and possibly international distribution putting the facts on kangaroos'; if so, who has commissioned the film and who will be bearing the costs of it.
(2) Have any instructions been given to Film Australia by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, his Department or the person/s commissioning the film, concerning the contents of the film.

(3) Is it proposed that when the film is completed it will be shown, or promoted in any way, by the Federal Government or any of its departments in such a way that viewers may be led to believe that the views expressed in the film are those of the Australian Government; if so, what will be the general nature of the views to be expressed in the film.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question: (1) Yes, Film Australia has been commissioned by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to make a film on kangaroos. The cost of the film will be met by the Service.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has provided a brief to Film Australia which suggests the aim of the film should be to inform the public about the conservation status of various species of kangaroos, and to discuss the aims, procedures and effects of kangaroo harvesting.

(3) Film Australia has been asked that the film present to the general public the widest possible range of views on the place of kangaroos in our culture, their current status in the environment and the desirability or otherwise of kangaroo harvesting. Current proposals are for the film to contain segments showing the aesthetic aspects of kangaroos, the views of graziers and farmers, the animal protectionists' view of kangaroos as needing complete protection, the industry view of kangaroos as sources of income and the role of wildlife authorities.
Distribution and promotion of the film will rest largely with Film Australia. However, the intention is that the film be shown on television.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government taken any decision to declare the second stage of the Kakadu National Park; if not, at what stage has the Government's consideration of this matter reached.

(2) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the concern of the Northern Territory Government that any move to declare the second stage without provision for the excision of the Koongarra and Jabiluka uranium deposits will deprive the nation of billions of dollars in export income, Aboriginal communities of millions of dollars in royalties and equity returns and thousands of new jobs which would flow from the development of these reserves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An announcement that the Federal Government has decided to declare Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park was made by the Prime Minister on 18 November 1983.

(2) Jabiluka and Koongarra have not been included in the park because ownership of those areas is not vested in the Commonwealth. The Government has indicated that it will have discussions with interested parties concerning the question of inclusion of those areas in the park.

It is the Commonwealth's view that development of appropriate visitor facilities in Kakadu National Park will generate a major long term increase in job opportunities and increase significantly revenue to the Northern Territory. Kakadu National Park is already a major tourist attraction, and the proposed development will need to be undertaken in such a way as to ensure the protection of the natural and cultural values of the park and be sensitive to Aboriginal interests. These matters will be taken up in discussions between the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Northern Territory Government and Aboriginal groups.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did information disseminated by the Australian Government in the United States prior to the commencement of the public hearings in Washington into the delisting of the three kangaroo species from the United States threatened species list, on 6 June 1983, seriously mislead the United States Government into believing that the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 and the national kangaroo management programme were both legally enforceable.

(2) Did the United States make it clear during these hearings on 6 June that the legal enforceability of the Act and the management programme were important to the delisting decision, and did the official Australian Government representative testify that the Act would be proclaimed in the near future.

(3) Did the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment commit the Australian Government to establishing a national kangaroo monitoring unit to assess population trends following the hearings. Did the Australian Embassy in Washington, in spite of the abovementioned undertakings, recently write to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service stating that no firm date could be given for either the proclamation of the Act or the establishment of the monitoring unit, and does the Australian Government consider that the United States has already received sufficient data on kangaroo management to make a decision on the delisting proposal.

(4) On what date will the Act be proclaimed, in light of the importance given by the United States to the legal enforceability of the Wildlife Protection ( Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982; and if this is not known, what are the reasons for the delay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Australian Government made two major submissions to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service prior to the 6 June hearings. The first submission, dated 10 November 1982, stated that the Wildlife Protection ( Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1982 was introduced into Federal Parliament on 6 May 1982. No date for passage of the Bill was suggested. This submission included, as an appendix, a copy of the national kangaroo management program. The status of this program is made clear in section 3 (Implementation) which lists issues which should be taken into account by Australian wildlife authorities in implementing agreed management objectives.

In a second submission dated 1 June 1983, the Government stated that the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 had been passed by the Parliament and was awaiting proclamation. At the hearing on 6 June 1983, the Australian Government representatives made it clear that this remained the position.

(2) The United States did not express any views at the hearing regarding the importance of the legal enforceability of the Wildlife Protection Act or the national kangaroo management program to the delisting proposal.

In respect of the Wildlife Protection Act, the Australian Government representative at the hearing indicated that as soon as minor adminstrative details and staffing concerns had been dealt with, including the finalization of the Regulations, the Act would be proclaimed.
(3) The Governor-General's speech on 21 April 1983 gave a commitment to establish a national kangaroo monitoring unit.

The Australian Embassy in Washington wrote to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on 4 October 1983 stating that no firm date could be given for the proclamation of the Act or for the monitoring unit; however, since that time , action has been taken to recruit staff for the establishment of the monitoring unit.

The Australian Government considers that sufficient information on kangaroo management has been provided to enable a decision to be made on the delisting proposal. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service, in the Federal Register of 8 April 1983, notified that it had received sufficient data to warrant removal of the Red, Eastern Grey and Western Grey from its classification as endangered and indicated its proposal to delist these kangaroos.
(4) I am unable to provide a date of proclamation for the Act as the drafting of regulations, including provisions relating to financial aspects, are yet to be finalised.

Discussions regarding enforcement and other adminstrative matters under the Act are continuing between the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Australian Customs Service. Necessary discussions are also being undertaken with the States.
I expect to be in a position to make an announcement regarding proclamation in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 2 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much funding has been allocated to the Department of Trade's consulting services feasibility study fund-CSFSF-for each year since its inception in 1973.
(2) What are the details for each year, of any unused allocation of CSFSF funds .
(3) Has the allocation of funds been fully utilised in every year since 1973; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) No. During its first years of operation from 1973-74 to 1974-75 the fund failed to attract the level of interest from Australian consultants that was expected. Initially the operational guidelines were very restrictive and it was the Department's responsibility to identify suitable CSFSF studies and to select suitable firms to undertake these studies. This proved to be unsatisfactory from the consultants' point of view.

Effective operation of the fund was suspended from 1976-77 and 1977-78 as a result of Government directives on limiting expenditures. No new projects were undertaken during this period. In 1978-79 the guidelines were revised and consultants were allowed to identify and introduce projects for funding in contrast to the earlier system of Government initiated studies.

When administering a scheme of this nature advance commitments can only be entered into to the extent of funds appropriated in the Budget. Consequently any cancellation or deferral by the recipient country, particularly if late in the financial year, can result in underexpenditure.

The operating guidelines are currently being reviewed in consultation with the Australian Professional Consultants Council to further improve the fund's effectiveness to assist Australian consultants obtaining overseas contracts. With projects presently under consideration the CSFSF is likely to be fully utilised this financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why are people receiving unemployment services not eligible for rental subsidy.
(2) Is the Minister for Social Security aware of the hardship suffered in the absence of a rental subsidy by people who experience long periods of unemployment and also rental accommodation.
(3) Will the Minister investigate the area of rental subsidies to ensure that people on unemployment benefits are not disadvantaged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Social Security Act, entitlement to a 'rental subsidy' by way of supplementary assistance/supplementary allowance is restricted to pensioners, including supporting parent beneficiaries, and sickness beneficiaries after six weeks on benefit.

(2) and (3) I am aware that in the current economic climate, large numbers of people, including older people, remain unemployed for long periods while renting in the private sector and that these people represent one of the most needy groups in the community. The Government is committed to extending supplementary assistance to unemployment beneficiaries over 18 years after 6 weeks on benefit and to those aged 16 and 17 living away from home. In the last Budget the Government introduced several measures designed to improve the situation of the unemployed but, because of the need for expenditure constraint, these did not include the extension of supplementary assistance to unemployment beneficiaries. The Government will give further consideration to this matter within the context of the future Budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

(2) Does this number of requests and warrants equal that of the previous year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In my answer to a similar question asked by Dr Klugman, House of Representatives, Question No. 164 (Hansard, page 2839, 16 November 1983) I said that, whilst it was appropriate to show publicly the general extent to which the intercept provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act were used, there would be no policy of automatically stating the number of current authorisations whenever asked.
In accordance with that approach, I indicated that the number of warrants presently authorised is of an order of magnitude consistent with the annual average for the period 1974 to 1983, viz, 85.6.

I also said that the Government would give further consideration to the detailed information it may be appropriate to make publicly available in the light of the recommendations, when received, of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-ASIO-hold 'normal registry files' on Australian citizens; if so, how many such files are there.
(2) Will the Attorney-General review this aspect of spying on Australian citizens to ensure that files are not kept on persons who are not a threat to security.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In paragraphs 195 and 196 of Volume 1 of the fourth report of the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security, Mr Justice Hope said:

'195. Not a few members of the public are concerned that ASIO might have a 'file ' about them. Being on ASIO's records is not, and should not be seen as, akin to having a police or criminal record. A very large number of ASIO's files establish that persons are not security risks. (4-68: They include people in vetting categories-people in certain Commonwealth Government employment, and immigrants-of whom ASIO almost certainly have a record.) But apart from this at times important intelligence, ASIO needs a bank of information.'

'196. A requirement that ASIO destroy all records about people whom it has not established to be security risks is not justified. Such a requirement is based on a simplistic idea about the nature, and the difficulty, of ASIO's task. Information cannot be assessed until after it is collected. Apparently innocent information about people might, after the addition of other information, assume a different appearance. The reverse can also happen. However, ASIO does hold many records which are not, or are not now, of actual or potential security relevance. As resources allow, these records should be destroyed. I have been told by the Director-General that a start has already been made.'
I am informed that there are information management practices employed by ASIO whereby files are reviewed and, where appropriate, destroyed.
Information management within ASIO is a matter that I expect will be examined by the current Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.
I do not think it is appropriate for statistics of ASIO file holdings to be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The numbers of full-time staff in the Australian Public Service increased in each of the years 1980, 1981 and 1982, and have increased in the nine months to end-September 1983, as follows:
Full-time Staff in the Australian Public Service (excluding Parliamentary Departments)
Increase

It is not possible to accurately measure changes in the total workload of the Service. Not all areas are amenable to precise measurement of workload and workload changes may vary markedly between departments and programs within departments. However, departments are expected to support requests for additional staffing with any workload and performance indicators that are available.

The Government proposes to introduce a system of human resource budgeting as part of its Public Service reform measures. The steps to be taken in introducing this system have been published in the White Paper on the Reform of the Australian Public Service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the British Health and Safety Commission is establishing an asbestos industry working group, comprising representatives of employees, trade unions, health and industrial safety experts and others to study the practical implementation of engineering controls within industries using asbestos and asbestos products, study effective exhaust ventilation methods, the cleaning of premises and plant, the use of respirators and protective clothing for workers handling asbestos or asbestos products as well as safety training for management and workers.

(2) Does the Minister foresee a need for a similar asbestos industry working group in Australia; if so, will the Federal Government initiate discussions with the appropriate parties with a view to reducing the hazards associated with the handling and use of asbestos and asbestos products in the Australian context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government recognises the importance and seriousness of the asbestos problem. In a joint Press statement with my colleague the Minister for Territories and Local Government I advised that priority would be given to the development of national standards and guidelines for the safe treatment and handling of asbestos. Such guidelines will be developed by the proposed tripartite National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, details of which were conveyed to the Parliament in my statement of 10 November.

Pending the establishment of that Commission, the newly formed National Consultative Committee on Occupational Health and Safety has established a working party to consider the problem of non-occupational exposure to asbestos. This will require that acceptable exposure levels be determined for working environments other than those related to the asbestos industry.

With regard to occupational exposure, it should be noted that Australia has one of the most stringent exposure standards in the world. In addition these are reviewed from time to time by the National Health and Medical Research Council.

While no decision has been taken regarding an asbestos industry working group similar to that established by the British Health and Safety Commission, I am confident that the initiatives I have announced concerning the establishment of a working group under the auspices of the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Health and Safety will ensure that Australia remains amongst the world's leaders in controlling asbestos hazards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Resources and Energy acknowledge the necessity for compensation to be paid to (a) the mining companies involved, which have, in good faith, spent millions of dollars in carrying out the Government's requirements for development of the uranium industry and to (b) the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land, who have given their permission for mining to be undertaken and who stand to lose some $200m if it is not, in view of the Press conference held by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, last Tuesday, at which he said he had instructed the Territory's Co-ordinator General to look into the question of compensation for the Territory if the future development of the uranium industry is stopped, and the statement by the Director of the Northern Land Council, Wesley Lanhupuy, on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's After 8 program in Darwin on 3 November 1983 when he said there is no doubt the Council could be approaching the Federal Government on the compensation issue.
(2) Does the Minister acknowledge that, no matter what amount the Government may settle on, compensation for the Northern Territory could not make up for the loss of the uranium industry.
(3) Will the Government review the decision and allow the development of the uranium industry in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The Government is advised that it has no legal obligation to pay compensation arising out of these matters. I point out that the decision taken in respect of existing mines in the Northern Territory provides a basis for maintaining development and revenue for the Northern Territory and employment and income for the relevant Aboriginal communities.

The Government envisages that the foreshadowed expansion of visitor facilities in the Kakadu National Park will generate a major expansion of economic and employment opportunities in the region. However, I note that during the recent Northern Territory election campaign the Country Liberal Party distributed a leaflet, bearing the photograph and name of the Chief Minister, which criticised development proposals made by the Labor Party as follows: 'Big numbers of tourists the Labor Party is planning to put in big hotels in the park under Balanda control will destroy Aboriginal self-determination and take away their control of the land.' This statement indicates that the Northern Territory Government is opposed to the proposed Kakadu tourist developments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the mechanical problems which delayed the departure of Qantas flights from Brisbane airport on 26 January 1983 and 31 August 1983 and what were the details in relation to the factors which caused the refuelling of the Trans Australia Airline flight on 27 May 1983 (see Answer to Question No. 290, Hansard , 8 November 1983, page 2324).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 26 January 1983 the Qantas flight was delayed by a thrust reverse defect on No. 2 engine.
On 31 August 1983 the Qantas flight was delayed by a leading edge flap defect.

On 27 May 1983 bad weather at Brisbane required the carriage of fuel for flight to an alternate aerodrome. The TAA flight was unable to carry sufficient fuel for the flight from Canberra to Brisbane because of the number of passengers required to be uplifted. A refuelling stop was therefore necessary at Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 19 November 1983:

(2) Is the Government going to declare the area known as Kakadu 2 in its entirety as a national park, locking in once and for all the many minerals in this highly mineralised area, or will it accede to the Northern Territory request that a conservation area of not more than 50 per cent be declared for a predetermined period to allow a national stocktake of the resources of this area .
(3) Does the Government expect that if this action is not taken uranium and other minerals, such as gold and copper, will be locked in permanently with no further development.

This statement indicates that the Northern Territory Government is opposed to the proposed Kakadu tourist developments.
