TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will any Australian television network broadcast the United States-produced television film depicting the effects of nuclear war, The Day After.
(2) Will the Minister for Communications request the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to show the film in prime time nationally and with adequate publicity.
(3) Will the Minister indicate the reasons if the film is not to be shown in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation endeavoured to purchase The Day After but television rights had already been sold to the Australian commercial television network Channel 10. Cinema rights for Australia are held by Roadshow Distributors Pty Ltd which plans to commence box office sales in February 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 30 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present system of quarantine on exotic live fish.
(2) Is the present system adequate to stop diseases such as cholera and parasites such as water lice and snail eggs entering Australia via imported pet fish and polluting our waterways.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Proclamation 112A, gazetted in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S 282 of 14 November 1983, places controls upon the exporters of live fish and the conditions under which live fish are exported to Australia. A visual inspection is carried out at all ports of entry to ensure that no prohibited species are brought in along with snails, plant material and obviously diseased specimens. Only premises meeting our requirements regarding hygiene, water quality, handling and packaging facilities have been issued with a certificate to export. Any adverse reports from the quarantine inspectors are followed up and a warning issued that such practices may lead to the certificate being revoked.

(2) No. To stop such diseases and pests we need proper Australian quarantine facilities where fish can be held for 14 days and the water in which the fish have been kept must be sterilised and disposed of safely. The industry has been advised of our intent to introduce regulations to include such requirements to be effective from 1 March 1984. Australian importers are currently building import premises to meet the new requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 30 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have works to accommodate domestic wide bodied aircraft at Adelaide Airport been completed; if not, what is the timetable for finalising these works.

(2) Will the Minister for Aviation obtain information from Ansett Airlines of Australia about when regular scheduled services operated by Boeing 767 wide bodied aircraft will commence to Adelaide, in view of the fact that Adelaide is the only mainland State capital not served by these aircraft.
(3) What are the reasons for Ansett Airlines of Australia not currently operating flights by Boeing 767 aircraft to Adelaide, while Perth and Brisbane are served by such equipment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The works to accommodate domestic wide bodied aircraft at Adelaide Airport were sufficiently advanced to enable operations by these aircraft to commence on 26 November 1982; they have continued on an ad hoc basis since. All major works have now been completed; however, there are a number of minor items still outstanding. These are expected to be finalised this financial year.

(2) The General Manager of Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd has advised that, if there is a recovery in the domestic airline market, it is probable that scheduled Boeing 767 services to Adelaide would be commenced when the company's fifth Boeing 767 is delivered in September 1984.

(3) The General Manager has further advised that Ansett does not operate Boeing 767 aircraft to Adelaide on a regular basis because of the effect that its introduction would have on the frequency of services. There is currently an average of five services a day between Melbourne and Adelaide; if the Boeing 767 were introduced, the average would fall to three a day. It is the company's assessment of the market that frequency of service is preferred above any particular aircraft type. The Boeing 767 is operated to Brisbane because of the much higher traffic densities which support 51 services a week. Boeing 767 operations to Perth are scheduled to offer an increase in capacity when additional frequency of service is not warranted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 1 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Special Minister of State aware that during the Pine Gap Women for Survival Peace Camp a helicopter was regularly hovering over the camp during the day and at night.
(2) Who authorised these flights.

(3) Is it correct that, during night flights, only one red light was operating; if so, was this red light part of any infra-red camera equipment the helicopter might have been carrying so that it could detect people at night without using a spotlight.
(4) Was the helicopter using any lights for navigational purposes; if not, why not.

(5) Is it correct that the word 'Police' appeared on the helicopter but that the identification number was either painted out or was not visible during flights over the camp; if so, was the helicopter in fact a police helicopter; if it was not a police helicopter, to whom did it belong.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that, on the night of 11 November 1983, a helicopter operated over the camp in the course of testing its equipment. This was an inadvertent operation of the aircraft and apologies were tendered to the Police Liaison Collective on the following morning by the Australian Federal Police-AFP-Officer in Charge of police arrangements. All subsequent helicopter operations were confined to the prohibited area or to hinterland patrols well away from the camp . The access road along which the majority of women were camped runs parallel to the perimeter of the prohibited area and at a distance of less than 200 yards. AFP helicopter operations would hence have come within 200 yards of the camp while engaged on protective security missions. The usual operating height at these times was between 400 and 500 feet above ground level.

(2) All operations by the Australian Federal Police helicopter during the period 11 to 23 November 1983 were directed by the AFP Commander, appointed to conduct the special police responses during the period of the Pine Gap demonstrations.

(4) Yes-but with exceptions. As the aircraft may have been placed at risk from projectiles originating from the area of the main gate, the aircraft pilot elected to douse navigation lights where and at those times when he thought himself to be most vulnerable. Airspace in which this decision operated was promulgated as 'Restricted Airspace'. A projectile was in fact discharged from the vicinity of the main gate on the night of 22 November 1983.
The following lights were used to assist the pilot in avoiding hazards:
(a) Hazard lights on artificial structures higher than 50 feet above ground level situated in his area of sortie; and
(b) floodlighting fitted to the aircraft.

(5) The word 'Police' appeared on one of two helicopters used by police at Pine Gap. The one making the inadvertent flight did so at night when its markings would not have been visible to persons on the ground.

One light helicopter was deployed by Northern Territory Police. This had no police identification marking and had no function other than random surveillance within the prohibited area. It is assumed that the question alludes to the helicopter deployed by the AFP.

The word 'Police' appeared on the fuselage of the AFP helicopter in accordance with contemporary obligations for police to be identifiable particularly when requiring members of the public to comply with lawful directions. In this case, lawful directions could be given via the public address system with which the aircraft was fitted.

The aircraft itself was operated by the National Safety Council of Australia of which the AFP is a contributing member. The NSCA is the custodian of a number of important support skills and equipment, including aircraft, for application in emergencies and disasters; hence Australian Federal Police membership.

Authority over tasking of the aircraft was vested with the Australian Federal Police Commander at Pine Gap. The aircraft operation was additionally authenticated by the contractual arrangements made with the NSCA and a procedure which ensured that it was not tasked on operational business without at least one Australian Federal Police officer in the aircraft; more often two.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 1 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the level of the cost benefits pertaining to pre-sale dumping.
(2) Have comparisons of costs of post and pre-sale dumping been made during the last 3 years; if so, what are the details.

(3) Would the difference in costs between the two methods be more than the amounts by which jumbo bales have been discounted, i.e. some 10c to 13c per kilo as indicated by the Australian Wool Processors Council.

(4) Will the Government suggest, if the comparisons of post and pre-sale dumping have not been undertaken, that they be conducted by an international authority on commodity handling so that the entire wool industry will have access to the information.
(5) What action is being taken by the Government to assure our largest overseas buyers that pre-sale dumping will not become widespread so our future trading arrangements will not be jeopardised.

(6) Will the Minister seek the views of the Australian Wool Corporation regarding the commercial risks involved in pre-sale dumped packs at substantially the same price levels as farm bales plus dumping charges.
(7) Will the Government intervene should wool brokers proceed with the installation of further pre-sale dumping arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has to date been no public disclosure of the cost-benefits associated with the commercial introduction of pre-sale dumping of wool in Brisbane in October 1983.

The Australian Wool Corporation has previously undertaken some desk studies which suggest there would be significant net benefits from this system, but these findings could only be substantiated through full-scale commercial trials.

(2) Detailed comparison of post and pre-sale dumping are presently being undertaken by the Australian Wool Corporation, the results of which could determine future reserve price support for wool prepared in a dumped form prior to sale and continued support by Queensland woolgrowers.

(3) Although discounts at auction of 10c to 13c per kilo on jumbo bales may apply on occasion, the Australian Wool Corporation has no evidence to support the view they are that high consistently, or on average. A detailed comparative study undertaken by the Corporation in 1980 disclosed average levels of discounts for jumbo bales at that time of 5c to 6c per kilo greasy and offsetting savings to growers of 3c per kilo.

The Australian Wool Corporation considers it is unlikely that the difference in costs between post and pre-sale high density dumping is more than the amounts by which jumbo bales have been discounted.

(4) As I indicated above, a study into the comparative effects of pre-sale dumping on the wool industry is being undertaken by the Australian Wool Corporation on behalf of woolgrowers. The Government believes that the Corporation is fully competent to undertake the study, the results of which will be available to all interested parties in the wool industry.

(5) The pre-sale dumping of wool is essentially a commercial matter which should be resolved between the parties involved, principally woolgrowers, brokers and the buyers. I have, however, been advised that unless the introduction of pre-sale dumping can be justified on commercial grounds in each case it is not likely that the system will be supported by growers or the Australian Wool Corporation through the wool reserve price scheme.

(6) Yes. The Australian Wool Corporation has reported that it recognises that some overseas markets do not support tri-packed bales, while others require only part of their wool in this form. It recognises also that local processors oppose tri-pack wool, and other high density package forms. The Corporation is continuing to monitor the extent of discounting at Brisbane sales as part of its evaluation of the system.

(7) The Corporation has indicated it will not continue reserve price support indefinitely for pre-sale dumped wool unless the system proves its commercial viability and potential net benefit to the wool industry. If this is not achieved, the absence of reserve price support and consequent lack of grower support, could be sufficient to discourage a general movement towards pre-sale dumping without the need for Government intervention.

Further, following representations from the Australian Wool Processors Council, I did write on 12 September 1983 to the principal parties involved in the pre- sale dumping of wool stressing that there should be considerable consultations between appropriate groups in the industry on the effects of the development in Brisbane, and that I would be concerned if there was a move towards pre-sale dumping of wool in other wool selling centres before the evaluation of the development in Brisbane was completed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people in each State have had to supply declaratory certificates of identity in order to receive Australian passports since the implementation of new passport procedures.
(2) How many of these people have received their Australian passports in each State.
(3) How many people are still waiting for their Australian passports in this category in each State.
(4) What is the delay in process in this category in each State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) I take it that the honourable senator is referring to declaratory certificates of citizenship. These certificates are issued to Australian citizens by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are any elements of the Defence Forces keeping surveillance or information on any civilians within Australia or overseas.
(2) For what purpose is the surveillance or information being kept.
(3) Under what supervision is this being done.
(4) Who are the Ministers responsible for any such action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Defence Force does not carry out surveillance of civilians.

There are instances in which Defence Force personnel, notably the Naval Police, Military Police and Air Force Police, are required to investigate civilians. For example, Naval, Military, or Air Force Police are, on rare occasions, called upon to make enquiries of or about civilians as part of investigations of Service personnel or of offences committed on Service premises.

Investigations of this type are conducted to determine whether prima facie evidence exists for proceedings to be instituted by civil authorities where breaches of State or Federal laws occur, and cases are transferred to the appropriate civil authority at the earliest opportunity.

Service intelligence and security staff also collect information concerning applicants for enlistment (that is, civilians) in order to assess their character and general suitability for access to classified information during service. The recruitment process into the Defence Forces requires a degree of investigation to verify background eligibility and stated qualifications of an applicant. Such investigation is done with the written authority of the applicant. Records are maintained on the basis of strict confidentiality and restricted access.
(3) Normal command supervision.
(4) The Minister for Defence has ministerial responsibility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the activities of the Immigration Review Panel, in particular the number of requests for review of decisions by type of review right exercised and the outcomes of such reviews, for example the number or rejections, reversals, confirmations and modifications of decisions.
(2) What is the current size and membership of the Immigration Review Panel.
(3) What is the current average length of time for consideration of individual review cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Immigration Review Panel examines appeals to the Minister against specific categories of adverse decisions made by departmental officers and recommends to the Minister whether he should uphold or vary those decisions.
Panel meetings are held in both Sydney and Melbourne for 2 or 3 days per week.
The specific categories of decisions reviewable are:
(1) Refusal to allow the migrant entry of a relative sponsored or nominated by an Australian citizen or legal permanent resident of Australia.
(2) Refusal to accept migrant entry sponsorship or nomination of a relative overseas by a person who is eligible to sponsor or nominate that relative.
(3) Refusal of permanent residence to a person legally in Australia who is eligible for consideration under the provisions of section 6A of the Migration Act.
(4) Refusal of permanent residences of a person illegally in Australia who is eligible for consideration under the provision of section 6A of the Migration Act.
(5) Refusal to issue a return endorsement to a permanent resident or cancellation of return endorsement held by a permanent resident.
(6) Grant of temporary residence instead of permanent residence to a person arriving in Australia with a migrant visa.
(7) Refusal to extend or cancellation of the temporary entry permit of a person legally in Australia on business, or for pre-arranged medical treatment, or visiting relatives.
(8) Refusal to extend or cancellation of the temporary entry permit of a person legally in Australia with permission to work (excluding entertainers for whom there are separate review arrangements).
(9) Refusal to extend or cancellation of the temporary entry permit of a person legally in Australia as a student.
(10) Refusal to grant citizenship (excluding cases where, because of refusal on security grounds, other review arrangements apply).

(11) An automatic review applies to a person who, having been located as a prohibited immigrant and as such is liable to deportation under section 18 of the Migration Act, is found to be eligible for consideration for resident status under section 6A (1) (b) of the Migration Act by virtue of having an Australian spouse or aged parent or minor child.

(12) An automatic review applies to a person who, having been admitted to Australia on a migrant visa, is subsequently found to be a prohibited immigrant pursuant to section 16 (1) of the Migration Act and is therefore liable to deportation under section 18 of the Act (such a person is required to seek a specially endorsed entry permit as required by section 16 of the Act).
(Note: Where the word 'relative' is used it means a spouse, child, brother, sister, fiance(e), and includes step-children, step-parents, step-brothers and step-sisters.)

(3) The intake of appeals has continued to grow steadily and seems to have peaked at about 150 per week. Through the appointment of a second chairman the number of panels sitting simultaneously was increased from one to two and the number of staff in the Review Branch of the Department which services the Immigration Review Panel has been increased substantially. Nevertheless the time taken for review has continued to increase as the backlog has built up further.

Priority is given to those reviews in which a requirement for urgent treatment has been brought to notice. The average time from lodgement of review application to decision by the Minister is close to 5 months. This includes the time taken for any further correspondence with the applicant, inquiries into the case (often including inquiries overseas), preparation of all necessary papers for the panel and dispatch to panel members for pre-meeting reading, full examination by the panel including any further inquiries directed by the panel, the panel's report to the Minister and subsequent consideration by the Minister.
In a further attempt to reduce the backlog and the average processing time, the Department has recently drawn together a task force which will continue to operate for some months.

I am keeping the review system under observation and will await the report of the Administrative Review Council on the review of adverse decisions under the Migration Act before making decisions on any significant changes to the system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the details of the APTCARE plan which sets out the procedures to be followed in the event of an accident at Lucas Heights Laboratories, referred to in the answer to Question on Notice No. 411 concerning the extent of the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure the health and safety of workers and residents in the surrounding areas of the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (see Hansard, 6 December 1983, pages 3349-50).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: APTCARE (A Plan to Cope with Accidents at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, New South Wales) is a joint emergency plan drawn up by the AAEC and New South Wales authorities to protect the public in the unlikely event of a serious accident at Lucas Heights. The plan consists of procedures to cope with such an accident and the responsibilities for implementation of these procedures. Such a plan is considered prudent for any industrial or technological activity where an accident, no matter how unlikely, could have potential to produce adverse health effects for the public.
I have arranged for copies of an information document setting out a summary of the APTCARE plan to be placed in the Parliamentary Library, where they will be available for examination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total value of Commonwealth subsidies paid in respect of feeder air passenger services in (a) 1981-82 and (b) 1982-83.
(2) What was the total value of subsidies paid in respect of air passenger services in each State and Territory in the above years.
(3) What routes, if any, are subsidised in South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Government currently provides subsidies for air services in three categories:

(i) The Remote Air Services Subsidy Scheme is designed to guarantee a minimum level of service throughout the year to ensure fresh food, other perishables and mail can be delivered to remote communities. The level of service normally considered to be a criterion for eligibility for this scheme is a once weekly service by a small single or twin engined aircraft. As the services currently assisted under the scheme are not commercially viable in their own right, they would not be provided without subsidy.

(ii) The 10 per cent subsidy for fares between Melbourne and Tasmania paid by the Commonwealth to Ansett, Trans-Australia Airlines and East-West Airlines. This subsidy was introduced by the previous Government in April 1981 following an air fare increase granted to Ansett and TAA. The fare increase was associated with revisions to the air fare formulae which resulted in fares on short haul routes such as those between Melbourne and Tasmania, increasing by more than those on the long haul routes. The subsidy was provided so that the increase in Melbourne-Tasmania airline fares paid by travellers would be contained to approximately the national average increase in fares.

(iii) Air travel on services to western Queensland ports is subsidised to enable continued operation of air services currently provided by TAA and Air Queensland, subject to matching subsidy from the Queensland Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report in the Age on Friday 9 December 1983 which cites claims by Dr Kazem Rajavi, a political science professor in Switzerland, that 7,746 people have been executed in Iran since June 1981.

(2) Was the Australian delegation to the United Nations one of the 75 delegations, according to Dr Rajavi, amongst which there was not a major nation willing to put the issue of human rights violations before the United Nations, given the Age report as well as Amnesty International's separate report on atrocities in Iran, and a further report authorised by the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva citing dozens of reports of imprisonment, torture and executions in Iran.

(3) Why does the Australian Government persist in refusing to take vigorous and determined action either unilaterally or in concert, to make known to the Government of Iran that its persistent barbarities are unacceptable to all civilised people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Late in the proceedings of the Third Committee of the recently-concluded session of the United Nations General Assembly-UNGA 38-a group representing an Iranian opposition movement lobbied a number of delegations in an effort to have the Third Committee consider the human rights situation in Iran. The group suggested the terms of a possible draft resolution but delegations decided not to proceed with the draft. I am advised that Western delegations assessed that to have initiated at such a late stage in proceedings a debate on the human rights situation in Iran in response to the initiative of an Iranian opposition group would very likely have had a counter-productive result.

(3) As should be well known, the Australian Government has taken action on a number of occasions, on both a direct bilateral basis and through multilateral channels, to make known to the Government of Iran its concern about the human rights situation in that country. At UNGA 38, in a statement relating to human rights, the Australian representative in the Third Committee expressed Australia 's serious concern over the recurrent reports of violations of human rights in Iran. In addressing this issue the Government has been guided by the need to ensure that its efforts should be as productive as possible and, in particular, should not put at further risk those suffering or under threat of human rights violations. We shall continue to pursue the question of human rights in Iran as opportunities arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Spanish Government announced a slow down of its nuclear power program.
(2) What are the implications of such a slow down.
(3) Will the slow down mean that work will stop or not begin on a number of nuclear plant sites where construction has already begun or been approved.
(4) What is the expected cost to investment of such a slow down.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On 13 October, 1983, the Spanish Government announced that, consistent with the projections of its economic plan, it had decided to 'slow down or paralyse temporarily' a part of the nuclear power program which had been planned under the direction of the previous Government. Nuclear capacity as at 1990 would now be limited to around 7500 MW rather than the 12,500 MW previously planned.

(2) The decision is in line with reduced growth in nuclear and other electricity capacity occurring in other countries. Implications for the Spanish economy include an adverse effect on the balance of payments, as reliance on oil and coal imports would not be reduced to the extent hitherto planned. The slow down in the nuclear power program would also result in a loss of employment opportunities in Spain.

(3) and (4) The slow down means that work will either stop or will not begin on 5 of the 12 nuclear plants already under construction or approved. Although the plants which would be affected have not been specified, the Government has indicated that the decision will represent a cost to investors of 300,000 million pesetas (A$2,100m) and result in a capital saving in the short term of 1 ,100,000 million pesetas (A$7700m).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Science and Technology confirm the authenticity of a photograph published in the British Geographical Magazine of October 1983, page 494, the caption for which reads 'Crates of radioactive soil await shipment back to the United States of America after the dismantling of the United States nuclear reactor at McMurdo in the Antarctic'.
(2) Was a US nuclear reactor operational in the Antarctic; if so, when and where and for what purpose.
(3) Can the Minister obtain information as to the disposal of radioactive waste material from this reactor.
(4) Does the installation of a nuclear reactor in the Antarctic constitute a violation of the Antarctic Treaty.

(5) Is it a fact that, since 1961, the Antarctic has been kept free of military , nuclear, territorial and commercial rivalries by this treaty which can be reviewed by any of the signatories after 1991.
(6) What distance from Australian Antarctic Territory is McMurdo and what is the Federal Government's attitude to nuclear reactors operating in the Antarctic region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I cannot confirm the authenticity of the photograph published in the Geographical Magazine. However, I am aware that shipment of radioactive material from McMurdo took place between the end of 1972 and some time in 1979, at which time what had previously been the reactor site at McMurdo was released for unrestricted use.
(2) A reactor was operational at McMurdo Station in the Ross Dependency between 1962 and 1972 for the purpose of generating electricity.
(3) The reactor and contaminated material were shipped to the United States for disposal in South Carolina and California.

(5) The Antarctic Treaty is one of the most successful international agreements and certainly the most successful demilitarisation treaty. It stipulates that Antarctica should forever be used exclusively for peaceful purposes and not become the scene or object of international discord. The Treaty also prohibits nuclear explosions, the disposal of nuclear waste and measures of a military nature, and removes the potential for sovereignty disputes between Treaty Parties. While the Treaty is open to review after 1991 at the request of any consultative party, modification to the Treaty would require agreement by a majority of consultative parties. The Treaty itself has no finite lifetime.

(6) McMurdo is about 150 kilometres from the nearest point on the eastern boundary of the Australian Antarctic Territory. Australia has no intention to install nuclear reactors in the Antarctic, but provided that suitable safeguards prevent contamination of the environment, the Antarctic Treaty imposes no particular restrictions on the use of nuclear reactors in Antarctica. The Antarctic Treaty expressly prohibits nuclear explosions and the disposal of radioactive waste material on the continent. Recommendation VIII-12 of the eighth Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting restates the intention of the Treaty parties that there be no disposal of nuclear waste in the Antarctic Treaty Area. If it were proposed that a reactor be installed in the Australian Antarctic Territory, the Government would be concerned to ensure that adequate safeguards existed to ensure the protection of the Antarctic environment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1641) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning the videotex system which incorporated three separate questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When will Telecom Australia be in a position to provide a full videotex service?
(2) Is there any danger that the gateway facility will intrude into the security or privacy of third party data base owners?
(3) Will the Minister answer criticisms relating to Telecom's decision to use the British developed Prestel standard?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:
(1) Telecom has set a target of providing a full national videotex service by the end of 1984.

(2) No. The gateway facility simply enables third party data base operators to give wider public access to the information held. The operators would need to consider whether any security problems might arise from wider access to their systems and take any appropriate precautions before they are connected to the Telecom network.

(3) The British developed Prestel standard is the only standard established and currently in use commercially to any extent in Australia to this time. It is compatible with the teletext standard recommended by the Department of Communications and this means that the cost of television sets serving both videotex and teletext in Australia is minimised.
Prestel is also the most basic of the videotex displays and this is expected to facilitate access by terminals of other types to the Prestel compatible data bases.
Telecom is therefore currently supporting the Prestel standard in the interests of cost and the rapid expansion of videotex generally throughout Australia.

Telecom indicated, too, that the Australian videotex environment is similar to that in the United Kingdom. The knowledge available from the industry and working applications in that country will be of considerable assistance to Australian information providers and will assist the expansion of videotex.

Telecom is asking manufacturers here and abroad to indicate what immediate or firm developmental plans they have in regard to compatibility between standards. Telecom's aim is to eventually provide a national system with low cost accessibility from differing types of terminals to the various types of data bases which may be established but there is still much technical development needed before this can be achieved.
In the meantime, Telecom is providing capability through its AUSTPAC service for terminals to be connected through to data bases of their own standard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2759) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning standards applied in the United States for permissible exposure to asbestos fibres. I was also asked to outline the measures taken by the Australian Government to regulate the use of asbestos and the standards of safety that apply to exposure in the work place.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration issued an emergency temporary standard on 4 November 1983, covering permissible exposure levels to asbestos fibres for a wide range of Federal and State workers employed in the manufacturing, construction and maritime industries.

This emergency temporary standard reduced the permissible exposure levels from two fibres (longer than 5 micrometres) per cubic centimetre to 0.5 fibres per cubic centimetre, over an eight hour time weighted average period. This standard does not discriminate between asbestos fibre types.
The current Australian standard for occupational exposure to asbestos, as recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council, is:
One fibre per millilitre of air for Chrysotile and Amosite asbestos and
0.1 fibre per millilitre of air for Crocidolite, or blue asbestos.

The current Australian exposure standard differentiates between asbestos fibre types, and is more restrictive for Crocidolite than the emergency temporary standard issued by the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration. In addition, the 96th Session of the National Health and Medical Research, Council held in October 1983, has agreed that from 1 July 1984, the threshold limit value for Amosite asbestos will be reduced to 0.1 fibre per millilitre, the same as for Crocidolite asbestos.

As regards the measures being taken by the Australian Government to regulate the use of asbestos, I announced on 14 October 1983, in conjunction with the Minister for Territories and Local Government, that the proposed National Occupational Health and Safety Commission will give priority to the development of guidelines for the safe treatment and handling of asbestos, and this will form the basis of dealing with the problem on a national level.

Pending the establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission the Government has announced the establishment of a National Consultative Committee on Occupational Health and Safety to ensure full consultation with the State and Territories, unions and employers, and relevant Government departments. This Committee is an advisory body to the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, details of which were provided in my ministerial statement to the Parliament on 10 November 1983 ( Hansard, pages 2587-2593).

The National Consultative Committee discussed the issue of asbestos at its first meeting on 13 December 1983, and agreed to establish a working party to draw up interim guidelines dealing with the problems of asbestos in the workplace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3395) Senator Reynolds asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that in a paper entitled 'Estimates of Unemployment by Local Government Area', the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations lists 36 local government areas, of a total of 145, as having unemployment rates in excess of the Queensland average of 10 per cent? A study of community employment program announcements in Queensland made to date indicates that only a few of these high level unemployment areas are, in fact, represented, leaving up to 30 areas not as yet recognised by the allocation of funds for vital job creation projects. Given that many of these areas are in northern central and western Queensland, can the Minister assure Queenslanders that there will not be a capital city-south-east corner bias in the implementation of the Federal Government's important employment initiatives in that State?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Department's estimates identify 32 local government areas in Queensland with an unemployment rate in excess of 10 per cent at March 1983. The number of such areas shown in the paper 'Estimates of Unemployment by Local Government Area' is slightly higher at 36, due to the disaggregation of the Brisbane City Council area into Commonwealth Employment Service Office areas for analytical purposes. I stress that the Departmental estimates should be used cautiously as they may not fully reflect underlying unemployment levels due to the unavoidable need to make a number of assumptions in the estimation procedure. These assumptions relate in particular to population movements and changes in the composition of unemployment.

The estimates will play a role in the implementation of the Government's job creation initiatives in assisting consultative committees to direct funds to areas of greatest need. However, consultative committees are dependent on organisations and authorities from these areas submiting project proposals for assessment.
I understand that as of 15 December 1983 applications for community employment program funds had been received from all but two of the 32 areas of highest unemployment in Queensland.
Applications from 17 of these areas had been approved at that date for funding, with a total project value of $7.859m and program grants made to the value of $5 .599m.

Projects totalling over $15.95m in Commonwealth funds had been approved to 15 December 1983 throughout Queensland, representing 38.6 per cent of the State's total allocation in 1983-84. Applications from the remaining areas of high unemployment are currently under consideration.

The program is still in its early stages. Many project proposals are still under consideration and further proposals are expected to be submitted. It is the Government's intention that priority will be given to areas of high unemployment in the implementation of the Federal Government's important employment creation initiative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3600) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice concerning precautionary measures for computer operators:

ANSWER.PARA: In a recent speech the Minister said that estimates suggested that at least $6 billion a year was wasted through loss of production and other costs caused by injury and ill health stemming from occupational hazards. Occupational health and safety are matters of concern to workers using computers because of the many repetition injuries and eye problems which are occurring. Will the recently announced Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission be looking at the precautions needed for people working with computers?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-INOHSC-has been established to advise the Government on the detailed functions, structure, membership, staffing levels and methods of operation of a permanent National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-NOHSC-and Office-NOHSO-and a National Institute of Environmental and Occupational Health-NIEOH. The establishment of the INOHSC reflects the high priority the Government accords the development of a national framework through which occupational health and safety problems may be resolved.

The terms of reference of the INOHSC do not allow it to examine specific occupational health and safety issues. However, the NOHSC when established will develop standards and guidelines for specific occupational health and safety issues, such as the precautions needed for people working with computers and the NIEOH will provide hazard information, commission research and will advise on training needs of health and safety professionals.

In the past, consideration of specific occupational health and safety issues has been undertaken by various bodies including the sub-committees on occupational health and safety established by the National Labour Consultative Council and the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee. A National Consultative Committee on Occupational Health and Safety-NCCOHS-which represents a merging of these two sub-committees, has now been established to provide a means by which the INOHSC can consult fully with the States, employers and unions. The terms of reference of the NCCOHS also provide for it to consider specific occupational health and safety issues which arise in the period prior to the establishment of the permanent NOHSC. This activity will complement the initiatives of other bodies active in the occupational health and safety field such as the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Department of Health and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3880) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the categorisation of private hospitals under Medicare.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What new authorities, committees, bureaux, or other such groups;
(a) have been established; or
(b) are proposed, by or within this Department, since 5 March 1983.
(2) How many additional staff:
(a) have been, or are being appointed; or
(b) are proposed to be recruited, as a result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Steel Industry Authority, consisting of three part time members, as from 1 January 1984.
The Shipbuilding Industry Task Force chaired by the Department and having two industry and two ACTU representatives, as from 7 November 1983.
The Car Industry Council established on 6 October to report by 14 December 1983 .

A revised Australian Manufacturing Council is to be established along with 11 industry councils replacing previously existing industry advisory councils and covering various industry sectors and small business.

(2) Five additional staff will be required to form a secretariat for the Steel Industry Authority. Approximately 15 more staff will be required for import watch and bounty activity as the steel plans become fully operative.
A secretariat for the revised Australian Manufacturing Council is presently being examined by the Public Service Board. Thirty-two additional staff have been sought.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many assessments have now been issued by the Commissioner of Taxation with copy notices to vendor shareholders for the purposes of the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Act.

(2) How many of the companies referred to in (1) had been served with notices of assessment in the ordinary course, i.e. without reference to the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Act and vendor shareholders.
(3) What steps have been taken to collect the tax from the companies referred to in both (1) and (2).
(4) Has the Commissioner issued notices of assessment to companies in all cases and taken normal recovery procedures; if not:
(a) has this matter been referred to the Special Prosecutor for legal examination; if so, has an explanatory report been issued; if not, when will such a report be forthcoming; and
(b) was this matter considered by the Treasurer in considering the re- appointment of the Commissioner of Taxation and the appointment of his successor .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Commissioner for Taxation has advised that since the enactment of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 14,000 company assessments, or copies thereof, in respect of some 5,000 companies have been served on vendor shareholders and other former owners as members of the representative class for each of those companies.

Precise statistics of assessments issued prior to the enactment of the recoupment tax legislation were not kept. However, on the basis of available information it is estimated that, of the companies identified as having been stripped of assets and rendered unable to pay their tax, assessments had been issued in respect of 60 per cent of those companies. Since the enactment of the legislation all company notices have been issued in accordance with the requirements of that legislation.

(3) Recovery action against stripped companies would not be productive as, at the completion of the stripping operation, the companies have no assets with which they can meet their taxation liabilities.

In these circumstances, if it were not for the recoupment tax legislation, proceedings would need to be instituted against persons associated with those companies, whether immediately before or after the sale of the shares, who may have breached the law. Those persons could, depending upon which laws might be found to have been breached, possibly be ordered to recompense the companies and thereby enable them to meet their liabilities.

However, because of the uncertainty of successfully recovering the unpaid company tax by this means, and in view of the fact that any tax that might ultimately be recovered would not be recovered in what could be regarded as a reasonable time, the recoupment tax was brought in to provide a clearer and more certain technique for collecting the unpaid tax.

Because of these considerations, the Commissioner's general policy has been to rely on the recoupment tax legislation to collect the company tax. In a limited number of cases representative of cases in which legal processes were already well advanced, liquidation proceedings have been continued but I have already mentioned the collection difficulties in relation to possible recovery of tax from the company or associated persons.

(4) Under the terms of the recoupment tax legislation, the service of a company notice of assessment on a member of the representative class constitutes service on the company. As I have already indicated, service of notices of assessment has been effected in respect of some 5,000 companies which represents approximately 85 per cent of the number of companies identified as having been stripped of pre-tax profits. I have been advised by the Commissioner that necessary action is now in course to enable the issue of notices of assessments in respect of the remaining companies. When this is done, action will be taken expeditiously to collect the tax under the recoupment tax legislation.

(a) The Commissioner informs the Special Prosecutor on a regular basis of the progress made in relation to the administration of the recoupment tax legislation. The Special Prosecutor is also aware of those cases in which liquidation proceedings have been continued.
(b) No such matter was taken into consideration in the re-appointment of the Commissioner and the appointment of his successor.

(3) What contracts include provision for conversion and enrichment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(*) Prior to completion of production at Mary Kathleen in October 1982, MKU produced sufficient yellowcake to meet all outstanding commitments. Product for outstanding deliveries is currently stored at conversion plants.

(1) (d) and (e) Contractural information relating to pricing and annual delivery details has been provided to the Government on a commercial-in- confidence basis and is not available for publication.

(2) The conditions and restrictions governing the conversion and enrichment of Australian uranium are specified in the bilateral nuclear cooperation and safeguards agreements that Australia has concluded with partner countries and EURATOM. At any particular time, the conditions and restrictions relevant for uranium exported under any contract are those specified in the relevant bilateral agreements in force at that time.

Australia's preparedness in the case of non-nuclear weapons states (NNWS) to conclude such agreements only with those adhering to the Treaty on the Non- Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) functions as a significant minimum condition in its own right. There is the additional requirement for a bilateral agreement with Australia. These agreements specify that Australian-origin nuclear material (AONM) subject to any given agreement (whether with a nuclear weapon state, or with an NNWS) is covered by a stringent regime of international safeguards applied by the International Atomic Energy Agency to verify solely peaceful usage. Strict conditions for applying physical security provisions at agreed international levels to the AONM are also specified in the agreements.
Within this framework:

(A) Australian-origin uranium or derived material may be converted and/or low- enriched (up to 20 percent U 235) in those countries with which Australia has a nuclear cooperation or safeguards agreement in place and operative.

(B) Under a number of Australia's bilateral agreements, specific provisions have been included to allow our treaty partners to have conversion and/or low- enrichment of AONM carried out in a specified third country not party to a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia, subject to certain additional requirements being met, including the granting of prior consent by Australia to any such proposal. The additional requirements specify amongst other things that the partner concerned make acceptable arrangements for the return to itself or to another country with which Australia has a nuclear safeguards agreement of a quantity of nuclear material equivalent to all AONM shipped into the specified third country. Finnish and Swedish utilities have made use of such provisions in Australia's agreements with Finland and Sweden to have Australia's uranium enriched in the USSR.
(C) Australian supplied uranium is not permitted to be enriched beyond 20 percent U 235 in any country without prior consent by Australia. To date no country has sought such consent.

(3), (4) and (5) No Australian uranium sales contracts provide for conversion and/or enrichment services. In all cases the contractual arrangements provide for delivery in the form of uranium concentrates. Subject to the conditions and requirements imposed by Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements, AONM may be processed at any of the approved facilities in bilateral partner countries providing conversion and/or enrichment services. Such services are provided on a commercial basis by, in the case of conversion, Allied Chemical Corp. (USA), British Nuclear Fuels Ltd (UK), Comurhex (France), Eldorado Nuclear Ltd (Canada) , and Kerr McGee Nuclear Corp. (USA), and, in the case of enrichment, by the Department of Energy (USA), Eurodif (France), and Urenco (Netherlands and UK). Additionally, ANOM may be enriched by Techsnabexport (USSR) in those instances where specific provisions (referred to in (2) (B) above) for toll-processing in a third country, not party to a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia, are operable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What provisions or instructions have been set out to ensure accountability of funds paid out under Division 312 Special Fund for Expenditure in relation to Government programs at the direction of the Minister for Finance.
(2) What reporting procedures have been adopted.
(3) How much of the funds have been expended so far.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The accountability requirements of the Audit Act 1901 will, of course, fully apply to the expenditure of funds provided under Division 312. The following procedures have also been established for the administration of Division 312 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84:

(a) The Minister for Finance and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Public Service Matters advised Ministers on 16 November 1983 of his approval of additional staffing agreed pursuant to procedures approved by the Government. Some further approvals are likely.

(b) Departments were advised on 22 November 1983 that the terms of the abovementioned procedures require departments to absorb to the maximum extent possible within Budget provisions, the costs-salaries and directly associated administrative expenses-of any additional staffing approvals.

(c) Departments were informed that they should apply for funds from Division 312 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84 where, after thorough examination of the scope for absorption, they consider additional costs, which are directly related to the Minister's approval referred to in (a), to be unavoidable in 1983 -84.

(d) Applications providing full justification of the amounts sought and the heads of expenditure to which the expenditure should be charged (pursuant to section 7 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84) are to be directed to the Department of Finance.

(e) The Department of Finance will examine applications for funds against the criteria set out in Division 312 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84. Where that Department is satisfied that the application meets the criteria it will recommend to the Minister for Finance that he make a determination under clause (a) of Division 312 and a direction under Clause 7 of the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84.

(f) Where the Minister makes a determination and gives a direction in that respect, funds will be issued to departments, in the same way as occurs for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, against the appropriate head of Expenditure ; funds so issued will remain as a final charge against Division 312 and will not need to be subsumed in Additional Estimates.

(2) Under clause (b) of the conditions applying to Division 312 the Minister for Finance is required to submit to the Parliament as soon as practicable after a determination is made by him, particulars of moneys made available for expenditure in respect of salaries and payments in the nature of salary and/or administrative expenses. The reporting of Division 312 allocations will be essentially as for the Advance to the Minister for Finance except that the reports will be made available to Parliament as soon as practicable after the making of a determination and will not await the end of the month as for the Advance.
(3) No funds have yet been expended under Division 312.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Retirement of Neil Inall

(2) Why was Neil Inall replaced or retired, given the age structure of the Australian farming community and the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television audience for such programs is not exactly youthful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Age was not a factor as evidenced by Mr Inall's replacement, Mr Jim Downes, who is 49 years old.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3395) Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question concerning the future of the Australian Defence Force presence at Butterworth, relations with the ASEAN countries, and the future of ex-Royal Australian Navy Skyhawk aircraft and pilots.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Australia's relations with the ASEAN nations are sound and close. It is a primary aim of the Government that they should remain so.

With regard to the future of the Australian Defence Force presence at Butterworth, decisions will be taken in consultation with the Governments of Malaysia and Singapore. Upon completion of the review of this matter by the Government, there will be early and comprehensive discussions with those countries.

In respect of the honourable senator's suggestion relating to Skyhawk aircraft, I confirm that the decision which I announced on 3 May, that naval fixed wing aircraft would be phased out, is final. Six Skyhawk aircraft have been withdrawn from service, and the remaining four are being used for target towing pending the development of an alternative system.

The announcement also mentioned arrangements for the future employment of Naval personnel affected and, largely because of these, the wastage of ex-Skyhawk pilots from the Australian Defence Force has been minimal to date. Of the 59 pilots, nine have elected to transfer and have been accepted by the Royal Naval and Royal Air Force, two have left to seek civilian employment in Australia, while 34 have elected to transfer to the Royal Australian Air Force and the remainder have decided to continue to serve in the Royal Australian Navy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3505) Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Finance, a question without notice concerning the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Finance has provided the following information in reply to the honourable senator's question:

Senator Coates will be aware that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust was established under the Superannuation Act 1976 to invest and manage the Superannuation Fund. In fulfilling these responsibilities, the Trust has adopted investment policies directed towards achieving the highest possible return in the interests of all contributors, consistent with the level of security offered .

The Chairman of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, Mr Hammond, has advised me that in 1982-83 new investments made by the Trust (excluding short- term investments) totalled about $400m, turnover of short-term investments totalled about $1.7 billion, while the cost value of all investments held by the Trust exceeded $2 billion for the first time. All this investment activity was handled by a relatively small investment staff.

Given its limited staff resources the Trust has necessarily imposed a lower limit on the size of investments below which individual proposals cannot be considered. While the Trust recognises that many small investment proposals may otherwise be attractive, it must nevertheless manage its activities within the constraints imposed by the resources available to it.

In respect of the Trust's property investment in Tasmania, Mr Hammond has advised that very few proposals have been received from Tasmania since the Trust gained property investment powers in 1976, and that there have always been other property investment proposals available which have met the Trust's investment criteria to a greater extent, especially in relation to size. Nevertheless, Mr Hammond has assured me that, in pursuit of its policy to invest moneys of the Superannuation Fund to achieve the highest possible return in the interests of all contributors, investment proposals originating from Tasmania and which are of an appropriate size, will continue to receive careful consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3647) Senator Crowley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning dental treatment of secondary school children and needy groups.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
I have read with interest the findings of the South Australian Public Accounts Committee with regard to the efficiency and effectiveness of the school dental service in South Australia.

Under the Australian school dental scheme which was initiated in 1973, school dental services in all States were rapidly developed. Together with various preventive programs such as the fluoridation of water, this development has led to a marked improvement in the dental health of children.

Specific purpose grants to States for school school dental services were discontinued by the previous Government on 1 July 1981 and were absorbed within general revenue payments. Under the revised arrangements the responsibility for school dental services rests with individual States which also determine the priority to be given to school dental services in the allocation of funds. Since July 1981 the Federal Government has had no direct responsibility for school dental services.

The initiation and financing of review and evaluation of school dental services are also matters for individual States. The Federal Government did not contribute funds for the review in South Australia to which the honourable senator has referred.

I am most sympathetic to the dental needs of children, and am hopeful that in the long-term school dental services will be further expanded to include secondary school children. However, such expansion must be viewed in the context of the available funds and competing priorities. There is a continuing need for restraint in expenditure.

In the present circumstances it would be inappropriate for the Federal Government to allocate funds for the dental care of secondary school children. However, the possibility of providing additional funds for the expansion of school dental services is being kept under consideration.

With regard to dental treatment of pensioners and other needy groups, I must emphasize that this is a responsibility of States though of course it is an area of concern to the Federal Government. While extension of Medicare cannot currently be contemplated, the possibility of including dental treatment in the Medicare arrangements at some future time cannot be ruled out. Clearly this would be of assistance to needy groups.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3644) Senator Reid asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, when discussions on the visit to Sydney by HMS Invincible began, at what level, and when and why the British High Commission sought an interview with the Minister for Defence.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The possibility of a visit by a Task Group led by HMS Invincible was raised initially on a Navy-to-Navy basis in February 1983 in the context of RN Fleet program forward planning. A formal request for a visit towards the end of the year was received on 24 June 1983. The acting Minister for Defence welcomed the deployment and port visits in a public statement on 15 July 1983.
The British High Commissioner met with the Minister for Defence on 29 November 1983, when the possibility of HMS Invincible dry-docking in Sydney arose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3741) Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, to consider tabling all relevant signals, correspondence or records of conversation relating to discussions between Australian and British authorities as to the possibility of HMS Invincible dry-docking in Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The departmental documents which the honourable senator has asked me to table concern confidential discussions between the Australian and United Kingdom governments. It has been the practice of successive governments to protect the confidentiality of discussions with other governments. This Government does not intend to depart from the practice. Accordingly, it would not be appropriate to table the documents, as requested by Senator Guilfoyle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3749) Senator Kilgariff asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, the cost of work at the Captain Cook drydock in preparing for its possible use by HMS Invincible, and who would meet the costs involved.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

When it seemed that HMS Invincible might go into dry-dock, the Garden Island Dockyard undertook preliminary preparations, including undocking HMAS Adelaide, earlier than anticipated. Costs associated with the preparations were of the order of $30,000.
Such preparations are part of the general operation of the dockyard, and the associated costs are met from the Defence Outlay.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 12 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the United States Congress recently investigated the operations of the International Atomic Energy Agency-(IAEA).
(2) Did the investigation come to the following findings:
(a) that IAEA inspectors are forbidden to look for clandestine facilities, that is hidden stocks of bomb making material or reprocessing plants;
(b) that the IAEA only inspects material that a nation has 'declared' to it;
(c) that IAEA inspectors are only allowed to investigate plants or nations where they have been given notice of such investigation weeks in advance;
(d) that the IAEA sees its function as promoting the atomic trade not policing it;
(e) that the IAEA does not have the proper equipment to monitor plants in the long intervals (up to a year) between visits; and
(f) that the IAEA's surveillance devices are inadequate in that they can be easily by-passed and that the system of sealing is poor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The operations of the International Atomic Energy Agency-(IAEA)-were the subject of hearings by the US Senate Committee on Foreign Relations in December 1981 and by sub-committees of the US House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Affairs in March 1982. In addition, committees and sub-committees of both the US House of Representatives and the US Senate conduct regular hearings on nuclear non-proliferation and safeguards issues which include in some cases examination of the operations of the IAEA. One such case was the hearings in June 1981 before the US Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the Israeli air strike in that month against a nuclear research reactor in Iraq.

(2) (a) to (f) In the course of hearings in recent years, a number of witnesses have given evidence on the operations of the IAEA. Criticisms of the IAEA, incorporating the sort of points listed in the question, have been made, notably by a former IAEA inspector, Mr Roger Richter. These criticisms have been rebutted in testimony, including by the US Ambassador to the IAEA, Mr Richard Kennedy, who generally praised the operations of the IAEA. To my knowledge, neither the US House of Representatives nor the US Senate have themselves-for example, through reports of committees or sub-commitees or through resolutions- come to the findings listed in the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Federal Government make arrangements so that Commonwealth employees in the Northern Territory are able to purchase Commonwealth government houses in which they are residing, given the arrangement of the previous Federal Government under which Commonwealth employees in the Northern Territory were able to purchase Commonwealth houses, and the current arrangement in the Northern Territory whereby Northern Territory government employees can buy Northern Territory houses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It has been decided that the home sales scheme will not be re-introduced for Commonwealth employees in the Northern Territory occupying Commonwealth-owned houses. Reintroduction of the scheme would exacerbate the shortage of staff housing and lead to further demands for capital expenditure on replacement stock .

A tenants' home sales scheme does not operate in respect of Commonwealth staff housing elsewhere in Australia and is not consistent with the Commonwealth's present role of employer only in the Northern Territory. In addition, the Northern Territory Government has agreed that occupancy of Commonwealth staff housing would not prejudice eligibility of Commonwealth employees for community housing provided by the Northern Territory Housing Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the racial mix of staff employed at the Australian embassy in South Africa, that is, black, coloured, white.
(2) What is the method of interviewing intending migrants to Australia.
(3) Where do interviews take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am assured that staff in South Africa locally engaged by the Australian Government have been employed solely on the basis of ability and qualifications and that race was not a consideration. The classification of persons by race is inherently offensive to the Australian Government. Racial terms are however used by the South African Government and in these terms, staff employed by the Australian Government in South Africa are:
Pretoria: Black-one, White-ten, Coloured-two, Indian-one.
Capetown: White-four, Coloured-two.
Johannesburg: White-five, Black-two.

(2) Applicants for migrant entry and their family members are interviewed in accordance with the standard format and procedures set out in the Migrant Entry Handbook. This is a public document. Its provisions are observed by Australian migration interviewers throughout the world.

(3) Interviews are conducted at the embassy in Pretoria and the consulate in Capetown. Interviewing officers from these centres also conduct interviews in Durban, Port Elizabeth and East London as required.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Authorities, Committees and Bureaus: Department of Resources and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What new authorities, committees, bureaus, or other such groups: (a) have been established; or (b) are proposed, by or within this department, since 5 March 1983.
(2) How many additional staff: (a) have been, or are being, appointed; or (b) are proposed to be recruited, as a result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
