ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Qantas: Films Shown on International Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 30 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many films have been shown by Qantas on its international services in the last financial year.
(2) How many of these films were made in Australia.
(3) Is there any policy to give preference to Australian made films on Qantas; if so, when was it introduced; if not, will one be introduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Qantas has advised that for the financial year July 1982 to June 1983, 24 films were booked for use on Qantas aircraft.
(2) During this period, 7 of the booked films were made in Australia.

(3) Qantas's aim is to show as many Australian made films on its aircraft as possible. The only restriction on this intent is that in doing so Qantas must achieve its primary objective of providing the highest possible standard of in- flight entertainment to its international passengers.

It is the company's view that the revenue potential of the airline market could be better known by Australian film producers, and in October 1982 Qantas instigated and sponsored a 'Selling to Airlines' seminar for Australian film producers, with the support of the Australian Film Commission. I am advised this seminar proved effective, and a follow-up is planned for February 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Australian Government's attitude to the continuing British military presence in Ulster.

(2) Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs discussed the Ulster question with the British Government or its representatives since 5 March 1983; if so, can he indicate whether Britain is likely to consider a timetable for withdrawal of its forces from Northern Ireland in the near future.

(3) Would the Australian Government be prepared to sponsor a motion in the United Nations enabling a UN peacekeeping force to relieve British forces of their responsibilities in Northern Ireland until a solution to the crisis can be found.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's policy on Northern Ireland is based on a genuine concern at the continuing tragedy of the province and at the same time upon a dispassionate assessment of the situation itself and of those parties most directly and legitimately concerned-the local people and the British Government.

The Government's view is that the situation in Northern Ireland is the responsibility of the British Government-for historical, political and social reasons. It follows that a lasting solution to the Northern Ireland problem is a matter for the Northern Irish people and the British Government to resolve. This is not to deny that the Irish Government has a special interest in developments in the North.

While it would not be appropriate for Australia to seek to play an active role in this situation, it is the Government's strong hope that there should be recognition of, and reconciliation between, the interests of both political traditions in the North. The Government also, of course, condemns all acts of terrorist violence, which are not only repugnant in themselves but can only impede progress towards a solution.
(3) Sponsorship of such a motion would not be consistent with the policy enunciated under (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any amount been spent under Division 312 Special Fund for Expenditure in Relation to Government Programs at the Direction of the Minister of Finance by the Department of Social Security; if so, how much and what are the details of those expenditures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Finance has approved additional urgent and unavoidable obligations of $5.7m against normal departmental appropriation items to enable implementation of the assets test to proceed.

The Department of Finance has advised that funds under normal departmental appropriation items will be augmented from Division 312 (special funds for expenditure in relation to Government programs at the discretion of the Minister for Finance) when the Minister for Finance has issued the necessary determination.
At 31 December 1983 income and assets test expenditure recorded against normal departmental appropriation items was about $1.9m, comprising some $1.7m for overtime and administrative expenses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the names of the organisations and individuals consulted with by the Minister for Social Security following the announcement of the introduction of an assets test in the August 1983 Budget up to the introduction of the legislation.
(2) What were the duration of those consultations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since the announcement by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech on 23 August 1983, I have consulted and am continuing to consult with a large number of organisations and individuals about the introduction of an income and assets test. Some of the major organisations consulted have included the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Council on the Ageing and the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled.

(2) Because the consultations are continuing, discussions have already occurred over a period of several months with a corresponding variation in time of the duration of my meetings with organisations and individuals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, uon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated full year cost of the abolition of the income test for females aged 60 to 64 years and males aged 65 to 69 years and all persons aged 70 years and over.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The estimated full year cost of the abolition of the income test on pensions is as follows:
Females 60 to 64 years $605m; males 65 to 69 years $253m; females 65 to 69 years $282m; persons 70 years and over $560m.

These estimates represent the cost of bringing existing part rate pensioners to full rate and giving non-pensioners full pension at rates current from November 1983. The estimates are based on estimated numbers of persons and pensioners at the end of December 1983. The costs are gross costs in that they make no allowance for the additional revenue that would result from taxation of the payments concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any possibility of the British aircraft carrier Invincible going into the Captain Cook dry dock in Sydney for repairs to her propeller shaft.

(2) What de-ammunitioning procedures will be followed if this is still likely to occur, despite all the confusion and uncertainty generated by the Government' s mishandling of the visit of the Invincible.
(3) Can the work be carried out without the help having to remove its explosive armaments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) Since the British Government decided that, for operational reasons, it did not wish to pursue the possibility of using the Captain Cook dry dock for repairs to HMS Invincible the matters raised in the honourable senator' s question are now hypothetical.
